application for a similar other license on premises other than described in
this application and the disposition of such application. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-
2004; amd. 2016 Code)
4-1-6: FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE:
   A.   Each individual applicant or each entity, upon filing an original
application, may be required to furnish certain financial information as
follows: (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004; amd. 2016 Code)
      1.   A detailed statement of assets and liabilities of the business
enterprise for which license is sought.
      2.   The names and addresses of all secured creditors and a description
of the security interest of each.
      3.   The names and addresses of all creditors who have any right to
control the use or disposition of the business or any asset thereof.
      4.   The name and address of each creditor who holds indebtedness of the
business totaling in the aggregate twenty percent (20%) or more of the net
worth of the business.
      5.   A detailed profit and loss statement for the last preceding business
year.
      6.   In the case of a corporation or entity, a copy of the latest annual
report required to be filed pursuant to state law as now or hereafter amended.
      7.   A detailed description of all agreements or obligations which
purport to bind any successor to the present applicant or licensee to continue
to purchase, rent or accept any goods, wares, or services from a specified
supplier thereof.
   B.   The financial statements required to be filed by this section shall be
held confidential except for official purposes, and it shall be unlawful for
any person to divulge said financial statements except for official purposes or
under order of a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-7: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
All applicants applying for any classification of liquor license and all
licensees applying for liquor license renewal to be issued by the village,
including any subclassification license, before any liquor license is
authorized and issued pursuant to this chapter, shall provide to the village
administrator an endorsement on insurance policies insuring the village as an
insured for the period the license is in effect, as follows: dramshop insurance
for the maximum limits required by the Illinois liquor control act of 1934, as
amended, and on a general liability policy in the amount of one million dollars
($1,000,000.00). There shall be compliance with these requirements before the
issuance or renewal of any liquor license. (Ord. 2014-1416, 9-16-2014; amd.
2016 Code)
4-1-8: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Schedule Of Fees: The annual fees for the issuance of licenses pursuant
to this chapter shall be as enumerated on schedule L, a copy of which shall be
on file in the office of the village clerk. Said schedule L shall set forth all
license fees by classification and/or subclassification and shall be modified
or amended only by action of the president and board of trustees.
   B.   Payment Of Fees: All retail dealer's liquor license fees, including
renewals, shall be paid to the village at the time of application submission.
No application shall be considered, acted upon or granted until and unless all
related fees are paid. Said payment shall be made by cash or money order or
cashier's check made payable to the village of Peoria Heights.
   C.   Refunds: In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall
be returned to the applicant. No refunds shall be made for those licenses that
terminate due to a business cessation or as the result of license revocation
pursuant to the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-9: SUITABILITY OF LOCATION:
Before the issuance of any license provided pursuant to the terms of this
chapter, the village president shall consider the following issues in
determining the suitability of license issuance:
   A.   The zoning classification of the proposed premises.
   B.   The character of the surrounding area.
   C.   The impact of additional vehicular traffic and parking relative to the
creation of hazards and/or congestion.
   D.   Any statements of interested persons, either oral or written.
   E.   Any past operating history of the licensee and the proposed site.
   F.   In the case of the question of a subclassification #1 license renewal,
whether the music or other live entertainment is audible in the nearest
sleeping room of a residential dwelling unit in any R-1, R-2, or R-3 zoning
district when the windows are closed. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-10: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES:
A.   Major Classifications: Licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter are hereby divided into the following classes:
   1.   Class A-1: Class A-1 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor on the premises of any tavern for consumption on the premises
as well as other retail sales of such liquor.
   2.   Class A-2: Class A-2 licenses shall authorize the retail sale of
alcoholic liquors on the premises in any restaurant which complies with the
requirement that thirty three percent (33%) or more of the gross revenue in any
month from the operation of the licensed premises must be derived from the
serving of meals, for consumption on the premises, as well as other retail
sales of such liquor.
   3.   Class B: Class B licenses shall authorize the retail sale of beer, ale
and wine, but not alcoholic liquor, for consumption on the premises as well as
other retail sales of such beer, ale and wine.
      a.   There is hereby created a subclass B-1 license. A B-1 license is a
supplemental license to a Class B license and authorizes the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor in packages.
   4.   Class C: Class C licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor, beer, ale and wine in packages, but not for consumption on the premises
where sold.
   There is created a subclass C-1 license. A C-1 license is a supplemental
license to a class C license and authorizes the sale of alcoholic liquor, beer,
ale, and wine in packages, but not for consumption on the premises where sold,
for twenty four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week.
   5.   Class D: Class D licenses are to clubs which shall authorize such
organization’s retail sale only to club members and guests accompanied by club
members on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale and wine for
consumption on the premises only.
   6.   Class E:
      a.   Class E licenses are issued to civic, religious, fraternal and
nonprofit organizations for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale and
wine for a temporary period not to exceed ten (10) days, and any such license
so issued under this classification shall be intended to be used only for a
bona fide special event or occasion.
      b.   Where such license issued under class E shall involve the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine in an outdoor location as part of
an approved public activity, the licensee shall comply with the following
additional conditions:
      (1)   The proposed licensee shall submit proof of adequate dramshop
insurance required by the Illinois liquor control act of 1934, as amended or in
the future revised, prior to being issued such license.
      (2)   To protect the public order, all licensees shall either provide
security guards or have a telephone at the bar or serving facility where any
alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine is dispensed. The village police department
will not provide security guards to licensees.
      (3)   To protect persons serving alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine, all
licensees under this subsection A6 shall provide a reasonably substantial
structure across which all alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine is served.
      (4)   Consumption of any and all alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine
shall be restricted to a confined area of the grounds on which the event is
conducted. The proposed licensee shall attach to the application a drawing
designating the area and the means of confinement.
      (5)   The licensee shall provide personnel at all exits to ensure that no
alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine is taken from the area and that effective
supervision is in place at all times to ensure against the transfer of
alcoholic liquor to minors.
      (6)   Prior to the actual sale of any alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or
wine, the licensee shall contact the village fire department to inspect the
premises and issue an occupancy permit and limit. The licensee shall cause the
conformance to said limit at all times.
   7.   Class F: Class F single event license is issued for a six (6) hour
period during a single day only, between the hours of four o’clock (4:00) P.M.
and ten o’clock (10:00) P.M., from Monday through Saturday, for the dispensing
of wine and beer during a single event held by a civic, religious, business,
not for profit, governmental body, or fraternal organization. Any food served
at the event must comply with all public health rules and regulations. A single
license issuing pursuant to this subsection A7 may only be issued once per year
to any organization.
   The proposed licensee shall submit proof of adequate dramshop insurance
required by the Illinois liquor control act of 1934, as amended or in the
future revised, prior to being issued such license.
   8.   Class G: Class G caterer retail license shall be a license permitting
the sale or service of alcoholic liquor by a caterer retailer, defined as “a
person who serves alcoholic liquor for consumption, either on site or off site,
whether the location is licensed or unlicensed, as an incidental part of food
service when prepared meals and foods and alcoholic liquors are sold as a
package price agreed upon under contract”, which alcoholic liquor is served in
connection with the catering contract and for consumption only on the premises
where the food is served. Class G licenses shall be subject to the following:
      a.   In order to be eligible for a class G license, a caterer retailer
must have a valid license issued by the Illinois liquor control commission as
required by the Illinois liquor control act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
1-1 et seq.
      b.   A class G license shall only be issued after the applicant can
demonstrate, with proper documentation to the village liquor control
commissioner or the village administrator, that the applicant is operating a
bona fide catering business.
      c.   The licensee shall, for each catering event, have an agreed upon
catering contract. Any catering contract shall be furnished to the village
liquor control commissioner or his agent upon a written request.
      d.   The sale of alcoholic liquor shall be incidental to the food
service. The revenue which the licensee derives for the sale of food must
comprise at least fifty one percent (51%) of the gross revenue earned from the
sale of food and alcoholic liquor at each and every event or function.
      e.   No alcoholic liquor, pursuant to a catering contract, shall be sold
or served at a single location for more than eight (8) consecutive hours. The
sale and service of alcoholic liquor shall only be allowed on Monday through
Sunday from ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. until one o’clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day.
      f.   The event or function shall not be open to the general public but
only to invited guests of the party requesting catering service.
      g.   One or more employees of the class G license holder shall at all
times be present throughout the event or function and be capable of observing
any and all areas in or on the premises where alcoholic liquor is being sold or
served.
      h.   The licensee must implement measures to ensure that minors are not
served alcoholic liquors and do not consume alcoholic liquor on the premises of
any place alcoholic liquor is being sold or served as authorized by a class G
license.
      i.   Class G license holders shall be exempt from sections
4-1-15 and
4-1-16 of this chapter.
      j.   Any applicant for a class G license shall submit proof of adequate
dramshop insurance required by the Illinois liquor control act of 1934, as
amended, prior to being issued such license covering the sale and of alcoholic
beverages pursuant to a retail catering contract.
   9.   Class H: Class H licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic
liquors for consumption on the premises for only two days per week subject to
the following provisions:
      a.   The days of the week shall be listed on the application and the
license. The days of the week may be changed by the applicant after receiving
written approval from the local liquor control commissioner of an amendment to
the license and a revised license is issued.
      b.   The annual fee for the class H license shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) which shall be in addition to any other fees required by license
holders pursuant to this chapter. Class H licenses shall not be prorated for
any length of time less than six (6) months or for less than the annual fee of
fifty dollars ($50.00).
   10.   Class I: Class I licenses shall authorize the retail sale of milk-
based and/or sherbet based dessert products containing alcoholic liquor from
the premises of any ice cream parlor for consumption on such premises, and the
retail sale of packaged milk-based and/or sherbet based dessert products
containing alcoholic liquor in fully sealed containers from the premises of any
ice cream parlor for consumption off of such premises.
      a.   The annual license fee for a Class I Liquor License shall be four
hundred dollars ($400.00).
   11.   Class J: Class J licenses shall authorize the retail sale of beer,
wine and ale, including beer brewed on-site at the licensed premises, for
consumption on such premises, and the retail sale in fully sealed containers of
packaged beer brewed on-site at the licensed premises for consumption off of
such premises.
B.   Subclassifications:
   1.   Subclassification #1:
      a.   A category of liquor license is hereby created as subclassification
#1, separate from all other licenses issued pursuant to this chapter, which
shall be available to those licensees holding a currently valid A-1, A-2, B or
D license issued under this chapter.
      b.   Subclassification #1 shall govern the outdoor sale and consumption
of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine. In addition to all other requirements
pursuant to this chapter, the following requirements shall be met:
      (1)   The areas designated for outdoor sale and consumption of alcoholic
liquor shall be attached or directly adjacent to the existing building for
which a currently valid liquor license is in effect.
      (2)   A scale drawing shall be submitted to show the method of
confinement that will be utilized to restrict the removal by patrons of
alcoholic liquor from the designated outdoor area.
      (3)   A minimum of two (2) exits shall exist from the designated outdoor
area, only one of which is to be through the building attached or directly
adjacent thereto.
      (4)   All licensees shall provide a reasonably substantial structure
across which the alcoholic liquor shall be served.
      (5)   As part of the application process, the village clerk shall cause
notices to be sent to surrounding property owners within a three hundred foot
(300') radius of the proposed designated outdoor area announcing the licensee’s
intention and requesting written comments. The receipt of any written comments
from surrounding property owners received within ten (10) days from the date of
notice shall be considered by the village president in the granting or denial
of a subclassification #1 license. Any and all expenses incurred in the
processing of these notices shall be the responsibility of the applicant.
   2.   Subclassification 1A:
      a.   A category of liquor license is hereby created as Subclassification
1A, separate from all other licenses issued pursuant to this chapter, and shall
be available to those licensees holding a currently valid A-1, A-2, or B
license issued for the B-1 Central Business District.
      b.   Subclassification 1A shall govern the outdoor sale and consumption
of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine in the Village right-of-way and located
in the B-1 Central Business District. In addition to all other requirements
pursuant to this chapter, the following requirements shall be met:
      (1)   Meet all criteria included under Subclassification 1.
      (2)   The licensee shall be responsible to see that no customers,
employees, or other persons remove alcoholic liquor and beverages from the
designated outdoor sidewalk, except for the employee carrying alcoholic liquor
directly between the establishment and the sidewalk area.
      (3)   The licensee shall be responsible to see that no person is served
or consumes alcoholic liquor in the designated outdoor sidewalk unless seated
in the seating which has been provided in the designated outdoor sidewalk.
      (4)   Any Class A-1, A-2 or B license holders in the B-1 Central Business
District who have a Subclassification 1A license for sidewalk sales shall be
permitted the sale of alcoholic liquor from eleven o’clock (11:00) A.M. to the
closing hours authorized for A-1, A-2 and B license holders.
   3.   Subclassification 2:
      a.   A category of liquor license is hereby created as Subclassification
2 which shall be separate from all other licenses issued under this chapter and
which shall be available only to those licensees currently issued a valid A-1,
A-2, B or D license under this chapter.
      b.   Subclassification 2 is a supplemental license authorizing the sale
of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale, or wine to the public for consumption on the
premises from six o’clock (6:00) A.M. until one o’clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day on Sunday through Wednesday and from six o’clock (6:00) A.M.
until two o’clock (2:00) A.M. the following day on Thursday, Friday and
Saturday. (Ord. 2016-1486, 10-4-2016; amd. Ord. 2021-1658, 7-20-2021; Ord.
2023-1692, 1- -2023; Ord. 2023-1709, 10-17-2023; Ord. 2025-1751, 1-7-2025)
4-1-11: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
In order to protect the public health, safety, and welfare through the
promotion of temperance in the consumption of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale and
wine, the number of licenses available pursuant to this chapter shall be as
follows:
Class Of License Number Of Authorized Licenses
Class Of License Number Of Authorized Licenses
A-1              14
A-2              16
B                5
B-1              1
C                5
C-1              3
D                2
E                No more than 2 at any 1 time
F                No more than 1 in effect at 1 time and only 1 event license
                 per year per entity or organization
G                No limit
H                1
I                2
J                1
 
   B.   From and after the adoption of this ordinance, the Liquor Commissioner
or his/her designee, shall maintain a current list of all authorized licenses,
and shall report to the Village Board promptly at any time there is a change in
the number of licenses, irrespective of the reason for the change.
   C.   In the event any license(s) shall be revoked by final administrative
action of the Liquor Commissioner and any appeals to the Illinois Liquor
Commission or the courts of this state shall have been exhausted, such license
(s) shall be automatically void and the Liquor Commissioner or his/her designee
shall decrease the number of authorized licenses by the number of such revoked
license(s).
    D.   In the event any license(s) shall be allowed to lapse through non-
renewal, relinquishment or otherwise, such license(s) shall be automatically
void and the Liquor Commissioner or his/her designee shall decrease the number
of authorized licenses by the number of such revoked license(s). (Ord. 2017-
1522, 9-5-2017; amd. Ord. 2018-1553, 5-15-2018; Ord. 2019-1583, 2-19-2019; Ord.
2019-1599, 7-23-2019; Ord. 2021-1652, 6-22-2021; Ord. 2021-1658, 7-20-2021;
Ord. 2021-1668, 12-7-2021; Ord. 2022-1687, 9-20-2022; Ord. 2023-1692, 1- -2023;
Ord. 2023-1709, 10-17-2023; Ord. 2024-1730, 5-21-2024; Ord. 2025-1750, 1-7-
2025; Ord. 2025-1751, 1-7-2025)
4-1-12: TERM OF LICENSE; PRORATION OF INITIAL FEE:
Each license issued pursuant to this chapter shall terminate on the fourth
Tuesday of October next following its date of issuance. The fee to be paid for
new licenses shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which
have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the license. (Ord. 2004-1225,
2-3-2004)
4-1-13: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE; CHANGE OF LOCATION; RENEWALS:
   A.   Retail liquor licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter shall be personal to the licensee or entity to whom issued and for the
premises specified therein and shall not be transferable, but must be
surrendered by the licensee for cancellation upon the transfer of said
licensee's business location and/or removal of the licensee's business from the
premises specified in the license application. However, the premises specified
on the license and application required by this chapter may be changed only
upon the filing of a written request to make such change, and any change must
be approved by the village president. A license shall be issued by the village
president only if the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale
of alcoholic liquor under the laws of the state, provisions of this chapter,
and other ordinances of the village.
   B.   A license issued pursuant to this chapter shall permit the sale of
alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application and license,
and only under the conditions and restrictions imposed under this chapter on
the particular classification of license described therein. Such license shall
not be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be
alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being
encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by the laws of
testate or intestate devolution, but shall cease upon the death of the
licensee; provided, that the executors or administrators of the estate of any
deceased licensee and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when
such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of
the sale of alcoholic liquor under the order of the appropriate court, and may
exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after
the death of such decedent or such insolvency or bankruptcy, until the
expiration of the license, but not longer than six (6) months after the death,
bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee.
   C.   Any licensee shall have the right to renewal of such license; provided,
that said licensee is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for
which such renewal is sought is suitable for such purpose, but nothing herein
shall be deemed to restrict the right of the village president to suspend or
revoke any such license. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-14: POSTING LICENSE:
Every licensee shall immediately post and keep posted, while current, in a
conspicuous place on the premises the license so issued pursuant to the terms
of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-15: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor,
beer, ale or wine within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school,
hospital, home for the aged or indigent persons, nursing home or home for
veterans, their spouses or children, or any military installation or facility;
provided, that this prohibition does not apply to hotels offering restaurant
services or to restaurants where the sale of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or
wine is not the principal business carried on nor the renewal of a license for
the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine on the premises
within one hundred feet (100') of any above noted facilities where said
facilities are established after the issuance of the original license. For the
purposes herein described, the distance of one hundred feet (100') shall be
measured to the nearest part of any building used for any of the above noted
facilities and not to property boundaries. However, nothing herein shall
prohibit the village president from considering the proposed location's overall
proximity to the above noted facilities and the deleterious effects that the
sale of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine may have. Nothing in this section
shall prohibit the issuance of a license to a church or private school to sell
at retail alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine if any such sales are limited to
periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of
some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor,
beer, ale or wine. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-16: CLEAR VIEW OF PREMISES; LIGHTING:
Upon premises within which the sale of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine is
licensed, no screen, blind or curtain, partition, article, or thing shall be
permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor inside
such premises which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such
licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times, and no booth,
screen, partition or other obstruction nor any arrangements of lights or
lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises which
shall prevent a clear view of the entire interior from the street, road or
sidewalk. All rooms where alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine is sold for
consumption on the premises shall be continuously lighted during business hours
by natural light or artificial white light so that all parts of the interior of
the premises shall be clearly visible. In case the view into any such licensed
premises required by this section shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or
wilfully permitted to be obscured or in any manner obstructed, then such
license shall be subject to revocation in the manner herein provided. In order
to enforce the provision of this section, the president shall have the right to
require the filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the
clearance of the view as required in this section. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-17: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
All premises used for the retail sale or storage of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale
or wine licensed under this chapter shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition and shall be kept in full compliance with the provisions of this
chapter and/or other ordinances regulating the condition of premises. (Ord.
2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-18: CLOSING HOURS:
   A.   Hours Established; Exceptions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail any
alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine in the village between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., except as authorized by
subsection
 4-1-10B2b of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
      2.   The closing hours provided herein shall not apply on New Year's Eve
to license classifications A-1, A-2, B or D; provided, that the licensed
establishment does not permit any additional patrons on the licensed premises
after normal closing hours as enumerated in subsection A1 of this section; and
further provided, that the licensed establishment not advertise or indicate in
any manner that it is open for business after the normal closing hours.
Further, that should a disturbance occur on the licensed premises during the
extended closing hours hereinabove designated which, in the opinion of the
police chief or his delegate, appears to endanger the lives, property or person
of the patrons of a licensed premises, said police chief or his delegate may
order the licensed establishment to close its business until the next business
day and may order all patrons to leave the licensed premises immediately. (Ord.
2014-1416, 9-16-2014)
   B.   Presence On Premises: It shall be unlawful to keep open for business or
to admit the public to any premises in or on which alcoholic liquor, beer, ale
or wine is sold at retail during the hours within which the sale of such
liquor, beer, ale or wine is prohibited; except, that in the case of
restaurants, clubs, and hotels, such establishments may be kept open during
such hours, but no alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine may be sold to or
consumed by the public during such hours. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-19: SALES TO CERTAIN PERSONS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No licensee, employee or agent shall sell, give away or deliver
alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine to any person under the age of twenty one
(21) or to any intoxicated person, except as provided in 235 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-16.1. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Should the village president find, following a hearing before the
president, as the village liquor control commissioner, that any licensee or his
officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee has knowingly
sold, given or delivered any alcoholic liquor to an intoxicated person, and the
person, while so intoxicated, has caused death or great bodily harm to himself
or any other person, the president shall revoke or suspend the license for the
establishment for not less than thirty (30) days for the first such violation,
and shall revoke such license for any subsequent violations. (Ord. 2004-1225,
2-3-2004)
4-1-20: MINORS:
   A.   Purchase, Accept, Possess Or Consume; Identification Requirements:
      1.   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic
liquor is prohibited because of age shall not attempt to or actually purchase
or accept a gift or delivery of such alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic
liquor in his possession, or consume such alcoholic liquor, except in the
performance of a religious ceremony or service.
      2.   If a licensee or his agent or employee believes or has reason to
believe that a sale or delivery of an alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of
the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or
delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification,
containing proof of age, issued by a public official in the performance of his
official duties.
      3.   For the purpose of preventing the violation of this subsection A,
any licensee or his agent or employee may refuse to sell or serve alcoholic
beverages to any person who is unable to produce adequate positive
identification of identity and of the fact that said person is over the age of
twenty one (21) years.
      4.   Proof that the licensee or his employee or agent demanded, was shown
and reasonably relied upon such positive identification in any transaction
forbidden by this subsection A is competent evidence and may be considered in
any criminal or ordinance prosecution therefor or in any proceedings for the
suspension or revocation of any license based thereon.
      5.   No person shall transfer, alter or deface such identification card,
use or attempt to use the identification card of another, carry or use or
attempt to use a false or forged identification card, or obtain or attempt to
obtain an identification card by means of false information.
      6.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall misrepresent
his or her age for the purpose of purchasing, receiving or consuming alcoholic
liquor, beer, ale or wine.
      7.   Every licensee shall display in a prominent place on the premises so
licensed, a printed notice that shall read as follows:
   WARNING TO MINORS
YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE UNDER THE ORDINANCES OF THE VILLAGE OF PEORIA HEIGHTS
IF YOU PURCHASE ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR, BEER, ALE OR WINE OR MISREPRESENT YOUR AGE
FOR THE PURPOSE OF PURCHASING, OBTAINING OR CONSUMING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR, BEER,
ALE OR WINE.
   B.   Presence On Premises:
      1.   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic
liquor is prohibited because of age shall not enter or remain upon any premises
licensed for the sale of alcoholic liquor except in the company of his parent
or legal guardian or when performing as a compensated entertainer pursuant to a
signed contract for such performance; provided, however, that this subsection B
shall not apply to restaurants, except as set forth in subsection B4 of this
section, ice cream parlors, dinner theaters, clubs, package liquor stores, or
privately owned clubs holding a valid temporary license, other than those
portions used exclusively or primarily for the sale and consumption of
alcoholic liquors.
      2.   Persons to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor
is prohibited because of age may enter and remain upon premises licensed:
         a.   For events where no alcoholic liquor is sold or served;
         b.   For events where no admission fee is charged other than the cost
to rent the hall, e.g., wedding receptions, private parties, etc.; or
         c.   When in the company of his parent or legal guardian.
      3.   The licensee and any officer, associate, member, representative,
agent or employee of such licensee shall monitor at all times the presence of
any person on the licensed premises to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any
alcoholic liquor is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any
officer, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to permit
or allow any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any liquor is
prohibited to remain on the premises, except in the company of his parent or
legal guardian.
      4.   In a restaurant which has a liquor license, any person to whom the
sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age
shall not enter or remain upon the premises after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
unless in the company of his parent or legal guardian or as a compensated
entertainer pursuant to a signed contract for such performance or the
restaurant's employee who is actually performing his/her duties. The licensee
shall post a sign in a prominent location within the premises stating as
follows:
No person under 21 shall be permitted on these premises after 8:00 p.m. unless
in the company of his/her parent or legal guardian after 8:00 p.m.
      5.   No licensee, employee or agent shall permit any minor to loiter in
or about any licensed premises.
   C.   Persons On Premises Where There Is Consumption By Minors: No person
shall knowingly enter or remain in any house, building, yard or other premises,
other than premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, under circumstances
where the person knows or reasonably should know that alcoholic liquor is being
illegally possessed or consumed by persons under the age of twenty one (21)
years.
   D.   Purchasing To Sell Or Deliver To Minors: No person, after purchasing or
otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such
alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one (21) years,
except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.
   E.   Employment:
      1.   No licensee under this chapter shall employ or permit any person
under the age of twenty one (21) to handle, sell or serve alcoholic liquors for
sale; provided, however that any establishment holding a class A, class B,
class D, or class I license may employ persons nineteen (19) years of age or
older to serve alcoholic liquors to patrons in any fixed location used for
service of food where such person is under the direct and immediate supervision
of an employee twenty one (21) years of age or older who has supervisory
authority over the underage employee and who is actually present on the
premises at all times the underage employee is serving alcohol, but under no
circumstances shall such person be employed or act exclusively as a bartender
or cocktail server, nor shall such person sell alcoholic liquors.
      2.   No licensee under this chapter shall employ or permit any person
under the age of eighteen (18) to act as a compensated entertainer. (Ord. 2004-
1225, 2-3-2004; amd. 2016 Code; Ord. 2021-1658, 7-20-2021)
4-1-21: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDUCT:
   A.   Illegal Activities Generally: No licensee, agent and/or employee shall
engage in any activity or conduct or suffer or permit any other person to
engage in any activity or conduct in or about the licensed premises which is
prohibited by any ordinance of the village or law of the state of Illinois or
United States Of America.
   B.   Peddling Alcoholic Beverages: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm
or corporation to peddle alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine in the village.
   C.   Solicitation: No licensee, agent and/or employee of a licensed
establishment shall permit the solicitation of any patron thereof by anyone,
including the licensee, agent and/or employee, to purchase alcoholic liquor,
beer, ale or wine or nonalcoholic beverages or to give or donate money or any
other thing of value for any purpose including prostitution. However, nothing
contained herein shall prohibit any employee, regularly employed therein, from
accepting and serving an order of a patron in the normal course of employment.
   D.   Curb Service: No curb service for the sale of alcoholic liquor, beer,
ale or wine shall be permitted on or in connection with any premises licensed
under the terms of this chapter either upon a public street or public or
private property.
   E.   Removal Of Beverages From Premises: It shall be unlawful for any person
to carry any alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine in an unsealed or opened
container from the licensed premises where such alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or
wine was purchased. No licensee, agent and/or employee of the licensed
establishment shall permit any patron to violate this subsection nor continue
to sell or serve alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine to any such patron knowing
such patron intends to carry the alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or wine from the
premises in an unsealed or opened container. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-22: CRIMES REPORTED TO POLICE:
Each licensee, agent and/or employee shall immediately report to the village
police department any incident occurring on or about the licensed premises and
in their knowledge or view relating to the commission of any crime and shall
truthfully and fully respond to all questions and investigations of any
identified police officer who makes an inquiry concerning any persons in or
about the licensed premises and any events taking place in and about the
licensed premises. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004)
4-1-23: PUBLIC POSSESSION OR CONSUMPTION:
   A.   No person shall transport, carry, possess or have on any public place
or any public way in the village any alcoholic liquor on or about his person,
except in the original package and with the seal(s) unbroken.
   B.   No person shall consume any alcoholic liquor upon any public place or
public way within the village, except on premises licensed for the retail sale
of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises.
   C.   For purposes of this section, the term "public way" shall mean any and
all streets, alleys, sidewalks, boulevards and rights of way. The term "public
place" shall mean all publicly owned buildings, grounds, parks and privately
owned buildings and grounds which are actually or customarily opened to the
public. (Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004; amd. 2016 Code)
4-1-24: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The village president may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to the
terms of this chapter for any violation of any provision of this chapter or any
state or federal law pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor, beer, ale or
wine. In addition to the suspension, the village president may levy a fine on
the licensee for such violations as provided in subsection
1-4-1B of this code for each violation. Each day a violation continues to exist
shall constitute a separate offense. No such license shall be suspended or
revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a hearing held pursuant to
currently applicable law.
Any such hearing shall be conducted before a court reporter or certified
shorthand reporter. Review of the village president’s order on appeal shall be
limited to a review of the certified official record of the proceedings before
the village president.
(Ord. 2004-1225, 2-3-2004; amd. 2016 Code; Ord. 2023-1721, 12-19-2023)
4-1-25: PENALTY:
In addition to the penalty and enforcement provisions of section
 4-1-24 of this chapter, any licensee, manager of licensee, person, firm,
principal partners, principal stockholders of a corporation or partners or
limited partners who are licensees, or entity, manager or agent being found
guilty of a violation of any provision of this chapter, upon conviction and
finding and being adjudged guilty, shall be fined as provided in subsection
1-4-1B of this code. (Ord. 2009-1316, 11-17-2009; amd. 2016 Code)
4-1-26: BRING YOUR OWN BOTTLE REGULATIONS:
The regulations in this section apply to allow so-called BYOB (Bring Your Own
Bottle) at certain classes of businesses within the Village.
   A.   It shall be expressly permissible for tobacco businesses in the Village
to allow patrons to bring in their own alcoholic beverages, provided they have
a Village-issued BYOB permit for the same. For the purposes of this Section,
tobacco businesses shall mean cigar lounges.
   B.   The owner of a qualifying business may apply for a permit by providing
a sworn statement on a form provided by the Village Clerk and paying the annual
fee.
   C.   No tobacco business shall allow any person to consume alcohol on the
premises unless it holds a valid current BYOB permit.
   D.   No person under 21 may consume alcohol on the premises of any business.
   E.   No alcohol may be consumed in the premises at any time between 1:00
a.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following morning.
   F.   Public intoxication is not permitted by this section and business
owners and managers shall promptly eject persons who have become intoxicated,
and, if necessary call the police promptly for assistance.
   G.   No alcoholic beverages may be poured or consumed by any adult in a
booth or table where a minor is seated, unless the minor is accompanied by a
parent or legal guardian, and is properly supervised.
   H.   Illegal Activities Generally: No licensee, agent and/or employee shall
engage in any activity or conduct or suffer or permit any other person to
engage in any activity or conduct in or about the premises which is prohibited
by any ordinance of the Village or law of the State of Illinois or United
States of America.
   I.   Permits granted hereunder shall not be assignable or transferable to
any person, firm or corporation by the permittee, and if any such permit shall
be assigned or transferred, the same shall thereupon immediately become void.
   J.   Any permit issued shall only be effective and valid for one particular
location or place of business; and the address of such location or place of
business shall appear plainly on the face of any such permit, together with the
name of the permittee and the name, if any, of the business operated by the
permittee; otherwise, such license shall be void
   K.   The owner and employees of the business shall not be permitted to sell,
serve, or pour any alcoholic beverage.
   L.   The BYOB permit is not considered a pouring license, and a business
which qualifies for a BYOB permit is not considered a liquor licensee or
otherwise qualified as a licensed establishment or licensed terminal operator
as those terms are defined within the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/
1 et seq.
   M.   The annual fee of $100 applies to all businesses holding BYOB permits.
Each permit issued pursuant to this section shall terminate on the fourth
Tuesday of October next following its date of issuance. The fee to be paid for
new permits shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which
have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the permit This fee is in
addition to all other license fees applicable to the businesses.
   N.   Any proven violation of the provisions of this section shall be
considered grounds to revoke this grant of permission by the Village President
upon not less than three days’ written notice. In the event of such revocation
the affected business may appeal to the Village Board whose majority decision
shall stand as the final administrative act of the Village.
   P.   A violation of the provisions of this section shall also subject the
offender to penalties as provided in subsection
1-4-1B of this Code. (Ord. 2022-1686, 9-20-2022)
CHAPTER 2
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
4-2-1: Licensed Video Gaming Exemption
4-2-2: Definitions
4-2-3: Video Gaming Establishment License
4-2-4: Video Gaming Terminal Permit Sticker
4-2-5: Regulations Governing Licensed Establishments Operating Video Gaming
Terminals
4-2-6: Inspection Of Premises
4-2-7: Revocation/Suspension Of License And Permit Sticker
4-2-8: Seizure Of Unlawful Video Gaming Terminals
4-2-9: Monetary Penalty
4-2-1: LICENSED VIDEO GAMING EXEMPTION:
   A.   The prohibitions set forth in ordinance 299, an ordinance regulating
"automatic amusement machines" and "mechanical musical devices" shall not apply
to video gaming terminals operated by a licensed establishment under authority
of this chapter; and
   B.   Any activity that is lawfully conducted in accordance with the video
gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., is permitted and shall
not constitute unlawful gambling within the village of Peoria Heights; and
   C.   Any other ordinances of the village of Peoria Heights which prohibit
gambling or gaming shall not apply to any video gaming terminal that has a
valid video gaming terminal sticker and is being operated pursuant to this
chapter by a "licensed establishment" as hereinafter defined. (Ord. 2016-1471,
4-19-2016)
4-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply within this chapter:
   LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT: Any establishment that is both licensed to sell
liquor at retail in the village pursuant to village ordinance 2004-1225, as
from time to time amended and also licensed by the Illinois gaming board to
operate a video gaming terminal on its premises.
   VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon
insertion of cash, electronic cards, or vouchers or any combination thereof is
available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including, but not
limited to, video poker, line up, and blackjack, utilizing a video display and
microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or credits that can
be redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that directly
dispenses coins, cash, or tokens or is for amusement purposes only. (Ord. 2016-
1471, 4-19-2016)
4-2-3: VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE:
In order for an establishment to operate a video gaming terminal, the
establishment shall first obtain an annual video gaming establishment license
from the village by submitting a written application, on a form provided by the
village, to the mayor or the mayor’s designee. An applicant has the burden of
demonstrating its suitability for licensure. All video gaming establishment
licenses issued by the village shall expire April 30, next, after the date of
issue. An annual license fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is payable in
full at the time the application is filed with the village or upon renewal as
the case may be. A licensed establishment in good standing shall be entitled to
renew its license upon timely payment of its annual fee without submission of
an application. Any change in ownership or other characteristic of a licensed
establishment shall require the submission of a new application. A license
shall be purely a personal privilege, good for a time period not to exceed one
year after issuance, unless sooner revoked as provided by law, and shall not
constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment, or
execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or
involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered. Not more than seventeen (17)
licensed video gaming establishments may operate at any one time within the
village. No additional license shall be issued by the village for the operation
of video gaming terminals whenever seventeen (17) such licenses have been
issued and are outstanding. (Ord. 2016-1471, 4-19-2016; amd. Ord. 2023-1705, 5-
16-2023; Ord. 2023-1706, 7-13-2023; Ord. 2024-1738, 10-15- 2024)
4-2-4: VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL PERMIT STICKER:
In order for a video gaming terminal to be operated at a licensed
establishment, the licensed establishment shall first obtain an annual video
gaming terminal permit sticker from the village for each video gaming terminal
located on its premises by submitting a written application, on a form provided
by the village, to the mayor or the mayor's designee. Each video gaming
terminal permit sticker issued by the village shall expire April 30, next,
after date of issue. An annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per video
gaming terminal payable in full at the time the application is filed with the
village, or upon renewal as the case may be. A licensed establishment in good
standing shall be entitled to renew gaming terminal permits upon timely payment
of the annual fee without submission of an application. (Ord. 2016-1471, 4-19-
2016)
4-2-5: REGULATIONS GOVERNING LICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS OPERATING VIDEO GAMING
TERMINALS:
The following regulations apply to all licensed establishments operating video
gaming terminals:
   A.   A valid village video gaming establishment license must be clearly
displayed on the premises at all times.
   B.   A valid village video gaming terminal permit sticker shall be clearly
displayed at all times on each video gaming terminal.
   C.   No more than six (6) video gaming terminals may be located on the
premises of a licensed establishment.
   D.   Other than having up to six (6) video gaming terminals with valid video
gaming terminal permit stickers, a licensed establishment is prohibited from
having, anywhere on its premises, an electronic video gaming machine that may
be available to play or simulate the play of poker, line up, blackjack, faro,
roulette, craps, slots, or any other card or dice game or other game of chance,
or that is otherwise akin to a gambling or gaming device, even if solely for
amusement purposes.
   E.   All video gaming terminals must be located in an area restricted to
persons twenty one (21) years of age or older. The entrance to such area must,
at all times, be within the view of at least one employee who is at least
twenty one (21) years of age.
   F.   No licensed establishment may cause or permit any person under the age
of twenty one (21) years to use, play or operate a video gaming terminal.
   G.   No video gaming terminal may be played except during the legal hours of
operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the licensed
establishment pursuant to village ordinance 2004-1225, as from time to time
amended.
   H.   The licensed establishment must fully comply with the Illinois video
gaming act 1  and all rules, regulations and restrictions imposed by the
Illinois gaming board. (Ord. 2016-1471, 4-19-2016; amd. Ord. 2020-1620, 2-18-
2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
4-2-6: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Every licensed establishment where any video gaming terminal is kept shall be
subject to inspection by the chief of police or the chief's authorized agents,
at any time, to ensure compliance with village ordinances. This includes
licensed establishments applying for a video gaming establishment license and/
or video gaming terminal permit sticker. It shall be unlawful for any person to
hinder, resist, oppose or attempt to hinder, resist or oppose the chief of
police or the chief's authorized agents in the course of an inspection. (Ord.
2016-1471, 4-19-2016)
4-2-7: REVOCATION/SUSPENSION OF LICENSE AND PERMIT STICKER:
The village liquor commissioner may revoke or suspend any video gaming
establishment license and any video gaming terminal permit sticker issued by
the village if it determines that the licensed establishment has violated any
of the provisions of this chapter or any applicable provisions of state or
federal law. No license shall be so revoked or suspended, except after a public
hearing before the village liquor commissioner, with not less than three (3)
days' prior written notice to the licensed establishment affording the licensed
establishment an opportunity to appear and defend. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, any licensed establishment that has its liquor license revoked or
suspended by the village under village ordinance 2004-1225, as from time to
time amended or by the Illinois state liquor commission, or has its video
gaming license revoked or suspended by the Illinois gaming board, shall
automatically, without a hearing before the village liquor commissioner, have
its village video gaming establishment license and all village video gaming
terminal permit stickers revoked or suspended for the same time frame as its
liquor and/or Illinois gaming board gaming license is suspended whichever the
case may. (Ord. 2016-1471, 4-19-2016)
4-2-8: SEIZURE OF UNLAWFUL VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
Every video gaming terminal that does not have a valid video gaming terminal
permit sticker or is otherwise unlawful shall be considered a gambling device
subject to seizure by the police chief or his designee, and shall be turned
over to the Illinois gaming board, in accordance with board regulations and
applicable law, unless otherwise ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2016-1471, 4-19-2016)
4-2-9: MONETARY PENALTY:
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense and a fine of not less than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a second offense and each subsequent
offense. Each day a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate
offense and a fine may be levied for not less than the minimum fine for each
day the offense continues. This penalty may be enforced by issuance of a
citation for the fine amount, or by issuance of a notice to appear. This
monetary penalty shall be in addition to any and all other remedies which may
be available to the village of Peoria Heights under village ordinance 2004-
1225, as from time to time amended or any other ordinance of the village of
Peoria Heights or federal or state law. (Ord. 2016-1471, 4-19-2016)
CHAPTER 3
FOOD DEALERS
ARTICLE A. FOOD AND ALCOHOL TAX; RESTAURANTS AND TAVERNS
SECTION:
4-3A-1: Definitions
4-3A-2: Food And Alcohol Tax
4-3A-3: Restaurant License Provisions
4-3A-4: Registration Of Restaurants And Taverns
4-3A-5: False Information On Applications Prohibited
4-3A-6: Rules And Regulations
4-3A-7: Penalty
4-3A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Is defined in the same manner as in section
4-1-1 of this title.
   FOOD ITEMS: Means and includes any and all materials, whether solid,
semisolid or liquid, used or intended to be used for human consumption and for
nourishment of the human body. The term includes any and all nonalcoholic
liquor beverages.
   OWNER: Any person or persons having a sufficient proprietary interest in
conducting the operation of a restaurant or tavern so as to entitle such a
person or persons to all or a portion of the net receipts thereof.
   PERSON: Any natural person, trustee, court appointed representative,
syndicate, association, partnership, firm, club, company, corporation, business
trust, institution, agency, government corporation, municipal corporation,
district or other political subdivision, contractor, supplier, vendor, vendee,
operator, user or owner; or any officer, agent, employee or other
representative, acting either for himself or for any other person in any
capacity; or any other entity recognized by law as the subject of rights and
duties.
   RESTAURANT: Means and includes any place located within the corporate limits
of the village kept, used and maintained as a place at which food items are
served and/or prepared, and where food items are regularly served and/or
prepared, whether or not consumed on the premises; but shall not include coin
operated automatic food item dispensing machines. For the purposes of this
article, luncheon or dinner clubs, employee cafeterias, any location with
respect to any catered event and the like where food items are prepared or
served are deemed to be restaurants.
   TAVERN: Means and includes an establishment licensed by the village to serve
alcoholic liquor.
   TREASURER: The duly appointed and acting treasurer of the village and
includes the village administrator and bookkeeper hereby authorized as
delegates to assist in the performance of the duties assigned to the treasurer
under this article.
   VILLAGE: The village of Peoria Heights, a municipal corporation located in
Peoria County, Illinois. (Ord. 2016-1487, 10-18-2016)
4-3A-2: FOOD AND ALCOHOL TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate: There is hereby levied and imposed upon the
privilege of purchasing food items or alcoholic beverages served or prepared at
either a restaurant, tavern or licensed food vendor in the village a tax of two
percent (2%) of the purchase price, exclusive of any other tax, charged for
such food items and/or alcoholic beverages; provided, however, that such tax
shall not apply or be imposed upon persons purchasing food items or alcoholic
beverages served or prepared at restaurants owned by any grade, junior high or
high school within the village. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Exemptions From Tax: No such tax shall be levied and imposed upon the
purchase of an alcoholic beverage or food item which is both purchased and
taken from the premises of purchase in the hermetically sealed container of its
manufacturer or wholesaler.
   C.   Tax Is Additional: The tax levied in this section shall be paid in
addition to any and all other taxes and charges.
   D.   Liability For Payment Of Tax: The ultimate incidence of and liability
for payment of such tax shall be borne by the person who purchases food items
or alcoholic beverages so served or prepared at any such restaurant or tavern,
such person hereinafter referred to as "consumer".
   E.   Collection Of Tax:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the owner, manager or operator of every
restaurant or tavern to act as trustee for and on account of the village, and
to secure such tax for the consumer of a restaurant or tavern and pay to the
village treasurer such tax under procedures prescribed by the treasurer or as
otherwise provided in this section.
      2.   Every person required to collect the tax levied by this section
shall secure such tax from the consumer at the time he collects payment for the
service of food or alcoholic beverage. Upon the invoice, receipt or other
statement or memorandum given to the consumer at the time of payment, the
amount due under the tax provided in this section shall be stated separately on
such documents.
   F.   Remittance Of Tax; Delinquencies:
      1.   Tax Return And Remittance Required; Due Date:
         a.   The owner of each restaurant or tavern within the village shall
file tax returns showing tax receipts received during each month by period on
forms prescribed by the treasurer. The returns shall be due on or before the
thirtieth day of the calendar month succeeding the end of the monthly filing
period. Such owner shall file an application for registration in the manner
hereinafter set forth prior to filing the first tax return.
         b.   The first taxing period, for the purpose of this section, shall
commence on July 1, 2014, and the tax return and payment for such period shall
be due on or before August 30, 2014. Thereafter, reporting periods and tax
payments shall be in accordance with the provisions of this section. At the
time of filing such tax returns, the owner shall pay to the treasurer all taxes
due for the period to which the tax return applies.
      2.   Failure To File Return:
         a.   Individuals:
            (1)   In case any person who is required under this section to file
a tax return to the village fails to file a return when and as required under
this section, such person shall pay to the village, in addition to the amount
of tax required to be transmitted, a penalty of five percent (5%) of the tax
that such person is required to transmit to the village; provided, however, a
twenty percent (20%) penalty shall be imposed for any fraudulent failure to
transmit such tax.
            (2)   In case any person who is required under this section to file
a tax return with the village files a return at the time required or fails to
transmit the tax proceeds, or any portion thereof, to the village when due, a
penalty of five percent (5%) of the amount of tax not transmitted to the
village shall be added thereto; provided, however, the fraudulent failure to
pay such tax shall result in a twenty percent (20%) penalty.
            (3)   In addition to any penalty for which provision is made in
this section, any amount of tax not transmitted when due shall bear interest at
the rate of two percent (2%) per month, or fraction thereof, until fully
transmitted.
         b.   Corporations: Any officer or employee of any corporation which is
an owner subject to the provisions of this section, who has control,
supervision or responsibility of collecting tax proceeds, filing returns and
transmitting collected tax proceeds of the tax imposed by this section and who
wilfully fails to file such return or to transmit any tax proceeds so collected
to the village shall be personally liable for any such amounts collected,
including interest and penalties thereon. The personal liability of such
officer or employee, as provided in this section, shall survive dissolution of
the corporation. For purposes of this subsection F2b, a person wilfully fails
to act if he takes any conscious and voluntary action intending not to perform
any of his obligations hereunder, including, but not limited to, the utilizing
of tax proceeds collected for the village to pay any other corporate
obligations.
      3.   Copies Of Sales And Use Tax Returns Required: The person filing such
return shall attach thereto a copy of the Illinois sales and use tax returns of
the submitting tavern or restaurant for the month for which a return is made
under this section.
   G.   Enforcement Of Payment: Whenever any person shall fail to pay any tax
as provided in this section, the village attorney shall, upon the request of
the village administrator, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce
the payment of such tax on behalf of the village in any court of competent
jurisdiction. Attorney fees incurred by the village for the purpose of
enforcing the collection or payment of such tax shall be assessed against the
defendants in any such action.
   H.   Books And Records:
      1.   The treasurer or any person certified as his delegate may enter the
premises of the restaurant and tavern for inspection and examination of books
and records in order to effectuate the proper administration of this section
and to assure the enforcement of the collection of the tax imposed.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder or interfere
with the treasurer or his duly authorized delegate in the discharge of his
duties or to fail to comply with the terms and conditions of this section. It
shall be the duty of every owner to keep accurate and complete books and
records to which the treasurer or his delegate shall at all times have full
access, which records shall include a daily sheet showing:
         a.   The amount of taxable receipts within the twenty four (24) hour
period; and
         b.   The actual restaurant/tavern tax receipts collected for the date
in question.
   I.   Disposition Of Revenues: All proceeds resulting from the imposition of
the tax under this section, including interest, penalties or other assessments,
shall be paid into the treasury of the village and shall be credited to and
deposited in the corporate fund of the village. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014)
4-3A-3: RESTAURANT LICENSE PROVISIONS:
   A.   License And Compliance Required; Interpretation: It shall be unlawful
for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established,
operated or maintained, upon any property owned or controlled thereby a
restaurant within the village without having first obtained a license therefor
from the village treasurer or without complying with all provisions of this
article. For purposes of this article, a restaurant or its operator which has
been issued a liquor license by the village shall be deemed to be licensed to
operate the restaurant and need not file a separate restaurant license
application. A restaurant that does not sell liquor is required to have a valid
restaurant license. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   No Fee: There shall be no fee for such license for a restaurant as
required in subsection A of this section.
   C.   Term Of License: The license shall be valid until the next expiration
date. All restaurant licenses shall expire on May 1 of each calendar year, but
shall be deemed reissued upon expiration without further application to all
restaurants in good standing under the terms of this article.
   D.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Appeals:
      1.   If the village president, after a hearing held by or for him, shall
find that any person has wilfully avoided payment of the tax imposed by this
article, he may suspend or revoke all licenses issued by the village and held
by such tax evader.
      2.   The owner, manager or operator of the restaurant or tavern shall
have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing to be held not less than five
(5) days after notice of the time and place of the hearing to be held,
addressed by him at his last known place of business. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-
2014)
4-3A-4: REGISTRATION OF RESTAURANTS AND TAVERNS:
   A.   Registration Required: The owner of every restaurant or tavern shall
register with the village for the purpose of providing information deemed
necessary to facilitate collection of the tax imposed by this article.
   B.   Application For Registration:
      1.   All persons registering as required by this section shall submit to
the treasurer an application in writing stating:
         a.   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual;
         b.   In the case of a corporation or club, the date of incorporation
and the names, ages and addresses of its officers and directors;
         c.   In the case of a for profit corporation, the names, addresses and
ages of any stockholders owning or controlling the voting rights to more than
five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation;
         d.   In the case of a partnership, the names, addresses and ages of
all partners or managers of the partnership;
         e.   The location of all taverns or restaurants operated by the
applicant within the village;
         f.   The Illinois business tax number of the establishment and the
federal employer identification number of the establishment.
      2.   If such application is made in behalf of a partnership, association,
club or corporation, then the same shall be signed by an authorized member of
such partnership or the president of such corporation, association or club.
      3.   The application for registration required by this subsection B shall
also serve as an application for a license to operate a restaurant if required
by section
4-3A-3 of this article. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014)
4-3A-5: FALSE INFORMATION ON APPLICATIONS PROHIBITED:
No person shall knowingly furnish false or misleading information or withhold
any relevant information on any application for any registration or license
required by this article nor knowingly cause or suffer another to furnish or
withhold such information on his behalf. No person shall knowingly furnish any
false or misleading information to the village president, the chief of police,
the village administrator, the treasurer or any person authorized to act in
their behalf in the investigation of any application required by this chapter;
nor shall any person wilfully withhold any information that is relevant to any
such investigation when called upon the chief of police, the village
administrator, the treasurer or a person acting in their behalf to furnish such
information. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014)
4-3A-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The treasurer may promulgate rules and regulations not inconsistent with the
provisions of this article concerning the enforcement and application of this
article. The term "rules and regulations" includes, but is not limited to, a
case by case determination whether or not the tax imposed by this article
applies. (Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014)
4-3A-7: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting, or
refusing to comply with, or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any of the
provisions of this article, except when otherwise specifically provided, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a fine of not less than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first
offense and not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense in any one
hundred eighty (180) day period. A separate and distinct offense shall be
regarded as committed each day upon which such person shall continue any such
violation or permit any such violation to exist after notification thereof. The
purpose of imposing penalties for the violation of this article is to ensure
the integrity of the collection process established pursuant to this article.
(Ord. 2014-1406, 5-6-2014)
ARTICLE B. SALE OF FOOD AND BEVERAGES FROM PUBLIC PROPERTY
SECTION:
4-3B-1: Purpose
4-3B-2: Definitions
4-3B-3: License Required
4-3B-4: Application For License; Competing Applications
4-3B-5: License Fee
4-3B-6: Background Check
4-3B-7: Issuance Of License
4-3B-8: Term And Nontransferability Of License
4-3B-9: Location Limitations
4-3B-10: Regulations
4-3B-11: Property Interest In Sites Prohibited; Village Authority Regarding
Vendors
4-3B-12: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
4-3B-13: Exemptions
4-3B-14: Penalty
4-3B-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is to regulate the placement and operation of food
vendors from within and adjacent to Tower Park and from certain public rights
of way. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to this article unless the use or context
clearly indicates that another meaning is intended:
   PUBLIC PROPERTY: Collectively "Tower Park" and "rights of way", as said
terms are defined herein.
   RIGHTS OF WAY: Sidewalks and street rights of way within areas of the
village zoned to allow retail sales as a permitted use.
   SITE: The total area occupied by a "vendor", as defined herein, including a
"stand", as defined herein, and auxiliary tables, the place where employees
stand and the place where goods and equipment are stored or displayed.
   STAND: Any table, showcase, bench, rack, pushcart, wagon or any other
vehicle or device used by a vendor for the display or dispensing of food or
beverages from a "site", as defined herein.
   TOWER PARK: The public park owned by the village of Peoria Heights located
in the southwest quadrant of the intersection of Prospect Road and Kingman
Avenue, together with any adjoining public rights of way and adjacent public
parking areas.
   VENDOR: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the selling or offering
for sale of food and nonalcoholic beverages on public property from a stand or
from his person by locating the same in a fixed location for a period of time
rather than by going from place to place within the village. (Ord. 2015-1451,
7-21-2015)
4-3B-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Except as otherwise provided in this article, no vendor shall operate from
public property without having first received a license from the village
administrator. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; COMPETING APPLICATIONS:
   A.   An application for a license required by this article shall be
submitted in writing to the village administrator on a form prescribed by the
village administrator setting forth the following information:
      1.   The name of the individual or entity applying for the license. A
corporate applicant shall provide the names of its officers and directors;
      2.   The residence address, business address, telephone number and
driver's license number of the applicant or, in the case of a corporation, such
information regarding its officers and directors;
      3.   The type of food and beverages to be sold or offered for sale;
      4.   The site where the applicant proposes to sell food and beverages;
      5.   Whether the applicant has, within the last five (5) years, been
convicted of a criminal offense or ordinance violation (other than traffic or
parking offenses) in any jurisdiction and, if so, a list of such convictions
with the date and prosecuting jurisdiction;
      6.   The State of Illinois Sales Tax number demonstrating that the
applicant is registered for the collection and payment of Sales Tax to the
Illinois Department of Revenue; and
      7.   Evidence of compliance with article A of this chapter imposing a tax
on the privilege of purchasing food items or beverages.
   B.   Competing approvable applications for the same site shall be reviewed
and considered on a first come, first served basis. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-5: LICENSE FEE:
The applicant shall pay to the Village Treasurer, with the application, a
filing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Should the Village Administrator
decline to issue a license in response to an application, the fee shall be
refunded to the applicant. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-6: BACKGROUND CHECK:
Upon receipt of a completed application, the Village Administrator shall cause
a copy thereof to be sent to the Chief of Police who shall conduct a conviction
information/criminal history background check through the Illinois State
Police. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-7: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon receipt of the completed background check from the Chief of Police, the
Village Administrator shall, within a reasonable time, issue a license to the
applicant unless he shall find:
   A.   That the applicant is under sixteen (16) years of age;
   B.   That the applicant was convicted within the last five (5) years of any
offense relating to theft, burglary or fraud;
   C.   That the site requested by the applicant is not proper for a vendor
under the terms of this article;
   D.   That the applicant has made a misrepresentation in its application; or
   E.   That the applicant cannot meet or has not met the requirements of this
article. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-8: TERM AND NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued during a calendar year shall expire on December 31 of such
calendar year regardless of the date issued. Licenses are not transferable.
(Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-9: LOCATION LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Not more than five (5) licenses shall be approved for a site within
Tower Park.
   B.   No site may be approved for a location within one hundred feet (100')
of the front entrance of any business licensed to sell food or beverages under
authority of article A of this chapter.
   C.   No license shall be issued for any site which, in the sole and
exclusive discretion of the Village Administrator, would unreasonably interfere
with the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic or unreasonably interfere with
the operation of any existing business located within one hundred feet (100')
of the site. (Ord. 2018-1541, 2-6-2018)
4-3B-10: REGULATIONS:
All vendors issued a license under authority of this article shall operate in
accordance with the following regulations:
   A.   Vendors shall not sell or offer for sale food and beverages other than
at the site approved by the Village Administrator.
   B.   1. Vendors may engage in business from a site only from Monday through
Friday of each week between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and two
thirty o'clock (2:30) P.M.
      2.   Vendors shall not place stands on a site or elsewhere on public
property before ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. from Monday through Friday and shall
promptly remove all stands and related material, merchandise and trash or
refuse from public property at the conclusion of business each day, but in no
event later than two thirty o'clock (2:30) P.M.
   C.   Vendors shall not at any time leave a stand unattended.
   D.   Vendors shall at all times maintain the site in a clean and sanitary
condition. All trash or refuse resulting from sales or activities of the vendor
shall be immediately picked up by the vendor and deposited in receptacles
maintained by the vendor. Vendors shall not dispose of trash or refuse in
public receptacles.
   E.   Vendors shall at all times operate in accordance with applicable local,
state or federal regulations including those governing food safety.
   F.   Vendors shall not sell or deliver alcoholic beverages from a site.
   G.   Vendors shall not deface, mar, mark, damage or destroy public property.
   H.   Vendors shall promptly remove all stains from cooking, wheels, spillage
or other causes.
   I.   Vendors shall place a protective pad under their stands to protect the
surface of public property.
   J.   Vendors shall timely pay all sales taxes due the Illinois department of
revenue and all food and beverage taxes due the village. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-
2015)
4-3B-11: PROPERTY INTEREST IN SITES PROHIBITED; VILLAGE AUTHORITY REGARDING
VENDORS:
   A.   Vendors shall have no property rights in any site.
   B.   The village may any time, in its discretion, determine that it is no
longer appropriate for a vendor to operate from any particular site or
determine that vendors will no longer be allowed to operate from public
property. Based on any such determination, the village may any time, at its
option, revoke any license which has been issued under this article or decline
to issue a license for a subsequent calendar year. In the event that the
village exercises its option to revoke a license during a calendar year, the
fee paid by the licensee with respect to that calendar year shall be refunded
to the licensee. In any event, however, a licensee operating from a particular
site during a calendar year shall have first priority to reserve a license for
that same site during the following calendar year; provided, that the licensee
submits an approvable application between November 1 and December 1 of the year
for which the current license for that site is effective. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-
21-2015)
4-3B-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If the village president, after a hearing held by him or his designee, shall
find that any licensee has violated the provisions of this article, he may
suspend the license of the offender for a period of not more than thirty (30)
days or permanently revoke the license issued under the provisions of this
article. A licensee shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing to be
held not less than five (5) days after notice of the time and place of the
hearing has been mailed or personally delivered to the last known address of
