the licensee. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-13: EXEMPTIONS:
Vendors registered with the sponsor of a public charitable or community event
approved by the village board of trustees shall be exempt from the application,
licensing and fee provisions of this article. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015)
4-3B-14: PENALTY:
Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be fined as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each day that a violation continues. (Ord. 2015-1451, 7-21-2015;
amd. 2016 Code)
CHAPTER 4
JUNK COLLECTORS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: Registration Requirements
4-4-3: Hours For Junk Collection
4-4-4: Violation; Penalty
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
   JUNK: Includes, but is not limited to, garbage, rubbish, refuse, which
includes any item, piece or part reduced in value or parts in order to
facilitate its discard and removal and disposal; which includes, but is not
limited to, combustible and noncombustible waste, cardboard, paper, plastics,
tin cans, glass, wood, bedding, crockery, iron, brass, automobile parts,
machinery parts, rubber tires, appliance parts and any other type of similar
material.
   JUNK COLLECTION: The removal of junk from any public place, street or alley
or at the curbside or on the property of any individual who has placed said
items on their private property for garbage collection in the village of Peoria
Heights.
   JUNK COLLECTOR: Any person engaged in junk collecting.
   PERSON: Any person or individual, or any employee of any entity,
corporation, partnership, LLC, or individual doing business under another name.
   PUBLIC PLACE: All streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public
ways and all public square spaces, grounds and buildings in the village of
Peoria Heights. (Ord. 2011-1356, 12-6-2011)
4-4-2: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS:
All junk collectors shall be required to register with the village police
department in order to collect junk within the village. The following
information shall be furnished: proof of identification of the junk collector,
name and address, a current driver's license and driver's license number, and
current valid vehicle registration certificate, all of which must be presented
to the village police department at the time of registration in order to be
registered as a junk collector. All junk collectors must reregister every six
(6) months from the date of issuance of their initial registration. There is no
cost for junk registration. (Ord. 2011-1356, 12-6-2011; amd. 2016 Code)
4-4-3: HOURS FOR JUNK COLLECTION:
Hours of junk collection shall be only as follows:
   A.   From May 1 to October 31: Between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. every day; and
   B.   From November 1 to April 30: Between the hours of six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. every day. (Ord. 2012-1363, 2-21-2012)
4-4-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
It is unlawful for any person to engage in junk collection in violation of this
chapter. Any person engaged in junk collection without first having registered
as required in this chapter shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation. (Ord. 2011-1356, 12-6-2011; amd. 2016
Code)
CHAPTER 5
TOBACCO DEALERS
SECTION:
4-5-1: License Required
4-5-2: Application For License
4-5-3: License Fee
4-5-4: Nontransferability Of License
4-5-5: License Applicable For One Location Only; Contents Of License
4-5-6: Display Of License
4-5-7: Violation; Penalty
4-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall hereafter keep for sale or give away or shall sell or give away
or offer to sell or give away any cigarettes, cigarette papers or wrappers and
tobacco products of any kind at any place within the village without first
having procured the license as herein provided. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-2000)
4-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for such license shall be made in writing to the village clerk,
signed by the applicant if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent if a
club or corporation. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-2000)
4-5-3: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Fee Established:
      1.   The fee for a license to sell cigarettes, cigarette papers or
wrappers and tobacco products in the village shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00) per annum for each location or place of business where such selling is
carried on.
      2.   Any person, firm or corporation who has not sold cigarettes,
cigarette papers or wrappers and tobacco products within the village prior to
making an application for a license between May 1 and November 1 shall be
required to pay the full annual license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 1172, 6-6-2000; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Payment And Disposition Of Fee; Refunds:
      1.   All of the license fee shall be paid to the village clerk at the
time application is made, and shall be forthwith turned over to the village
treasurer. In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be
returned to the applicant; if the license is granted, then the fee shall be
deposited in the general fund or in such other fund as has been designated by
the board of trustees by proper action.
      2.   No rebate or refund shall be given to any licensee who ceases to
engage in the sale of cigarettes, cigarette papers or wrappers and tobacco
products prior to the expiration of the year for which his/her license is
issued on account of the unexpired term of such license. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-2000)
4-5-4: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
No license to sell cigarettes, cigarette papers or wrappers and tobacco
products of any kind shall be assignable or transferable to any person, firm or
corporation by the licensee, and if any such license shall be assigned or
transferred, the same shall thereupon immediately become void. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-
2000; amd. 2016 Code)
4-5-5: LICENSE APPLICABLE FOR ONE LOCATION ONLY; CONTENTS OF LICENSE:
Any license issued shall only be effective and valid for one particular
location or place of business; and the address of such location or place of
business shall appear plainly on the face of any such license, together with
the name of the licensee and the name, if any, of the business operated by the
licensee; otherwise, such license shall be void. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-2000)
4-5-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his license to be framed and kept in plain view in a
conspicuous place on the licensed premises. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-2000)
4-5-7: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and
shall be punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day during which or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1172, 6-6-
2000; amd. 2016 Code)
CHAPTER 6
SECONDHAND DEALERS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Definition
4-6-2: License Required
4-6-3: Application For License
4-6-4: Bond Required
4-6-5: License Fee
4-6-6: Investigation Of Applicant
4-6-7: Conditions On Issuance Of License
4-6-8: Nontransferability Of License Or Stock
4-6-9: Posting License
4-6-10: Location Regulations
4-6-11: Closing Hours
4-6-12: Prohibited Purchases
4-6-13: Weapons Purchases Or Sales Prohibited
4-6-14: Records And Reports
4-6-15: Waiting Periods After Sales
4-6-16: Inspections; Property Seizures
4-6-17: Revocation Or Suspension Of License; Hearing
4-6-18: Exemptions
4-6-19: Penalties
4-6-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, a "secondhand dealer" is any person who operates a
business for profit and who buys, sells, possesses on consignment for sale or
trades jewelry, stamps, coins/currency, precious metals or stones which may
have been previously owned by a consumer; or who derives more than thirty five
percent (35%) of his gross receipts from the sale, consignment for sale, pledge
or trade of any goods, wares or merchandise which have previously been owned by
a consumer including, but not limited to, furniture, appliances, automobile
parts and accessories, metals, whether in bulk or manufactured state,
computers, computer parts or equipment, video/camera/stereo parts or equipment,
electronic video consoles and games, videos, music, musical instruments,
collectibles and memorabilia, sporting goods, bicycles, motorized tools/
vehicles, tools, collectible artwork, and firearms including their accessories
and ammunition. The term "secondhand dealer" shall include businesses commonly
known as pawnbrokers, swap shop operators, stamp dealers, coin dealers and
jewelers who purchase and resell items from persons other than dealers and
suppliers. The fact that any business does any of the following acts shall be
prima facie proof that such business is a secondhand dealership:
   A.   Advertises in any fashion that it buys or sells secondhand or used
items. Such advertisements shall include, but not be limited to, media
advertisements, telephone listings, and signs, whether on the exterior or
interior of the business.
   B.   Devotes a significant segment or section of the business premises to
the purchase or sale of secondhand or used items. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, either as owner, manager, lessee, officer or agent, or in any other
capacity, shall operate or permit to be operated a secondhand dealership
without first having obtained a license from the village to do so. (Ord. 2014-
1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a license required by this chapter shall be made in writing
to the village president and shall set forth the following:
   A.   The name of the individual, partnership, corporation or association
applying for a license.
   B.   The residence, phone number, date of birth and driver's license number
of the applicant or partners; or if a corporation or association, the
residence, phone number and driver's license number of the officers and all
shareholders owning more than five percent (5%) of the outstanding shares of
stock.
   C.   The location for which the license is requested.
   D.   Whether the applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders,
have been convicted of any criminal offense or ordinance violation (other than
traffic or parking offenses) in any jurisdiction and, if so, a list of such
convictions with date and prosecuting jurisdiction.
   E.   Whether the applicant, his partners, officers or listed shareholders,
have held a license or had an interest in a license issued by the village or
any other jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of secondhand property
revoked for cause and, if so, list the date of revocation and jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-4: BOND REQUIRED:
Every applicant for a license under this chapter shall file with the village a
license bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), approved by
the village administrator, with the village as obligee, conditioned upon the
faithful and due performance of the provisions of this chapter and the laws of
the state concerning the operation of the licensed business and the payment of
all fines and penalties by reason of the violation thereof. (Ord. 2014-1418,
11-4-2014; amd. 2016 Code)
4-6-5: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   The applicant for a license required by this chapter shall pay the
village treasurer, prior to filing an application, a nonrefundable license fee.
The fee for secondhand dealers established after the effective date hereof
shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   B.   All secondhand dealer businesses established prior to the effective
date hereof shall be exempt from any and all fees but shall still be required
to register and obtain a license from the village.
   C.   All fees are per calendar year or part thereof, and license fees shall
not be prorated. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-6: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
Upon receipt of an application for a license under this chapter, the village
president shall cause a copy thereof to be sent to the police department and
the building inspector, each of which shall report back to the president within
twenty one (21) days whether the applicant and the proposed location of the
secondhand dealership is in accordance with applicable village codes. (Ord.
2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-7: CONDITIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon receipt of the report from the departments referred to in section
4-6-6 of this chapter, the village president shall issue the license requested
unless he shall find that:
   A.   The applicant is under the age of eighteen (18).
   B.   The location requested is not in a permanent structure.
   C.   The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have been
convicted of or have pled guilty to any offense related to theft, burglary, or
purchasing or receiving stolen items under the laws of the state, village or
any other jurisdiction within the past ten (10) years, or have forfeited a bond
to appear in court to answer for charges for such offenses during such time.
   D.   The location requested and structure to be used would not comply with
all applicable laws including the zoning ordinance of the village.
   E.   The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have held
a license or had an interest in a license issued by the village or any other
jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of secondhand property which was
revoked for cause.
   F.   The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have
knowingly furnished false or misleading information or withheld relevant
information on any application for a license required by this chapter or any
investigation into any application. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-8: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE OR STOCK:
   A.   No license issued under this chapter may be transferred to any other
person.
   B.   No corporate licensee shall permit any transfer of its stock which
would vest in aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock outstanding in
such corporation in any shareholder unless such shareholder has been certified
by the village administrator as meeting the requirements of section
4-6-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-9: POSTING LICENSE:
Every license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall, at all times
during the period for which it is effective, be posted in a conspicuous place
at or near the principal entrance to the premises for which the license is
issued. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-10: LOCATION REGULATIONS:
No licensee shall carry on any business required to be licensed under this
chapter except at the location designated on the license. Should the licensee
wish to change the location, application shall be made to the village president
for such change in writing. The president shall approve the change of location
unless the new location would be contrary to the provisions of this chapter or
any other ordinances of the village. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-11: CLOSING HOURS:
No licensee shall purchase any goods, wares, articles or things whatsoever from
any person between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. the next day. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-12: PROHIBITED PURCHASES:
No licensee under this chapter shall purchase or accept any goods, wares,
articles or things under any of the following circumstances:
   A.   Where the seller is less than the age of eighteen (18).
   B.   Where the seller is intoxicated.
   C.   Where the seller fails to present a valid and current identification
government issued ID containing the seller's full legal name, date of birth,
address, photograph, and an identification number.
   D.   Where the article to be purchased had an original manufacturer's serial
number at the time it was new but no longer legibly exhibits such number.
   E.   Where the licensee or its employee or agent knows or reasonably should
have known that the items are stolen or otherwise illegal to possess. (Ord.
2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-13: WEAPONS PURCHASES OR SALES PROHIBITED:
No licensee shall deal in, or buy or sell or display in his shop, any pistol,
revolver, derringer, bowie knife, dirk or other deadly weapon of like
character, capable of being secreted upon the person, unless such licensee
shall also possess a valid and current license as provided under some other
legal authority. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-14: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Record Of Purchases:
      1.   Every licensee shall keep at the licensed location a register on
multicopy forms provided by the chief of police in which shall be accurately
entered all of the following information:
         a.   A succinct and accurate description of all property taken
(excluding junk/scrap), purchased or received in the course of the business
licensed under this article including:
            (1)   Type of article.
            (2)   Brand name/make/manufacturer.
            (3)   Model number.
            (4)   Serial number.
            (5)   Color/finish.
            (6)   Any other identifying marks, writings, engravings, etc.
         b.   Clear photograph of any property using LeadsOnline cameras.
         c.   Seller's full legal name, date of birth, and address. Also
required is a color copy or photograph of a valid and current government issued
photo ID containing the aforementioned information.
         d.   The amount given or loaned to such person and the terms thereof.
         e.   The signature of the employee who received the property.
         f.   A signed statement of the person from whom the property was
obtained affirming that he is over eighteen (18) years of age and lawful owner
of the property which is clear of all attachments.
      2.   Entries made in the register shall be printed or typed and shall be
legible. All entries shall be made immediately upon receipt or purchase of any
property. The register shall be open to inspection by any law enforcement
officer during the performance of their duties during normal hours of
operation.
      3.   a. Effective January 1, 2015, all licensees are required to use the
LeadsOnline system for keeping records under this chapter. The chief of police
shall provide information on obtaining the software and hardware necessary for
this purpose.
         b.   All licensees shall subscribe to and participate in
"leadsonline.com", the current software based tracking system approved by the
chief of police. Any article deposited, pawned or pledged shall be entered into
leadsonline.com and downloaded into the database within twelve (12) hours of
receipt of the article. LeadsOnline may be substituted in the future at the
discretion of the chief, however substitution shall be made with ample notice
to licensees to allow for compliance.
   B.   Reports To Chief Of Police; Exemptions:
      1.   It shall be the duty of every licensee under this article to (upon
request) have available for delivery to the chief of police or designee a
legible, correct, and complete copy of the register for the period of time as
specified.
      2.   No person shall be required to furnish such description of any new
property purchased from manufacturers or wholesale dealers having an
established place of business, or of any goods purchased at open sale, or from
a bankrupt stock. Such goods must be accompanied by a bill of sale or other
evidence of open and legitimate purchase and must be shown to the chief of
police and members of the police department, when demanded. (Ord. 2014-1418,
11-4-2014)
4-6-15: WAITING PERIODS AFTER SALES:
The licensee under this chapter shall keep all property purchased or received
from an individual available for inspection for the period of time as
prescribed below before it can be sold, traded, or discarded. Licensees may
advertise, display, and sell items during their respective waiting periods but
they must remain on the licensed premises until the waiting period expires.
Gold and silver commodities identified in subsection B2 of this section may be
sold or disposed of after seven (7) days. However, in the event the items are
determined to be stolen and the owner is identified within fourteen (14) days
of the date of receipt by the dealer, the dealer shall make the owner whole for
the total fair market value of the items.
   A.   Fourteen (14) day waiting period:
      1.   All items with serial numbers or other identifying markings/
engravings (excluding appliances).
      2.   Memorabilia/collectibles (i.e., autographed items, sports cards,
collectible stamps, figurines, etc.).
      3.   Collectible artwork (numbered prints, sculptures, etc.).
      4.   Jewelry (precious metals, gemstones, etc., excluding costume
jewelry).
      5.   Collectible currency/collectible coins.
      6.   Musical instruments.
      7.   Automobile wheels/rims.
   B.   Seven (7) day waiting period:
      1.   Appliances.
      2.   Gold/silver and other precious metal coins, bars, etc., valued only
as commodities, not otherwise uniquely identifiable or collectible.
      3.   All other items not specified in this section.
   C.   No waiting period required (only below items lacking serial numbers or
other identifying markings/engravings):
      1.   Video games.
      2.   Music (CDs, cassettes, records, etc.).
      3.   Movies (DVDs, tapes, etc.).
      4.   Furniture.
      5.   Sporting goods.
      6.   Tools. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-16: INSPECTIONS; PROPERTY SEIZURES:
Every licensee under this article and every person employed by the licensee in
the conduct of business shall admit to any and every part of the premises
designated in the license, during normal business hours, any law enforcement
officer of the village, county or state to examine any goods, articles, things,
pledges, pawns, or books or other records on the premises dealing with purchase
or sale of used property and to search for and to take into possession any
article known or for which he has reasonable grounds to believe to have been
stolen. Such law enforcement officer may make any such search or seizure as is
provided for in this section, and property so seized shall be receipted for by
such officer who shall adequately describe the seized property and sign the
receipt. Should the officer determine the property not to be stolen, he shall
promptly return same to the licensee. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-17: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE; HEARING:
   A.   Any license issued for a secondhand dealer under this chapter may be
revoked or suspended for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days by the
president if he shall find, after hearing:
      1.   That the licensee, its officers, agents or employees have violated
any of the provisions of this chapter, the laws of the state, or other
ordinances of the village in the operation of the business;
      2.   That the licensee, its partners, officers or shareholders have been
convicted of any offense set forth in subsection
4-6-7C of this chapter; or
      3.   That the licensee, its partners, officers or shareholders have
knowingly furnished false or misleading information or withheld relevant
information on any application for a license required by this chapter or any
investigation into any application.
   B.   The licensee shall be responsible for the acts of its agents, servants
and employees in the operation of the business. Prior to holding a hearing
concerning the questions of whether a license shall be revoked or suspended,
the village president shall give at least ten (10) days' written notice to the
licensee specifically describing the alleged violation. The licensee may
present evidence and cross examine witnesses at such hearing. (Ord. 2014-1418,
11-4-2014)
4-6-18: EXEMPTIONS:
The following are exempt from the requirements of this chapter:
   A.   Garage sales.
   B.   Sales conducted by governmental, civic, patriotic, fraternal,
educational, religious or benevolent organizations which have been in active
and continuous existence for at least one year prior to the holding of the
sale, or which are incorporated as not for profit corporations by the state.
   C.   Sales or purchases which are regulated by the licensing laws of the
state, including automobile dealers, used parts dealers and automotive parts
recyclers.
   D.   Consumer shows, or exhibitions of collectibles holding a license
pursuant to any other license issued by the village.
   E.   Sales or trades of used books between a customer and owner of a used
bookstore. (Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014)
4-6-19: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. In addition to the penalty set forth
herein, the village retains the right to suspend or revoke the license for a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or state or federal laws.
(Ord. 2014-1418, 11-4-2014; amd. 2016 Code)
CHAPTER 7
PEDDLERS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definitions
4-7-2: License Required; Expiration
4-7-3: Application For License
4-7-4: License Fee
4-7-5: Background Check; Ineligibility For License
4-7-6: Nontransferability Of License
4-7-7: Possession Of License Required
4-7-8: Restrictions On Peddlers
4-7-9: Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Hearing
4-7-10: Exemptions
4-7-11: Penalty
4-7-12: Sales Of Food Items From Non-Motorized Carts
4-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning is intended:
   NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION: Any bona fide charitable, educational, fraternal,
labor, religious, or veterans' organization that operates without profit to its
members and which has been in existence continuously for a period of five (5)
years or more immediately before making application for a license and which has
had, during the entire five (5) year period, a bona fide membership engaged in
carrying out its objectives. If the organization has an exemption under section
501(c) of the internal revenue code, the five (5) year requirement is waived.
   PEDDLER: Every person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange,
at retail, any goods, wares or merchandise by traveling from place to place in,
along and upon the streets, avenues, alleys or public thoroughfares of the
village; or who shall sell and deliver from any vehicle goods, wares or
merchandise, by going from place to place in the village, whether to regular
customers or not; or who shall sell and deliver goods, wares or merchandise
from any vehicle parked on public property. The term shall also mean every
person who moves from house to house or from place to place in the village
selling or taking orders for goods, wares, subscriptions or merchandise for
future delivery. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXPIRATION:
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to transact any business within the
village without first having obtained a license therefor. All peddler's
licenses shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year in which the license
was issued. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a peddler's license shall be made in writing to the village
administrator and shall set forth the following:
   A.   The name of the individual applying for the license.
   B.   The residence, telephone number and driver's license number of the
applicant.
   C.   The address of the principal place of business of the applicant and the
applicant's telephone number.
   D.   If the applicant is employed by another person or entity, the name of
the employer, its address and telephone number.
   E.   A state of Illinois sales tax number or other evidence that the
business is registered with the state department of revenue.
   F.   An applicant engaged in the sale of food or beverages shall demonstrate
compliance with chapter 3, article A of this title imposing a tax on the
privilege of purchasing food items or alcoholic beverages. Any such applicant
issued a peddler's license shall comply with all applicable provisions of
chapter 3, article A of this title. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-4: LICENSE FEE:
Each applicant for a peddler's license under this chapter shall pay to the
village treasurer, with the application, a fee of five hundred dollars
($500.00) per calendar year or part thereof. Should the application be denied,
the license fee shall be refunded to the applicant. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-5: BACKGROUND CHECK; INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
Upon receipt of an application, the village administrator shall submit the
application to the chief of police. Upon receipt of the application from the
village administrator, the chief of police shall conduct a conviction
information/criminal history background check through the Illinois state
police. The chief of police shall issue a license to an eligible applicant
within seven (7) days after receipt of the results of the background check from
the Illinois state police; provided, however, no such license shall be issued
to an applicant whose conviction information/criminal history background check
results indicate, or if the chief of police otherwise obtains information
indicating, the applicant has been convicted of:
   A.   A felony or any offense which, if committed in the state of Illinois,
would have been a felony;
   B.   A sex offense for which the applicant is required to register as a sex
offender; or
   C.   An offense involving fraud or deceit. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-6: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
No license issued under the authority of this chapter shall be transferable.
(Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-7: POSSESSION OF LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any person licensed pursuant to this chapter shall, at all times while engaged
in the activities regulated by this chapter, keep said license in his or her
possession and shall display the same upon the demand of any police officer or
upon the request of any person whose premises he seeks to enter. (Ord. 2015-
1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-8: RESTRICTIONS ON PEDDLERS:
   A.   Departure Required Upon Request: It is unlawful for any peddler to
enter or remain upon private premises in disregard of the expressed wish of the
owner or occupant of such premises or to enter into a private residence or
other privately owned or occupied building without the express consent of the
owner or occupant of such residence or building.
   B.   Compliance With Sign Prohibiting Peddling: It shall be unlawful for any
peddler to enter upon any premises or to in any way disturb or attempt to gain
the attention of the owner or occupant of any premises if a sign having
dimensions of not less than three inches by five inches (3" x 5") which states
"No Peddlers Allowed" or other words of similar substance has been posted at a
conspicuous location near the front entrance to the premises.
   C.   Prohibited Hours: It shall be unlawful for any peddler to transact the
business of a "peddler", as defined by this chapter, between the hours of six
o'clock (6:00) P.M. on one day and ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on the following
day.
   D.   Transactions From Parked Vehicles: Whenever a peddler engages in the
activities of a peddler from a vehicle parked on a public street, the vehicle
shall be stopped at the right hand curb of the street or at the extreme right
and edge of a pavement. No business shall be transacted from any vehicle except
from the curbside thereof. Nothing in this subsection shall allow any peddler
to park a vehicle in violation of any applicable local or state law or
regulation. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-9: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; HEARING:
If the village president, after a hearing held by him, shall find that any
person has wilfully violated the provisions of this chapter, he may suspend or
revoke the license issued hereunder. The licensee shall have an opportunity to
be heard at such hearing to be held not less than five (5) days after notice of
the time and place of the hearing, addressed by the president or his designee
and mailed or personally delivered to the last known address of the licensee.
(Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015; amd. 2016 Code)
4-7-10: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   The following shall be exempt from the application and license
requirements imposed by this chapter:
      1.   Persons engaged in the sale of or solicitation to purchase
newspapers, magazines, books and other printed materials;
      2.   Persons seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing
or other valuable things for the support or benefit of any charitable,
religious, political or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or
project;
      3.   Any person seeking to proselytize beliefs by any charitable,
religious, political or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or
project; or
      4.   Nonprofit organizations; provided, however, that the organization
provides documentation to the chief of police sufficient to demonstrate that it
qualifies as a "nonprofit organization" as defined in this chapter.
   B.   Persons exempt from the application and license requirements under the
provisions of this section shall nevertheless be subject to the remaining
provisions of this chapter including, without limitation, those sections
requiring departure from private property upon the request of the owner or
occupant, disturbing or attempting to gain the attention of the owner or
occupant of any premises with a sign indicating that no peddlers are allowed
and the limitation on the hours during which business may be transacted. (Ord.
2015-1449, 7-15-2015)
4-7-11: PENALTY:
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each day that a violation continues. (Ord. 2015-1449, 7-15-2015;
amd. 2016 Code)
4-7-12: SALES OF FOOD ITEMS FROM NON-MOTORIZED CARTS:
For purposes of this section
4-7-12, a “Pushcart” is any non-motorized vehicle from which food sales are
made. It shall be unlawful to engage in sales from a Pushcart without a valid
peddler's license pursuant to Section
4-7-2 of this code. No peddler engaging in sales from a pushcart may stand in a
stationary position on public property except when actually engaged in the
transaction of a sale of food items from the pushcart. Peddler's wishing to
engage in stationary sales at a public event on public property may do so only
with written permission granted by the Village Administrator. (Ord. 2021-1659,
7-20-2021)
CHAPTER 8
PEDAL BUSES AND PEDICABS
ARTICLE A. PEDAL BUSES
SECTION:
4-8A-1: Purpose
4-8A-2: Definitions
4-8A-3: License Required
4-8A-4: Condition Of Pedal Bus; Inspections
4-8A-5: Pedal Bus Driver Requirements
4-8A-6: Rates
4-8A-7: Rules And Regulations
4-8A-8: Pedal Bus Operation
4-8A-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is intended to regulate the operation of pedal buses as a means of
group transportation within the village in order to promote safety for pedal
bus passengers as well as to promote safe vehicular and pedestrian traffic.
(Ord. 2019-1604, 9-17-2019)
4-8A-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms when used in this chapter shall have the indicated meanings
unless the use or context clearly indicates another meaning is intended:
 
                            Any single-unit device upon which any person may
                            ride, propelled by human power through a belt,
                            chain, or gears, having four (4) or more wheels,
PEDAL BUS:                  and designed and constructed in such a manner as to
                            engage in the business of carrying groups of
                            passengers for hire as agreed by pre-arranged
                            contract.
                            The business of operating a pedal bus for the
PEDAL BUS BUSINESS:         recreational or physical transportation of groups
                            of the general public as agreed by pre-arranged
                            contract.
PEDAL BUS DRIVER:           The person in actual physical control of the pedal
                            bus.
PEDAL BUS BUSINESS LICENSE: A license granted in accordance with this chapter.
OPERATOR:                   The owner of a business that provides pedal bus
                            services. (Ord. 2019-1604, 9-17-2019)
 
4-8A-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to all pedal buses
and to the drivers and operators of such pedal buses within the corporate
limits of the village. Every pedal bus business shall register with the village
and obtain a license before conducting any such business within the village.
   B.   Each license issued under this chapter shall expire April 30 of the
fiscal year for which such license was issued. The fee for licenses shall be
five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year. Licenses issued during the fiscal year
shall be subject to prorated license fees.
   C.   Application: A verified application for a pedal bus business license
shall be made in writing by the owner or manager of the pedal bus to the
village administrator or her/his designee upon forms furnished by the village.
The application shall include the following information as applicable:
      1.   The full name of the applicant (if a firm or corporation, provide
names, telephone numbers and addresses of the president, secretary and
treasurer);
      2.   The applicant's residence (local and permanent) address;
      3.   The full name and intended place of business, the telephone number
of the business, and the owner and/or manager;
      4.   The number of pedal buses to be operated, a complete description of
each pedal bus to be used, pictures clearly depicting all four (4) sides of
each unit to be operated, the seating capacity thereof according to its trade
rating, the company assigned number for each unit (if any), the body style, and
the color;
      5.   Insurance certificates; and
       6.   Signature of applicant.
   D.   Issuance:
      1.   The village administrator or her/his designee is authorized to issue
a license to any qualified applicant for the operation of a pedal bus business.
The license shall contain a distinguishing number, full name of the person
owning such pedal bus business, and his/her business address.
      2.   The pedal bus business license shall be non-assignable and
nontransferable.
      3.   The pedal bus business shall carry a copy of said license aboard
each pedal bus unit at all times and shall present it for inspection upon the
request of any passenger or law enforcement officer.
      4.   Whenever an owner/manager of a pedal bus business has lost or
destroyed his/her license, he/she shall submit an affidavit in writing to the
village administrator or her/his designee, stating that the license has been
lost or destroyed. The village administrator or her/his designee shall issue a
duplicate copy or substitute thereof upon payment of a fee in the amount of
twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      5.   The village shall issue no more than one (1) license to a pedal bus
business before April 30, 2023; provided, however that the village shall offer
licenses to additional pedal bus business operators in the event the sole
licensee operates a pedal bus business outside of the village but within twenty
five (25) miles of the Peoria Heights Village Hall.
   E.   Licensees shall report any change in information furnished in the
application for a pedal bus business license pursuant to this division to the
village administrator or her/his designee in writing within ten (10) days of
the change. Failure to so report shall be cause for suspension or revocation of
the license.
   F.   Renewal: If a pedal bus business license holder wants to renew their
license so that the renewal takes effect immediately upon the expiration of the
prior annual license, such license holder must submit the renewal application
prior to April 15. Applications for renewal submitted after April 15 shall
incur a late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), plus a per diem late fee in
the amount of five dollars ($5.00) per day for each day after April 15 that the
application is submitted. If the late fee is not paid prior to issuance of the
renewed license, the existing license shall lapse as of midnight April 30.
   G.   Suspension Or Revocation:
      1.   The village administrator may initiate suspension and/or revocation
proceedings for a license issued under this chapter for any of the following:
         a.   Violation of any ordinance provisions regulating a license of a
pedal bus business or any other provisions of the village code;
         b.   Knowingly allowing any individual to operate or drive a pedal bus
with a driver's license that is suspended or revoked under the Illinois Vehicle
Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.).
      2.   Any person whose business license has been revoked shall immediately
return every such license to the village administrator. (Ord. 2019-1604, 9-17-
2019)
4-8A-4: CONDITION OF PEDAL BUS; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   No license to engage in the business of driving a pedal bus shall be
issued unless:
      1.   The pedal bus is equipped with seats for the driver and all
passengers;
      2.   The pedal bus provides a hood or cover to protect passengers from
the elements;
      3.   The pedal bus is equipped with hydraulic or mechanical disc brakes,
a battery-operated or generator-operated headlight and taillight, both front
and rear turn signals, tires, and bell or horn;
      4.   The pedal bus has been inspected and found by the village
administrator or her/his designee to be in clean, sanitary, safe and good
mechanical condition for the transportation of passengers; and
      5.   A written certificate of the inspection required by this section is
filed with the village administrator or her/his designee.
   B.   Every pedal bus in operation shall be inspected at the beginning of the
license year to determine if such pedal bus meets the requirements of this
chapter. The inspection required may be conducted by the village or by such
duly qualified persons as the village administrator may direct.
   C.   Additional inspections may be required as often as the apparent
condition of the pedal bus warrants.
   D.   All pedal buses shall have the name of the pedal bus business as
provided to the village administrator or her/his designee in visible lettering
at least three (3) inches in height painted conspicuously upon the pedal bus
unit.
   E.   It shall be unlawful to operate a pedal bus that is wider than eighty-
four (84) inches at its widest point.
   F.   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, or cause to be driven, a
pedal bus that is not in good working order. (Ord. 2019-1604, 9-17-2019)
4-8A-5: PEDAL BUS DRIVER REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall drive a pedal bus or be permitted to do so if they are not:
   A.   A duly licensed driver in the State of Illinois;
   B.   Familiar with local traffic laws and ordinances; and
   C.   The age of nineteen (19) years or older. (Ord. 2019-1604, 9-17-2019)
4-8A-6: RATES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of a pedal bus to charge a
passenger a fare that was not agreed upon with the passenger in advance through
a pre-arranged contract.
   B.   A copy of said contract must be present with the pedal bus driver for
the duration of each group's reservation. (Ord. 2019-1604, 9-17-2019)
4-8A-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Proof Of Insurance Or Bond: No pedal bus business shall provide pedal
bus service unless such pedal bus is covered by a bond or an insurance policy
or other proof of general liability insurance in the minimum amount of one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00)
per incident, and one hundred thousand ($100,000.00) for property damage.
Evidence of such coverage shall be filed with the village administrator prior
to the issuance of any pedal bus business license.
   B.   No driver or other employee of a pedal bus business shall imitate the
name, colors, or emblems, previously adopted and in use by any other pedal bus
business or represent him/herself as an employee of any other pedal bus
business.
   C.   No person shall knowingly permit any pedal bus to be used in the
perpetration of a crime.
   D.   Every driver of a pedal bus shall obey all traffic rules established by
statute or ordinance.
   E.   No pedal bus driver shall exceed the rated seating capacity of the
pedal bus.
   F.   No passenger shall be allowed to ride the pedal bus except in the
designated seating area.
   G.   Pedal buses licensed under this chapter shall not operate or permit the
operation of any sound amplification system that creates noise that is audible
more than twenty (20) feet from the pedal bus.
   H.   Alcohol Possession And Consumption:
      1.   No pedal bus operator or driver shall provide an alcoholic beverage
to a passenger for a fee or as part of the passenger transport service.
      2.   No pedal bus operator or driver shall provide or stock any alcoholic
beverage in the pedal bus.
      3.   Alcoholic beverages may be consumed by a pedal bus passenger under
the following conditions:
         a.   No glassware of any kind shall be allowed for consumption of
alcoholic liquor on a pedal bus. This prohibition includes, but is not limited
to, bottles, receptacles, or drinking glasses. Glass bottles or containers may
be used solely by the pedal bus operator or its employees for the exclusive
purpose of uncorking, pouring, serving, or otherwise controlling the
consumption of alcoholic liquor.
         b.   Alcoholic beverages as described in this section may be consumed
only from plastic or foam cups.
         c.   Alcoholic beverages as described in this section may be consumed
only when the passenger is in or on a pedal bus and only when otherwise
permitted by all applicable state laws and regulations.
         d.   The pedal bus operator and driver may not allow consumption of
alcoholic beverages by persons under the age of twenty-one (21). (Ord. 2019-
1604, 9-17-2019)
4-8A-8: PEDAL BUS OPERATION:
   A.   No pedal bus driver shall transport passengers while using a wireless
device unless said pedal bus is not in motion.
   B.   No pedal bus shall be driven in weather conditions that pose an
unreasonable safety risk to the driver or passengers of the pedal bus, or to
motorists or pedestrians.
   C.   For the purposes of immediately loading and unloading passengers, a
pedal bus may remain standing upon a street if the pedal bus is in any legal
parking stall, designated loading zone, or any other location that does not
impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
   D.   No pedal bus shall be left unattended by the pedal bus driver unless
legally parked in a legal parking stall.
   E.   No pedal bus driver shall operate a pedal bus on a street with a posted
speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or greater, except for the
purpose of crossing that street.
   F.   No pedal bus driver, while driving a pedal bus, shall stop on a street
with a posted speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or greater in
order to pick up or drop off passengers.
   G.   No pedal bus driver shall drive a pedal bus on a sidewalk.
   H.   No pedal bus driver shall drive a pedal bus in a way that obstructs the
flow of pedestrian traffic, except for the time period necessary to pick up or
drop off passengers.
   I.   Route Restrictions: Pedal bus operation shall be limited to the
following streets:
      1.   North Prospect Road;
      2.   East Paris Avenue;
      3.   North Boulevard Avenue;
      4.   East Lake Avenue; and
      5.   Grandview Drive; provided that the Peoria Park District provides
written consent to the pedal bus business to operate thereon. (Ord. 2019-1604,
9-17-2019)
ARTICLE B. PEDICABS
SECTION:
4-8B-1: Purpose
4-8B-2: Definitions
4-8B-3: License Required
4-8B-4: Condition Of Pedicab; Inspections
4-8B-5: Pedicab Driver Requirements
4-8B-6: Rates
4-8B-7: Rules And Regulations
4-8B-8: Pedicab Operation
4-8B-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is intended to regulate the operation of pedicabs as a means of
transportation within the Village in order to promote safety for pedicab
passengers as well as to promote safe vehicular and pedestrian traffic. (Ord.
2020-1635, 10-6-2020)
4-8B-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms when used in this chapter shall have the indicated meanings
unless the use or context clearly indicates another meaning is intended:
 
                          A bicycle that has three (3) or more wheels that
                          transports, or is capable of transporting, passengers
                          on seats attached to the bicycle that is operated by
                          an individual, and that is used for transporting
                          passengers for receipt of any form of consideration;
PEDICAB:                  or a bicycle with a singular unarticulated frame,
                          that pulls a device that transports, or is capable of
                          transporting, passengers on seats attached to a
                          passenger cab or similar device, that is operated by
                          an individual, and that is used for transporting
                          passengers for receipt of any form of consideration.
                          The business of operating a pedicab for the
PEDICAB BUSINESS:         recreational or physical transportation of the
                          general public as agreed by pre-arranged contract.
PEDICAB BUSINESS LICENSE: A license granted in accordance with this chapter.
PEDICAB DRIVER:           The person in actual physical control of the pedicab.
OPERATOR:                 The owner of a business that provides pedicab
                          services. (Ord. 2020-1635, 10-6-2020)
 
4-8B-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to all pedicabs and
to the drivers and operators of such pedicabs within the corporate limits of
the Village of Peoria Heights. Every pedicab business shall register with the
Village and obtain a license before conducting any such business within the
Village.
   B.   Each license issued under this chapter shall expire April 30 of the
fiscal year for which such license was issued. The fee for licenses shall be
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year. Licenses issued during the fiscal
year shall be subject to prorated license fees.
   C.   Application: A verified application for a pedicab business license
shall be made in writing by the owner or manager of the pedicab to the Village
Administrator or her/his designee upon forms furnished by the Village. The
application shall include the following information as applicable:
      1.   The full name of the applicant (if a firm or corporation, provide
names, telephone numbers and addresses of the president, secretary and
treasurer);
      2.   The applicant's residence (local and permanent) address;
      3.   The full name and intended place of business, the telephone number
of the business, and the owner and/or manager;
      4.   The number of pedicabs to be operated, a complete description of
each pedicab to be used, pictures clearly depicting all four (4) sides of each
unit to be operated, the seating capacity thereof according to its trade
rating, the company assigned number for each unit (if any), the body style, and
the color;
      5.   Insurance certificates; and
      6.   Signature of applicant.
   D.   Issuance.
      1.   The Village Administrator or her/his designee is authorized to issue
a license to any qualified applicant for the operation of a pedicab business.
The license shall contain a distinguishing number, full name of the person
owning such pedicab business, and his/her business address.
      2.   The pedicab business license shall be non-assignable and
nontransferable.
      3.   The pedicab business shall carry a copy of said license aboard each
pedicab unit at all times and shall present it for inspection upon the request
of any passenger or law enforcement officer.
      4.   Whenever an owner/manager of a pedicab business has lost or
destroyed his/her license, he/she shall submit an affidavit in writing to the
Village Administrator or her/his designee, stating that the license has been
lost or destroyed. The Village Administrator or her/his designee shall issue a
duplicate copy or substitute thereof upon payment of a fee in the amount of
twenty five dollars ($25.00).
   E.   Licensees shall report any change in information furnished in the
application for a pedicab business license pursuant to this division to the
Village Administrator or her/his designee in writing within ten (10) days of
the change. Failure to so report shall be cause for suspension or revocation of
the license.
   F.   Renewal: If a pedicab business license holder wants to renew their
license so that the renewal takes effect immediately upon the expiration of the
prior annual license, such license holder must submit the renewal application
prior to April 15. Applications for renewal submitted after April 15 shall
incur a late fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00), plus a per diem late fee in
the amount of five dollars ($5.00) per day for each day after April 15 that the
application is submitted. If the late fee is not paid prior to issuance of the
renewed license, the existing license shall lapse as of midnight April 30.
   G.   Suspension or revocation.
      1.   The Village Administrator may initiate suspension and/or revocation
proceedings for a license issued under this chapter for any of the following:
         a.   Violation of any ordinance provisions regulating a license of a
pedicab business or any other provisions of the Peoria Heights Village Code;
         b.   Knowingly allowing any individual to operate or drive a pedicab
with a driver's license that is suspended or revoked under the Illinois Vehicle
Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.).
      2.   Any person whose business license has been revoked shall immediately
return every such license to the Village Administrator. (Ord. 2020- 1635, 10-6-
2020)
4-8B-4: CONDITION OF PEDICAB; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   No license to engage in the business of driving a pedicab shall be
issued unless:
      1.   The pedicab is equipped with seats for the driver and all
passengers;
      2.   The pedicab is equipped with hydraulic or mechanical disc brakes, a
battery-operated or generator-operated headlight and taillight, both front and
rear turn signals, tires, and bell or horn;
      3.   The pedicab has been inspected and found by the Village
Administrator or her/his designee to be in clean, sanitary, safe and good
mechanical condition for the transportation of passengers; and
      4.   A written certificate of the inspection required by this section is
filed with the Village Administrator or her/his designee.
   B.   Every pedicab in operation shall be inspected at the beginning of the
license year to determine if such pedicab meets the requirements of this
chapter. The inspection required may be conducted by the Village or by such
duly qualified persons as the Village Administrator may direct.
   C.   Additional inspections may be required as often as the apparent
condition of the pedicab warrants.
   D.   All pedicabs shall have the name of the pedicab business as provided to
the Village Administrator or her/his designee in visible lettering painted
conspicuously upon the pedicab unit.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, or cause to be driven, a
pedicab that is not in good working order. (Ord. 2020-1635, 10-6-2020)
4-8B-5: PEDICAB DRIVER REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall drive a pedicab or be permitted to do so if they are not:
   A.   A duly licensed driver in the State of Illinois;
   B.   Familiar with local traffic laws and ordinances;
   C.   The age of nineteen (19) years or older. (Ord. 2020-1635, 10-6-2020)
4-8B-6: RATES:
Each pedicab shall clearly post rates within the pedicab. (Ord. 2020-1635, 10-
6-2020)
4-8B-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Proof of insurance or bond. No pedicab business shall provide pedicab
service unless such pedicab is covered by a bond or an insurance policy or
other proof of general liability insurance in the minimum amount of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) per
incident, and one hundred thousand ($100,000.00) for property damage. Evidence
of such coverage shall be filed with the Village Administrator prior to the
issuance of any pedicab business license.
   B.   No driver or other employee of a pedicab business shall imitate the
name, colors, or emblems, previously adopted and in use by any another pedicab
business or represent him/herself as an employee of any other pedicab business.
   C.   No person shall knowingly permit any pedicab to be used in the
perpetration of a crime.
   D.   Every driver of a pedicab shall obey all traffic rules established by
statute or ordinance.
   E.   No pedicab driver shall exceed the rated seating capacity of the
pedicab.
   F.   No passenger shall be allowed to ride the pedicab except in the
designated seating area.
   G.   Pedicabs licensed under this chapter shall not operate or permit the
operation of any sound amplification system that creates noise that is audible
more than twenty (20) feet from the pedicab.
   H.   Alcoholic beverages may not be consumed on a pedicab. (Ord. 2020-1635,
10-6-2020)
4-8B-8: PEDICAB OPERATION:
   A.   No pedicab driver shall transport passengers while using a wireless
device unless said Pedicab is not in motion.
   B.   No pedicab shall be driven in weather conditions that pose an
unreasonable safety risk to the driver or passengers of the pedicab, or to
motorists or pedestrians.
   C.   For the purposes of immediately loading and unloading passengers, a
pedicab may remain standing upon a street if the pedicab is in any legal
parking stall, designated loading zone, or any other location that does not
impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
   D.   No pedicab shall be left unattended by the pedicab driver unless
legally parked in a legal parking stall.
   E.   No pedicab driver shall operate a pedicab on a street with a posted
speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or greater, except for the
purpose of crossing that street.
   F.   No Pedicab driver, while driving a Pedicab, shall stop on a street with
a posted speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or greater in order to
pick up or drop off passengers.
   G.   No pedicab driver shall drive a pedicab on a sidewalk.
   H.   No pedicab driver shall drive a pedicab in a way that obstructs the
flow of pedestrian traffic, except for the time period necessary to pick up or
drop off passengers.
   I.   Route restrictions: Pedicab operation shall be limited to the following
streets:
      1.   North Prospect Road;
      2.   East Paris Avenue;
      3.   North Boulevard Avenue;
      4.   East Lake Avenue; and
      5.   Grandview Drive; provided that the Peoria Park District provides
written consent to the pedicab business to operate thereon. (Ord. 2020-1635,
10-6-2020)
CHAPTER 9
MUNICIPAL CANNABIS RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: Tax Imposed; Rate
4-9-3: Collection Of Tax By Recreational Cannabis Retailers
4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
The words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS 705/
1-1 et seq.), as may be amended from time to time, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning. (Ord. 2019-1606, 9-17-2019)
4-9-2: TAX IMPOSED; RATE:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling adult-use, recreational cannabis at retail in the village at the rate
of 3.0% of the gross receipts from these sales made in the course of that
business. Such tax shall not apply to sales of cannabis that are made pursuant
to the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act (410 ILCS 130/1 et
seq.) as may be amended from time to time.
   B.   The imposition of this tax is in accordance with the provisions of
Illinois Municipal Cannabis Retailers' Occupation Tax Law, as set forth in
Section 8-11-22 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-22), as amended
from time to time. (Ord. 2019-1606, 9-17-2019)
4-9-3: COLLECTION OF TAX BY RECREATIONAL CANNABIS RETAILERS:
   A.   The tax imposed by this chapter shall be remitted by such retailer to
the Illinois Department of Revenue. Any tax required to be collected pursuant
to or as authorized by this chapter and any such tax collected by such retailer
and required to be remitted to the Illinois Department of Revenue shall
constitute a debt owed by the retailer to the State of Illinois. Retailers may
reimburse themselves for their seller's tax liability hereunder by separately
stating that tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in
combination, in a single amount, with any State tax that sellers are required
to collect.
   B.   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed
as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power
to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-1606, 9-
17-2019)
CHAPTER 10
BODYWORK ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definitions
4-10-2: License Required
4-10-3: Application Requirements
4-10-4: Issuance Of License
4-10-5: Facilities
4-10-6: Operating Requirements
4-10-7: Solicitation Prohibited
4-10-8: Advertising
4-10-9: Inspections
4-10-10: Transfer Of License
4-10-11: Display Of License
4-10-12: Employment Of Massage Therapists
4-10-13: Revocation Or Suspension Of License
4-10-14: Renewal Of License
4-10-15: Public Nuisance
4-10-16: Penalty
4-10-17: Appeals
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
4-10-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise, offer, engage in, conduct or
carry on, or to permit to be advertised, offered, engaged in, conducted, or
carried on, in or upon any premises in the village, the operation of a bodywork
establishment as herein defined, without first having obtained a license from
the village pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, with the exception of
the following:
   A.   Hospitals, nursing homes, medical facilities, or offices at which
physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths, podiatrists, naprapaths,
occupational therapists, physical therapists, or other health care workers duly
licensed by the State of Illinois to provide, on an ongoing basis, professional
health services to individuals including, but not limited to, services
permitted by the Illinois Occupational Therapy Practices Act (225 ILCS 75/1 et
seq.); the Illinois Physical Therapy Act (225 ILCS 90/1 et seq.); or the
Illinois Naprapathic Practices Act (225 ILCS 63/1 et seq.);
   B.   Athletic trainers for any athletic program of a private or public
school, college, or any athletic team regularly organized or engaging in
competition;
   C.   Barbers, estheticians, and cosmetologists who are duly licensed by the
State of Illinois, and who perform massage in a manner consistent with their
training and the code of ethics of their respective professions;
   D.   Practitioners who only provide bodywork services of the neck, back,
face, scalp, hair, hands, and/or feet of a patron who is fully clothed; and
   E.   Bodywork provided by massage therapy students enrolled in a massage
therapy program approved by the Illinois Department of Financial and
Professional Regulation during the course of clinical externships, practicums
or community services, provided that such bodywork services are part of the
curricular requirements of the recognized school and for which no compensation
is received by the students. (Ord. 2025-1763, 6-3-2025)
4-10-3: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate, or conduct a
bodywork establishment shall file an application with the village clerk as
provided herein. The application shall be in the form provided by the village
clerk or his/her designee.
   B.   All license fees and other required fees, including costs of
fingerprinting and background investigations, shall be paid at the time the
application is submitted:
   C.   The application for a license to operate a bodywork establishment shall
set forth the exact nature of the services to be administered and the proposed
place of business and facilities therefor.
   D.   The application for a license shall contain the following information:
      1.   The applicant’s name, current address, telephone number, and date of
birth.
      2.   The name, address, and date of birth of all bodywork providers,
managers, and persons with supervisory authority employed or contracted by the
establishment.
      3.   Whether the applicant has had any business or liquor license denied,
revoked or suspended by the village, the State of Illinois, or any other state
or municipality and the reasons therefor.
      4.   Whether the applicant or any employee, massage therapist, bodywork
provider, manager, or person with supervisory authority has had any criminal
convictions, forfeiture of bond, or pleadings of nolo contendere, except minor
traffic violations, within the last five years.
      5.   Authorization for the chief of police or his designee to conduct a
background check and take fingerprints of the applicant and any manager or
person with supervisory authority.
      6.   A copy of the State of Illinois issued massage license for each
massage therapist that has been or is intended to be employed by the applicant
to provide massage services, or a copy of the certification or other written
documentation or proof of exemption for licensing as required by the Act.
      7.   A drawing or floor plan of the premises designating each room by its
purpose or the activity that will take place in each room.
      8.   If the premises is leased:
         a.   A copy of the lease. and any subleases, assignments or
acceptances in effect at the time of application;
         b.   The name, address, and telephone number of the legal owner of the
premises;
         c.   If the legal owner is not an individual, the name, address, and
telephone number of a representative or agent authorized to act on behalf of
the legal owner; and
         d.   If the premises is managed or supervised by someone other than
the legal owner thereof, the name, address, and telephone number of the person,
business, or entity who manages or supervises the premises.
      9.   If the applicant is a business:
         a.   The type of business or entity (i.e., sole proprietorship,
corporation, limited liability company, partnership. etc.);
         b.   The name of the business or entity, and all assumed names under
which the business or entity is conducted; and
         c.   The names, addresses, telephone numbers, and dates of birth of
all persons with management and supervisory authority of the business or
entity.
      10.   The information requested in subsections C.1, 3, 4, and 5 of this
section shall also be provided for the following individuals:
         a.   If the applicant is a sole proprietorship, for the individual
proprietor.
         b.   If the applicant is a partnership, for each general and limited
partner, for each individual who is a general partner of such general or
limited partnership, and for each individual who owns more than five percent
(5%) of such limited partnership.
         c.   If the applicant is a joint venture, for each joint venturer and
each individual who owns more than 5% of such joint venture.
         d.   If the applicant is a corporation, for each officer and director,
and if the corporation’s stock is publicly traded, for each shareholder owning
more than 5% of the outstanding stock in said corporation.
         e.   If the applicant is a limited liability company, for each manager
and member owning or holding more than a 5% membership interest.
   E.   If a change in any information required under this section occurs at
any time during a license period, the licensee shall file a written statement
with the village clerk indicating the nature and effective date of the change.
The change in information statement shall be filed no later than ten days after
the change(s) take effect. (Ord. 2025-1763, 6-3-2025)
4-10-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
   A.   The village clerk shall, within five days of the receipt of an
application for a bodywork establishment license, forward copies of such
application to the police department, the fire department, the department of
public works, and the building inspector. These departments shall, within 30
days of the receipt of a copy of the application, inspect the premises proposed
to be operated as a bodywork establishment and make written recommendations to
the village administrator, with a copy to the village clerk, concerning
compliance with the codes, laws, regulations, and ordinances that each
respective department administers.
   B.   Within 30 days of receipt of the recommendations of the aforesaid
departments, the village administrator shall determine whether to grant, deny,
or hold an application for further investigation, and shall notify the
applicant of his or her determination. The period of such additional
investigation shall not exceed an additional 30 days unless additional time is
agreed to by the applicant. Upon conclusion of any period of additional
investigation, the village administrator shall advise the applicant in writing
whether the application is granted or denied.
   C.   The village administrator shall grant the application unless he or she
finds:
      1.   That the operation of a bodyworks establishment, as proposed by the
applicant, would not comply with all applicable laws, including but not limited
to, the building, health, planning, housing, zoning, and fire codes of the
village; or
      2.   That the applicant and any other person who will be directly or
indirectly engaged in the ownership, management, or operation of the proposed
bodywork establishment has been convicted of or pled guilty to:
         a.   A felony;
         b.   A misdemeanor, an essential element of which involves (i)
dishonesty or fraud; (ii) sexual offenses as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-.01 et
seq.; (iii) the use of violence or force; or (iv) misconduct otherwise directly
related to the provision of bodywork or massage services or the operation of a
bodywork establishment;
         c.   An offense involving sexual misconduct with children; or
         d.   Prostitution, soliciting for a prostitute, keeping a place of
prostitution, pimping, or other similar offense opposed to decency and
morality; or
      3.   That the applicant has failed or refused to give information
relevant to the investigation of the application; submitted false, misleading,
or incomplete information; or has refused to submit to or cooperate with any
inspection required by this chapter; or
      4.   That the operation of the bodywork establishment as proposed by the
applicant would violate the provisions of this chapter; or
      5.   That the granting of the license would not be in the best interests
of the village, in which case the determination shall state the reason(s) for
such determination.
   D.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the village administrator may, at his/
her discretion, issue a license to any person convicted of or who has pled
guilty to a felony if the village administrator finds:
      1.   That such conviction occurred at least five years prior to the date
of application;
      2.   The offenses did not involve (i) dishonesty; (ii) sexual offenses as
defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-.01 et seq.; (iii) the use of violence or force; or
(iv) misconduct otherwise directly related to the provision of bodywork or
massage services or the operation of a bodywork establishment;
      3.   The applicant has had no subsequent convictions, and
      4.   The applicant has shown evidence of rehabilitation sufficient to
warrant the public trust.
   E.   Upon a determination by the village administrator granting the
application, the village clerk shall issue a license to maintain, operate, or
conduct a bodywork establishment pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 2025-1763, 6-
3-2025)
4-10-5: FACILITIES:
No bodyworks establishment shall be issued a license or be operated,
established, or maintained within the village unless said establishment
complies with each of the following minimum requirements:
   A.   Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths, and showers
shall be made waterproof with approved waterproof materials and shall be
installed in accordance with the building code of the Village of Peoria
Heights.
   B.   All massage tables, bathtubs, shower stalls, steam or bath areas,
lavatories, and floors shall have surfaces which may be readily disinfected.
   C.   Adequate bathing, dressing, locker, and toilet facilities shall be
provided for patrons to be served at any given time. In the event male and
female patrons are to be served simultaneously, separate bathing, dressing,
locker, toilet, and massage room facilities shall be provided for each sex.
Doors to dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing.
   D.   Separate toilet and lavatory facilities shall be maintained for
employees and staff.
   E.   The premises shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and
sterilizing non-disposable instruments and materials used in administering
massages. Such non-disposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected
after use on each patron.
   F.   Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations within the
premises and in accordance with applicable occupancy requirements.
   G.   Lavatories or washbasins shall provide both hot and cold running water
and shall be installed in the toilet room. Lavatories or washbasins shall be
provided with a soap dispenser and clean towels or paper towels.
   H.   All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms, and
all other physical facilities shall be maintained in good repair and in a clean
and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms, steam or
vapor cabinets, shower compartments, bathtubs, and toilet rooms shall be
thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. When carpeting is
used on the floors, it shall be kept clean and dry.
   I.   The premises shall be equipped with a service sink for custodial
service. (Ord. 2025-1763, 6-3-2025)
4-10-6: OPERATING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The premises of the licensed establishment shall be supervised at all
times when open for business by at least one person who is an owner or manager
of the business or who has supervisory authority with regard to the business.
The supervisor shall not violate, or permit others to violate, any applicable
provisions of this chapter. The violation of any provision of this chapter by
any agent or employee of the licensee shall constitute a violation by the
licensee.
   B.   Every portion of the licensed establishment, including appliances and
apparatus, shall be kept and operated in a clean and sanitary condition.
   C.   Reserved.
   D.   Sheets, towels, and other linens shall be available in sufficient
quantities to service each patron and shall be laundered after each use. Closed
cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean linen, towels, and
other materials used in connection with administering massages. All soiled
linens, towels, and other materials shall be kept in properly covered
containers or cabinets, which shall be kept separate from the clean storage
areas.
   E.   Oils, creams, lotions, or other preparations used in administering
massages shall be kept in clean, closed containers or cabinets.
   F.   All employees, managers, persons with supervisory authority, bodywork
providers, agents, and independent contractors shall wear clean, non-
transparent outer garments, which cover the sexual and genital areas while on
the licensed premises. Employees, bodywork providers, agents, and independent
contractors shall not disrobe, or offer or agree to disrobe, either wholly or
partially while in the presence of any patron receiving massage services.
   G.   The sexual or genital area of patrons must be covered by towels,
cloths, or undergarments when in the presence of an employee, manager, person
with supervisory authority, bodywork provider, agent, or independent contractor
of the licensed establishment.
   H.   No bodywork provider shall administer bodywork services to a patron
impaired by intoxicating liquor or drugs, nor shall any bodywork provider
administer bodywork services to a patron while impaired by intoxicating liquor
or drugs.
   I.   No bodywork provider shall administer bodywork services to a patron
exhibiting any skin fungus, skin infection, skin inflammation, or skin
eruption, unless a physician or nurse practitioner duly licensed by the State
of Illinois certifies in writing that such services maybe safely performed and
prescribing the conditions thereof.
   J.   Each bodywork provider shall wash his or her hands in hot running
water, using a proper soap or disinfectant before administering bodywork
services to any patron.
   K.   All licensees shall maintain, as a business record of the licensed
establishment:
      1.   A record of:
         a.   The date and time of all bodywork services performed at the
licensed premises;
         b.   The name of the bodywork provider administering the bodywork
services; and
         c.   The amounts received for bodywork services.
      2.   The record of the date, time, and service provided must be made
before services are initiated, and the record of the amount received for
services must be made at the time payment is rendered. All records shall be
kept for a period of at least one year and shall be made available in a format
that can be inspected at any reasonable time upon request by the village
administrator or the chief of police or their designees.
   L.   The main entrance to the licensed establishment where patrons and
potential customers are greeted shall be clearly visible from the outside and
shall have and maintain clear glass that is not painted over, darkened, or
otherwise blocked by cloth or any other obstruction.
   M.   A sign shall be posted in a prominent location near the main entrance
of the licensed establishment identifying the establishment as a bodywork
establishment and state the trade or business name as it appears on the
establishment’s license.
   N.   The hours of operation for bodywork establishments shall be limited to
the hours between 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.
   O.   No person shall reside or be allowed to remain overnight in the
licensed premises; provided, however, that if the licensed premises contains
living quarters that are properly zoned and authorized for such residential
use, the entrance to such living quarters shall be separate from the entrance
to the licensed establishment and shall not be accessible in any manner from
the interior of the licensed establishment. (Ord. 2025-1763, 6-3-2025)
4-10-7: SOLICITATIONS PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any employee, manager, person with supervisory
authority, bodywork provider, agent, or independent contractor of the licensed
