6-7-2: DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, unless the context otherwise
requires, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this subsection:
   CANNABIS: Shall have the meaning ascribed thereto in subsection
6-7-1A of this chapter.
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Shall have the meaning ascribed to it in section 102
of the Illinois controlled substances act, as if that definition were
incorporated herein.
   DELIVER OR DELIVERY: The actual, constructive or attempted transfer of
possession, with or without consideration, whether or not there is an agency
relationship.
   DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products and materials of any kind which
are peculiar to and marketed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating,
growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing,
processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing,
containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing
into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the
cannabis control act or the Illinois controlled substance act. The term
includes, but is not limited to:
      1.   Kits peculiar to and marketed for use in manufacturing, compounding,
converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis or a controlled
substance.
      2.   Isomerization devices peculiar to and marketed for use in increasing
the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled
substance.
      3.   Testing equipment peculiar to and marketed for private home use in
identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of cannabis
or controlled substances.
      4.   Diluents and adulterants peculiar to and marketed for cutting
cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons.
      5.   Objects peculiar to and marketed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or
otherwise introducing cannabis, cocaine, hashish or hashish oil into the human
body including, where applicable, the following items:
         a.   Water pipes.
         b.   Carburetion tubes and devices.
         c.   Smoking and carburetion masks.
         d.   Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials.
         e.   Carburetor pipes.
         f.   Electric pipes.
         g.   Air driven pipes.
         h.   Chillums.
         i.   Bongs.
         j.   Ice pipes or chillers.
      6.   Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is
for use in violation of this section. (Ord. 2007-1280, 4-17-2007)
   B.   Sale Or Delivery:
      1.   Prohibited: Any person who keeps for sale, offers for sale, or sells
or delivers for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia
commits an offense. (Ord. 2007-1280, 4-17-2007; amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   Nuisance Declared: Any store, place or premises from which or in
which any item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold
or delivered for any commercial consideration is declared to be a public
nuisance.
   C.   Possession Prohibited:
      1.   A person who knowingly possesses an item of drug paraphernalia with
the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing cannabis
or a controlled substance into the human body, or in preparing cannabis or a
controlled substance for that use, commits an offense.
      2.   In determining intent under subsection C1 of this section, the trier
of fact may take into consideration the proximity of the cannabis or a
controlled substance to drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis or a
controlled substance on the drug paraphernalia. (Ord. 2007-1280, 4-17-2007)
6-7-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be
punishable as provided in subsection
1-4-1D of this code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed upon each day said violation continues. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 8
MINORS
SECTION:
6-8-1: Curfew Regulations
6-8-2: Tobacco Products And Accessories Regulations
6-8-3: Truancy
6-8-1: CURFEW REGULATIONS:
   A.   Definitions: Whenever used in this section, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
   CURFEW HOURS: 1. Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on Saturday;
      2.   Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. on Sunday; and
      3.   Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday,
inclusive, and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
   EMERGENCY: An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state
that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a
fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring
immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life.
   ESTABLISHMENT: Any privately owned place of business operated for a profit
to which the public is invited including, but not limited to, any place of
amusement or entertainment.
   GUARDIAN: 1. A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person
of a minor; or
      2.   A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a
court.
   MINOR: Any person under seventeen (17) years of age.
   PARENT: A person who is:
      1.   A natural parent, adoptive parent, or stepparent of another person;
or
      2.   At least eighteen (18) years of age and authorized by a parent or
guardian to have the care and custody of a minor.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the
public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and
the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings,
transport facilities, and shops.
   REMAIN: To:
      1.   Linger or stay; or
      2.   Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer
or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises.
   SERIOUS BODILY INJURY: Bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of
death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss
or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ.
   B.   Offenses:
      1.   A minor commits a curfew offense when he or she remains in any
public place or on the premises of any establishment during curfew hours.
      2.   A parent or guardian of a minor or other person in custody or
control of a minor commits a curfew offense when he or she knowingly permits
the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment
during curfew hours.
   C.   Defenses: It is a defense to prosecution under subsection B of this
section that the minor was:
      1.   Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian or other person in
custody or control of the minor;
      2.   On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian,
without any detour or stop;
      3.   In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel;
      4.   Engaged in an employment activity or going to or returning home from
an employment activity, without any detour or stop;
      5.   Involved in an emergency;
      6.   On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the
residence of a next door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the
police department about the minor's presence;
      7.   Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational
activity supervised by adults and sponsored by a government or governmental
agency, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes
responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any
detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity
supervised by adults and sponsored by a government or governmental agency, a
civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the
minor;
      8.   Exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States
constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the
right of assembly; or
      9.   Married or had been married or is an emancipated minor under the
emancipation of minor's act.
   D.   Enforcement: Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a
law enforcement officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for
being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an
arrest under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an
offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances,
no defense in subsection C of this section is present. (2016 Code)
   E.   Penalties: Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall,
upon conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation; except, that neither a person who has
been made a ward of the court under the juvenile court act of 1987, nor that
person's legal guardian, shall be subject to any fine. In addition to or
instead of the fine imposed by this subsection, the court may order a parent,
legal guardian, or other person convicted of a violation of subsection B of
this section to perform community service as determined by the court; except,
that the legal guardian of a person who has been made a ward of the court under
the juvenile court act of 1987 may not be ordered to perform community service.
The dates and times established for the performance of community service by the
parent, legal guardian, or other person convicted of a violation of subsection
B of this section shall not conflict with the dates and times that the person
is employed in his or her regular occupation. (Ord. 1112, 1-21-1997; amd. 2016
Code)
6-8-2: TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND ACCESSORIES REGULATIONS:
   A.   Definitions: The following definitions shall apply to this section:
   MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   SMOKELESS TOBACCO: Any finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf tobacco that is
intended to be placed in the oral cavity.
   TOBACCO ACCESSORIES: Cigarette papers, pipes, and holders of smoking
materials of all types, designed primarily for the smoking or ingestion of
tobacco products or of substances made illegal under any statute or of
substances whose sale, gift, barter, or exchange is made unlawful under this
section.
   TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco, or tobacco in any
of its forms. (Ord. 1111, 1-21-1997)
   B.   Purchase By, Sales Or Delivery To Minors Prohibited:
      1.   No minor shall buy any tobacco product or tobacco accessory.
      2.   No person shall sell, buy for, distribute samples of or furnish any
tobacco products or tobacco accessories to any minor.
   C.   Possession By Minors Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any minor to
possess any tobacco product or tobacco accessory. Any minor found to be in
possession of any tobacco products or tobacco accessories shall be subject to
having such items removed from said minor's possession by any law enforcement
officer who has become aware of the possession of such items.
   D.   Use Of False Identification Prohibited: No minor in the furtherance or
facilitation of obtaining tobacco products or tobacco accessories shall display
or use false or forged identification card or transfer, alter, or deface an
identification card. (Ord. 1111, 1-21-1997; amd. 2016 Code)
   E.   Warning To Minors: Any person, firm, partnership, company, or
corporation operating a place of business where tobacco products and/or tobacco
accessories are sold or offered for sale shall post in a conspicuous place upon
the premises a sign upon which there shall be imprinted the following
statement:
SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR TOBACCO ACCESSORIES TO PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF
EIGHTEEN (18) YEARS OF AGE OR THE MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE TO PROCURE SUCH A
SALE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
(Ord. 1111, 1-21-1997)
   F.   Penalty: Any person convicted of any violation of this section shall be
fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation. (Ord. 1111, 1-21-1997; amd. 2016 Code)
6-8-3: TRUANCY:
   A.   Prohibited; Exemptions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18)
years enrolled in a public, private or parochial school and residing within the
corporate limits of the village to absent himself or herself from attendance at
school without parental permission. Any person who shall so absent himself or
herself shall be guilty of the offense of truancy and be subject to the penalty
hereinafter set forth.
      2.   Emergency or unforeseen absences due to illness or other causes
beyond the control of the person so absenting himself or herself from school
without parental permission shall not constitute truancy if permission for such
absence has substantially been obtained from the parent or legal guardian.
   B.   Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian: It is unlawful for a parent,
legal guardian or other person to knowingly permit a person in his custody or
control to violate subsection A1 of this section. (Ord. 1149, 6-15-1999)
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating subsection A1 of this section shall be
fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. Each day during which or on which any
person violates subsection A1 of this section shall be deemed a separate
offense. (Ord. 1149, 6-15-1999; amd. 2016 Code)

CHAPTER 1
GENERAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Scope
7-1-2: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
7-1-3: Penalty
7-1-1: SCOPE:
The provisions of this title shall apply to traffic upon all the public
streets, highways and alleys in the Village. (1914 Code § 10-57)
7-1-2: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., as
passed, approved, and amended is hereby adopted by reference by the Village of
Peoria Heights as if fully set out herein. In the event of any inconsistency
between the provisions of this title and any provisions of the Illinois Vehicle
Code, the terms of this title shall apply. (Ord. 2018-1559, 6-19-2018)
7-1-3: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate or fail to comply with any of
the provisions of this title or who shall control a vehicle which violates or
fails to comply with any of the provisions hereof shall be fined as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1914 Code § 10-58; amd. 2016 Code; Ord. 2018-1559, 6-19-
2018)
CHAPTER 2
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Definitions
7-2-2: Method Of Parking
7-2-3: Parking Vehicles With Expired Plates
7-2-4: Parking During Snowfall
7-2-5: Parking For Persons With Disabilities
7-2-6: Parking On Private Property
7-2-7: Parking Trailers, Boats Or Recreational Vehicles On Streets
7-2-7-1: Parking Of Vehicles With A Gross Weight In Excess Of Ten Thousand
Pounds
7-2-8: Parking Prohibitions And Restrictions In Specific Places
7-2-9: Twenty Four Hour Parking Prohibited
7-2-10: Loading And Unloading
7-2-11: Signs Posted
7-2-12: Lessors Of Visitor Vehicles
7-2-13: Enforcement; Responsibility For Violations
7-2-14: Exemption From Compliance With Certain Limitations On Parking
7-2-15: Portable Storage Units
7-2-16:    Temporary Dumpsters
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
   OPERATOR: Any person who is driving or is assuming physical control of a
vehicle.
   PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, joint stock association,
limited partnership partner, or any city or state subdivision thereof; and
includes any trustee, receiver, assignee or personal representative therefor.
   VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power,
and snowmobiles as defined in the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act 1 .
For the purposes of this chapter, unless otherwise prescribed, a device shall
be considered to be a vehicle until such time it either comes within the
definition of a "junk vehicle", as defined by Village ordinance, or a junking
certificate is issued for it. (Ord. 2004-1235, 11-16-2004; amd. 2016 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq.
7-2-2: METHOD OF PARKING:
   A.   Parallel Parking: Except when otherwise provided by a Village
ordinance, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one- way roadway shall be so
stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction
of authorized traffic movement, with its right hand wheels within twelve inches
(12") of the right hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of
the right hand shoulder, or with its left hand wheels within twelve inches
(12") of the left hand curb or as close as practicable to the left edge of the
left hand shoulder.
   B.   Angle Parking: Angle parking on any roadway is only permitted where
specifically permitted by Village ordinance; except, that angle parking shall
not be permitted on any Federal aid or State highway unless the Illinois
Department of Transportation has determined that the roadway is of sufficient
width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of
traffic. (Ord. 2004-1235, 11-16-2004)
7-2-3: PARKING VEHICLES WITH EXPIRED PLATES:
No person may stop, park, or leave standing upon a public street, highway, or
roadway a vehicle upon which is displayed an Illinois registration plate or
plates or registration sticker after the termination of the registration period
for which the registration plate or plates or registration sticker was issued
or after the expiration date set under section 3-414 or 3-414.1 of the Illinois
Motor Vehicle Code. (Ord. 2004-1235, 11-16-2004)
7-2-4: PARKING DURING SNOWFALL:
   A.   Declaration Of Snow Emergency: Whenever there is an excessive snow
accumulation or a forecast for two (2) to four (4) or more inches or when
weather conditions deem it necessary, it shall be within the discretion of the
Mayor or official designee, upon consultation with appropriate administrative
staff, to declare a weather/snow emergency.
   B.   No Parking On Snow Routes: In the event of such declaration, vehicular
parking shall be prohibited on certain village streets and highways designated
and posted as "emergency snow routes" to facilitate street clearing, proper
movement of vehicular traffic, emergency operations, or to protect life and/or
property as follows: Bellevue Place, Boulevard Avenue, Central Avenue, Columbus
Avenue, Cox Avenue, Glen Avenue, Glen Elm Drive, Kelly Avenue, Lake Avenue,
Moneta Avenue, Monroe Avenue, and Terrace Court.
   C.   Effect Of Declaration: Upon declaration, said emergency shall be in
effect for a minimum of twenty four (24) hours or until further notice.
Vehicles shall be removed from the above designated routes one hour after the
emergency is announced to take effect.
   D.   Enforcement: Any person, firm, or corporation who fails to comply with
the provisions of this section shall be subject to the issuance of a traffic
citation for illegal vehicular parking and possible towing of the vehicle at
the owner's expense. (Ord. 919, 11-20-1979; amd. 2016 Code)
7-2-5: PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
   A.   Parking Privileges: Vehicles displaying person with disabilities
identification devices or decals as issued by the secretary of state (including
person with disabilities parking permits, transporter of person with
disabilities parking permits, person with disabilities vehicle registration
plates and disabled veteran vehicle registration plates) may be parked at
specifically designated parking spaces for persons with disabilities within the
village, and may further park in conformity with sections 11-1301.1, 1301.2,
and 1301.3 of the Illinois vehicle code 1 . Nothing in this subsection,
however, shall be interpreted as permitting any vehicle to be parked in a
village owned parking lot or deck without paying the designated fee; nor shall
it be interpreted as permitting a vehicle to park at any metered parking space
which has a maximum time limit of thirty (30) minutes or less without paying
the required fee. A person to whom privileges were granted shall, at the
request of a police officer or any other person invested by law with authority
to direct, control or regulate traffic, present an identification card with a
picture as verification that the person is the person to whom the special
registration plates, special decal or device was issued.
   B.   Designation Of Spaces:
      1.   The board of trustees is authorized to determine and designate, in
accordance with the village schedule P or this section, places which shall be
reserved for parking for vehicles for persons with disabilities.
      2.   The owners or lessees of private property within the village are
hereby authorized to determine and designate, by proper signs, places which
shall be reserved for the parking of vehicles displaying persons with
disability parking devices as set forth in subsection A of this section.
   C.   Violations:
      1.   No vehicle shall be parked in a space designated for vehicles for
persons with disabilities unless such vehicle shall have displayed thereon a
person with disabilities parking device as set forth in subsection A of this
section.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for an individual with a vehicle displaying a
person with disabilities license plate or parking decal or device issued to a
disabled person to park in a space designated for persons with disabilities if
the individual is not the authorized holder of a person with disabilities
license plate or parking decal or device and is not transporting the authorized
holder of a person with disabilities license plate or parking decal to or from
the parking location and the person uses the person with disabilities license
plate or parking decal or device to exercise any privileges granted through the
person with disabilities license plates or parking decals as set forth in
subsection A of this section. (Ord. 2004-1234, 11-16-2004; amd. 2016 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1, 5/11-1301.2, 5/11-1301.3.
7-2-6: PARKING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   No motor vehicles, watercraft, trailers, recreational vehicles or
anything else of a vehicular nature may be parked in the front yard of any home
or business. "Front yard" shall be defined as that portion of the property even
with and/or in front of the primary structure on the property. If no primary
structure is located there, no vehicles can be parked there.
   B.   No paved surface may be added to a front yard or back yard, subsequent
to the effective date hereof, without approval from the Village Administrator
or his designee or the Code Enforcement Officer. (Ord. 2006-1270, 11-21-2006)
7-2-7: PARKING TRAILERS, BOATS OR RECREATIONAL VEHICLES ON STREETS:
No recreational vehicle may be parked on the street unless the parking is of a
temporary nature. No trailer, boat trailer or any vehicle, other than a
passenger car, truck, van or the like, may be parked on the street unless the
parking is of a temporary nature. "Temporary nature" shall be defined as a
twenty four (24) hour period, and no more than one 24-hour period per week. In
the event that such above named vehicle would require to be parked on the
street for longer than a twenty four (24) hour period, it will still be
considered as "temporary". A onetime permit for twenty five dollars ($25.00)
can be obtained for such temporary period, not to exceed two (2) weeks, after
review by the Code Enforcement Officer and/or the Village Administrator. (Ord.
2006-1270, 11-21-2006)
7-2-7-1: PARKING OF VEHICLES WITH A GROSS WEIGHT IN EXCESS OF TEN THOUSAND
POUNDS:
It shall be unlawful to stop or park motor vehicles with a gross weight in
excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds upon any street, road or highway in the
Village of Peoria Heights, Illinois, provided, however, that any such motor
vehicle may stop or park upon any road, highway or street for the sole purpose
of making a delivery or picking up a load for a period of time no longer than
is necessary to load, unload or deliver material but in no event for a period
in excess of thirty (30) minutes or for a period of time no longer than is
necessary to embark or discharge passengers. (Ord. 2018-1567, 8-21-2018)
7-2-8: PARKING PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS IN SPECIFIC PLACES:
   A.   Specific Streets; P Schedule:
      1.   It is hereby determined that, upon the basis of engineering, traffic
and police investigation as authorized by law, certain portions and areas along
or upon certain streets of the Village should be designated by the President
and Board of Trustees as no parking areas. The no parking areas upon those
streets or portions thereof are described in schedule P and hereinafter
designated as "no parking", "loading zone", or "restricted parking" locations
to be enumerated on said schedule by street location. It is hereby declared in
the interest of safety and public health that there shall be restricted parking
in the areas of those streets or portions thereof as described in schedule P
when appropriate signs are so erected in said areas giving notice thereof.
Schedule P shall be on file in the Office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2010-
1325, 3-16-2010)
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stop any vehicle
along or upon any roadway in the Village in any place designated as a
restricted parking area as set forth in schedule P. The operator, person in
possession, owner, or lessee of any said vehicle parked in violation of the
restricted areas as set forth in schedule P shall be subject to a fine and
penalty.
   B.   Additional Areas: It shall be unlawful for any person, operator, lessee
or owner of any motor vehicle to stop, stand or park a motor vehicle in
violation of any of the provisions of this subsection.
      1.   It shall be unlawful to stop, stand, or park:
         a.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street.
         b.   On a sidewalk.
         c.   Within an intersection.
         d.   On a crosswalk.
         e.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings.
         f.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
         g.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel.
         h.   On any railroad tracks.
         i.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping or parking,
other than parking or loading signs set forth in schedule P.
         j.   On any controlled access highway.
         k.   In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including
crossovers.
         l.   In a public parking area if the vehicle does not display a
current annual registration sticker or current temporary permit pending
registration.
      2.   Standing or parking a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except
momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers, is unlawful and prohibited as
follows:
         a.   In front of a public or private driveway.
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
         c.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
         d.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of
a roadway.
         e.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted).
         f.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
      3.   Parking a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for
the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or
passengers, is unlawful and prohibited as follows:
         a.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing.
         b.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
      4.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into
any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful.
(Ord. 2004-1235, 11-16-2004; amd. Ord. 2019-1596, 8-20-2019)
7-2-9: TWENTY FOUR HOUR PARKING PROHIBITED:
No vehicle of any kind or description, or any part of the same, shall be
permitted to stand or remain in any of the streets, avenues, alleys or other
public grounds of the Village for more than twenty four (24) consecutive hours.
(1914 Code § 18-15; amd. 2016 Code)
7-2-10: LOADING AND UNLOADING:
   A.   No vehicle shall stand backed up to the curb except when actually
loading or unloading. (1914 Code § 10-56; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   A vehicle waiting at the curb shall give place to a vehicle about to
load or unload. (1914 Code § 10-56)
7-2-11: SIGNS POSTED:
The Village may furnish, install and maintain proper signs for the enforcement
of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-1235, 11-16-2004)
7-2-12: LESSORS OF VISITOR VEHICLES:
   A.   Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to law and
who leases such vehicle to others, after receiving written notice of a
violation of this chapter involving such vehicle, shall, upon request, provide
such police officers as have authority of the offense, and the court having
jurisdiction thereof, with a written statement of the name and address of the
lessee at the time of such offense and the identifying number upon the
registration plates and registration sticker or stickers of such vehicle.
   B.   No person who is the lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease
agreement shall be liable for the violation of any parking or standing
regulation of this chapter or any other ordinance of the Village involving such
vehicle during the period of the lease; provided, that upon the request of the
appropriate authority received within one hundred twenty (120) days after the
violation occurred, the lessor provides, within sixty (60) days after such
receipt, the name and address of the lessee. The driver's license number of the
lessee may be subsequently individually requested by the appropriate authority
if needed for enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-1235, 11-16-2004)
7-2-13: ENFORCEMENT; RESPONSIBILITY FOR VIOLATIONS:
   A.   It is unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to park such vehicle upon
the street in violation of any sign where parking is heretofore or shall
hereafter be prohibited during the designated hours or at all times as the case
may be. Whenever any vehicle shall have been stopped, standing or parked in
violation of any provisions of this chapter, the operator of the motor vehicle
and/or the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be subject to
the penalty for such violation as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
   B.   Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of this chapter and the
operator or registered owner of the vehicle is not present, the Chief of Police
or any member of the Village of Peoria Heights Police Department observing such
violation may issue a citation and leave a copy thereof on the vehicle.
   C.   The Chief of Police or any member of the Village of Peoria Heights
Police Department is authorized, in his or her discretion, to remove or cause
the removal of any vehicle which is parked in violation of this chapter at the
registered owner's expense, if one or more of the following conditions exist:
      1.   The vehicle remains parked in violation of this chapter for more
than twenty four (24) consecutive hours following the issuance of a citation;
      2.   The vehicle has been issued three (3) or more citations for a
violation of this chapter and which are unpaid at the time of the violation at
issue; or
      3.   The vehicle has been issued three (3) or more citations for a
violation of this chapter within a thirty (30) day period prior to the
violation at issue.
   D.   The Police Department shall keep a record of each vehicle removed in
accordance with this section. The record shall include a description of the
vehicle, its license plate number, date and time of its removal, where it was
removed from, the location where it was removed to, and the name and address of
its owner or operator, if known.
   E.   Within twenty four (24) hours after a vehicle is removed pursuant to
this section, the Village shall notify, certified mail, return receipt
requested, the owner of record at his or her last known address, as indicated
by the vehicle's registration, of his or her right to request a hearing before
a Hearing Officer that will be conducted to determine whether the subject
vehicle is eligible for removal pursuant to this section. However, no such
notice need be sent to the owner of record if the owner is personally served
with the notice within twenty four (24) hours after the vehicle is removed and
the owner acknowledges receipt of the notice in writing. The written notice
shall state the penalties that may be imposed if no hearing is requested,
including that a vehicle not released by payment of a fine plus any and all
towing and storage fees may be sold or disposed of by the Village in accordance
with applicable law.
   F.   Any vehicle removed under this section shall be released prior to a
hearing to any person entitled to lawful possession of said vehicle upon
payment of a fine plus any and all towing and storage fees. If a person
entitled to lawful possession of said vehicle does not pay the applicable fine
plus any and all towing and storage fees within thirty (30) days after the
vehicle is removed or after the Hearing Officer's written determination,
whichever is later, then such vehicle may be disposed of in accordance with the
procedure set forth for disposal of unclaimed or abandoned vehicles as provided
by law.
   G.   The owner of record seeking a hearing under this section must file a
written request for a hearing with the Chief of Police at the Peoria Heights
Village Hall, 4901 N. Prospect Road, Peoria Heights, Illinois, no later than
fifteen (15) days after the notice was mailed or otherwise given under this
section.
A hearing shall be scheduled and held, unless continued for good cause by order
of the Hearing Officer, no later than thirty (30) days after the request for a
hearing has been filed.
All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at
the hearing. At the hearing, the formal rules of evidence shall not apply, and
hearsay evidence shall be admissible.
If, after the hearing, the Hearing Officer determines by a preponderance of the
evidence that the vehicle was used in violation of this chapter, the Hearing
Officer shall enter an order requiring the vehicle to continue to be impounded
until the owner pays the applicable fine plus any and all towing and storage
fees. If the Hearing Officer determines that the vehicle was not in violation
of this chapter, he or she shall order the return of the vehicle to the owner
of record.
For the purposes of this section, the Hearing Officer shall be a licensed
attorney who is not an employee of the Village. (Ord. 2018-1536, 1-2-2018)
7-2-14: EXEMPTION FROM COMPLIANCE WITH CERTAIN LIMITATIONS ON PARKING:
   A.   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to approve requests for
exemptions from compliance with certain limitations on parking on public
streets but only under the following circumstances:
      1.   The person seeking an exemption resides adjacent to a public street
subject to limitations on the hours during which vehicles may be parked on such
adjacent street, but such limitations do not prohibit parking at all times.
      2.   The person seeking an exemption has insufficient space at his or her
place of residence to park all vehicles utilized by persons living at the
residence on an improved driveway.
   B.   An approved exemption shall allow parking only on the public street
adjacent to the residence of the person requesting the exemption and then only
during hours when parking would otherwise be prohibited. An exemption shall not
apply to any other rule or regulation governing the parking of vehicles.
   C.   No more than two (2) vehicles may be parked on the public street under
authority of any such exemption at any one time.
   D.   The Chief of Police shall grant such an exemption through a letter
signed by the Chief of Police which describes the exemption.
   E.   The Chief of Police shall revoke an exemption if he finds that the
recipient no longer qualifies for the exemption because of some change in
circumstances. (Ord. 2017-1529, 11-28-2017)
7-2-15: PORTABLE STORAGE UNITS:
   A.   For purposes of this Section, portable storage unit means a large
container, storage unit, parking crate or other portable structure (such as,
but not limited to PODS), which is transportable and is designed and used for
the temporary storage of household goods, personal items and other materials
used in moving from one place to another.
   B.   Portable storage units shall be allowed within the Village subject to
the following:
      1.   Portable storage units shall not be placed on Village-owned property
or public right of way.
      2.   The property on which the portable storage unit is placed shall be
occupied by a principal building.
      3.   Portable storage units shall only be allowed on paved surfaces and
shall only be allowed for a period not to exceed 60 days in any one-year
period.
(Ord. 2022-1683, 7-19-2022)
7-2-16: TEMPORARY DUMPSTERS:
   A.   For purposes of this Section, Temporary Dumpster means a large
container designed for the receiving, transporting and dumping of waste
materials on a temporary basis during demolition or construction projects. The
term “temporary dumpster” does not include garbage receptacles used for normal
waste collection services provided by a licensed waste hauler on a regularly
scheduled basis.
   B.   Temporary Dumpsters shall be allowed within the Village subject to the
following:
      1.   Temporary Dumpsters shall not be placed on Village-owned property or
public right of way.
      2.   The property on which the temporary dumpster is placed shall be
occupied by a principal building.
      3.   No litter, rubbish, debris, or construction materials may extend
beyond the height and width of the temporary dumpster; all items must be
contained within the temporary dumpster.
      4.   Temporary dumpsters shall only be allowed on paved surfaces.
      5.   Temporary dumpsters shall only be allowed for a period not to exceed
sixty (60) days in any one-year period. Upon written request from the property
owner, the Chief of Police in his discretion may grant an extension if the
property owner is diligently pursuing removal activities.
(Ord. 2024-1728, 4-2-2024)
CHAPTER 3
SKATEBOARDS, ROLLER SKATES, BICYCLES AND MOTORIZED SCOOTERS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Definitions
7-3-2: Prohibited Acts
7-3-3: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
7-3-4: Yield Right Of Way
7-3-5: Signs Posted
7-3-6: Application Of Provisions
7-3-7: Enforcement
7-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions apply to this chapter:
   BICYCLE: A device with two (2) or three (3) wheels in tandem, propelled by
pedals and having handlebars and a saddlelike seat.
   BUSINESS CENTER: An area where there is located the privately owned real
property upon which a business/commercial development is situated, which
development is open to the general public and primarily devoted to retail sales
and services from shops and stores situated therein, although, it may also
contain some offices and eating places, as well as other accessory uses
compatible with a retail sales shopping area.
   MINOR: A person who has not obtained the age of eighteen (18) years. A
person who has obtained the age of eighteen (18) years is of legal age for all
purposes under this chapter.
   MOTORIZED SCOOTER: A scooter or scooter cart which is motorized and powered
by a battery or similar device to be used only by a disabled person.
   PEDESTRIAN WALKWAYS: Those areas of walkways in the business center which
are open to the general public exclusively for persons who are walking or
otherwise afoot or in wheelchairs.
   PRIVATELY OWNED ROADWAYS AND PARKING AREAS: Those areas in the business
district which are open to the general public for vehicular traffic and
parking, and for persons who are walking or otherwise afoot or in wheelchairs.
   PUBLIC PLACE: All publicly owned buildings and grounds and all privately
owned buildings and grounds which are customarily open to the public.
   PUBLIC WAY: Any and all streets, alleys, sidewalks, and rights of way in the
village of Peoria Heights.
   ROLLER SKATE OR IN-LINE SKATE: A shoe or similar device worn on the foot
that has wheels or a cylindrical device affixed to its sole and which would
enable the wearer to skate or propel oneself in sidewalks, gutters, streets or
hard surfaces.
   SCOOTER: A platform or footboard mounted between two (2) wheels controlled
by an upright steering handle and which is propelled by human power and/or
motorized power.
   SIDEWALK AND STREET: Refer to any public sidewalk or street within the
specified business district or other specified public property.
   SKATEBOARD: A mechanism on wheels, often resembling wheels on roller skates,
which are fastened to a platform, commonly constructed to accommodate a
standing person. Skateboards are normally propelled by the operator pushing off
the ground with one foot or by force of gravity.
   SPECIFIED BUSINESS CENTER: That area beginning at the intersection of Glen
Avenue and Prospect Road, then proceeding one block east on the north side of
Glen Avenue to the intersection of Glen Avenue and Columbus Avenue and then
proceeding southerly along the west side of Columbus Avenue to the intersection
of Columbus Avenue with Marietta Avenue and then proceeding west on the north
side of Marietta Avenue to the east side of the intersection of Marietta Avenue
and Prospect Road, then proceeding north on Prospect Road to Kelly Drive and
then west on the south side of Kelly Drive until its western termination point
and then north on Kelly Drive to the north side of Kelly Drive and then east on
the north side of Kelly Drive to Prospect Road; then north on Prospect Road to
Seiberling Avenue, then west on Seiberling Avenue until it terminates at the
private property line at its westerly edge and then north along the westerly
edge along Seiberling Avenue to the north side of Seiberling Avenue and then
east to Prospect Road; then north on the west side of Prospect Road to the
south side of Duryea Avenue, then west on the south side of Duryea Avenue to
Atlantic Avenue and then north on the east side of Atlantic Avenue to Glen
Avenue and then east on the south side of Glen Avenue to the intersection with
Prospect Road, being the point of beginning. The "specified business center"
shall include, as to any public way described in the "specified business
center", all of the public sidewalks contiguous to a public street that are
described in the "specified business center".
   TOWER PARK/VILLAGE HALL AREA: An area beginning at the intersection of Glen
Avenue with Prospect Road then proceeding west along the north side of Glen
Avenue to Park Avenue then north along the west side of Park Avenue to the
intersection with the north line of Kingman Avenue, then east on the north side
of Kingman Avenue to the intersection with Euclid Avenue; then westerly along
the southwesterly side of Euclid Avenue to where the extended line of the north
side of Park Place intersects with the north line of Euclid Avenue, then
southeasterly along the northeasterly line of Euclid Avenue to the intersection
with the north line of Kingman Avenue, then easterly along the north line of
Kingman Avenue to the intersection with the west line of Prospect Road and then
south along the west line of Prospect Road to the intersection with Glen
Avenue, being the place of beginning. The "Tower Park/village hall area" shall
include, as to any public way described in the "Tower Park/village hall area",
all of the public sidewalks contiguous to a public street that is described in
the "Tower Park/village hall area". (Ord. 2003-1212, 4-1-2003)
7-3-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to participate or engage in any of the
following acts:
   A.   Ride, propel or in any manner operate a skateboard, scooter, roller
skate, in-line skate, bicycle or similar self- propelled device upon any public
way, public street, public sidewalk, public alley or public place located
within the specified business center area or Tower Park/village hall area.
   B.   No person shall ride, propel or in any manner operate a skateboard,
scooter, roller skate, in-line skate, bicycle or similar self-propelled device
in the specified business center and on, along or over any pedestrian walkway,
privately owned roadway or parking area situated within a business center
located anywhere within the village where a sign has been posted prohibiting
such activity.
   C.   No person riding upon a skateboard, bicycle, scooter and/or using
roller skates or in-line skates or similar self- propelled device shall go upon
any roadway or sidewalk in such a manner as to endanger the safety of the
skateboard, bicycle or scooter rider, and/or roller skater, in-line skater or
pedestrians. When operating a skateboard, scooter, bicycle, roller skates, in-
line skates or similar self-propelled device upon any street, a skateboard,
bicycle or scooter rider and/or roller skater or in-line skater, or anyone
using a similar device, shall ride with the flow of traffic and ride as close
to the curb as possible and/or shall not restrict the flow of traffic.
   D.   No person shall operate a skateboard, scooter, roller skates, bicycle,
in-line skates or similar self-propelled device upon a street or sidewalk
during the hours between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before
sunrise without wearing a reflective device on both the front and back of the
skateboard, bicycle or scooter rider and/or roller skate or in-line skate user.
   E.   Any person riding or operating on a skateboard, scooter, roller skates,
bicycle, in-line skates or similar self-propelled device shall not attach the
same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. (Ord. 2003-1212, 4-1-
2003)
   F.   1. No person shall ride, propel or in any manner operate a skateboard,
scooter, roller skates, in-line skates, bicycle, or similar self-propelled
device on any private property or within a specified business center where
signs have been posted at the entrance or displayed properly on the property
prohibiting the use of skateboards, roller skates, in-line skates, scooters,
bicycles or similar self-propelled device and has accomplished the following:
         a.   Posted a sign, as described below, along each exterior entrance
to a shopping center, which is in plain view of pedestrians and motorists.
Additional signs as described below may be posted within the interior of the
shopping center. These signs shall be continually maintained by the owner or
manager of the private property. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of
the private property to erect a sign of prohibition in conformity with this
chapter.
         b.   Delivered a written notification to the chief of police, not less
than twenty four (24) hours prior to posting the signs described below, that
invokes the provisions of this chapter as of a certain date which shall be
specified in the notice.
      2.   The manager or owner of the private property may withdraw the sign
and the property from the provisions of this chapter by removing the signs
required by this chapter and notifying the chief of the police in writing of
such withdrawal. The manager or owner shall deliver a written notification to
the chief of police, not less than twenty four (24) hours prior to posting the
signs as described in this subsection, that invokes the provision of this
section, as of a date certain, which shall be specified in the notice. (Ord.
2003-1212, 4-1-2003; amd. 2016 Code)
7-3-3: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Any person operating a skateboard, scooter, roller skates, in-line
skates, bicycle or similar self-propelled device shall obey the instructions of
official traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to
vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
   B.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left
or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a skateboard, scooter, roller
skates, in-line skates, bicycle or similar self-propelled device shall disobey
the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the
skateboard, scooter or bicycle and/or removes said roller skates or in-line
skates or similar device to make any such turn, in which event, such person
shall obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. (Ord. 2003-1212, 4-1-
2003)
7-3-4: YIELD RIGHT OF WAY:
Whenever a person is riding a skateboard, bicycle or scooter and/or using
roller skates or in-line skates, such person shall yield the right of way to
any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing
such pedestrian, so as not to endanger the safety of the pedestrian. (Ord.
2003-1212, 4-1-2003)
7-3-5: SIGNS POSTED:
   A.   The chief of police is authorized to erect signs on any sidewalk,
roadway, public way or public place prohibiting the riding of skateboards,
bicycles or scooters or the use of roller skates or in-line skates or similar
self-propelled devices by any such person as prohibited in this chapter, and
when such signs are in place, no person shall disobey them. Any sign
prohibiting the use of skateboards, scooters, bicycles, roller skates, in-line
skates or similar self- propelled devices provided in this chapter shall state
"Use Of Skateboards, Scooters, Roller Skates, In-Line Skates, Bicycles Or
Similar Devices Are Prohibited", and below that "Village Of Peoria Heights,
Ordinance No. 2003-1212". The letters of prohibition shall be two inches (2")
in height and shall be printed in black with white background. The sign shall
not exceed two hundred eighty (280) square inches in area. (Ord. 2003-1212, 4-
1-2003; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Signs posted on privately owned roadways and parking ways prohibiting
the use of skateboards, scooters, bicycles, roller skates, and in-line skates
as prohibited by this chapter shall conform to this section. It shall be the
responsibility of the owner of the private property to erect a sign of
prohibition in conformity with this section. (Ord. 2003-1212, 4-1-2003)
7-3-6: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   This chapter is applicable to any person who operates a skateboard,
scooter, roller skates, in-line skates, bicycle or similar self-propelled
device in or on any public way, public place, Tower Park/village hall area,
specified business center area, or any area, sidewalk, street or property in
which the use of such devices are prohibited by this chapter.
   B.   The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward under the age of
eighteen (18) shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to
violate any of the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   This chapter shall not apply to a disabled person operating a motorized
scooter in the prohibited areas as set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 2003-1212,
4-1-2003)
7-3-7: ENFORCEMENT:
Any village police officer who observes any person violating any of the
provisions of this chapter is authorized to seize the offender's skateboard,
roller skates, bicycle, scooter, in-line skates or other similar recreational
devices and to hold same in the village police station. In the event of such
seizure, the offender, if an adult, may secure the return of the article after
twenty four (24) hours have elapsed since the seizure. In the case of a minor,
the articles seized may be returned only to the parent or guardian of such
minor offender, after twenty four (24) hours have elapsed since the seizure.
(Ord. 2003-1212, 4-1-2003)
CHAPTER 4
NEIGHBORHOOD ELECTRIC VEHICLES
SECTION:
7-4-1: Definition
7-4-2: Restricted Operation Generally
7-4-3: Persons With Disabilities; Permit Requirements
7-4-4: Insurance Requirements
7-4-5: Operation Regulations
7-4-6: Required Equipment
7-4-7: Signs Posted
7-4-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, "neighborhood electric vehicle" means a self-
propelled, electronically powered, four-wheeled motor vehicle which is capable
of attaining in one mile a speed of more than twenty (20) miles per hour, but
not more than twenty five (25) miles per hour, and which conforms to federal
regulations under 49 CFR part 571.500. (Ord. 2005-1242, 7-5-2005)
7-4-2: RESTRICTED OPERATION GENERALLY:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any
person to drive or operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on any street or
highway under the jurisdiction of the village. (Ord. 2005-1245, 8-16-2005)
7-4-3: PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES; PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Request For Exemption Permit: Subject to the limitations set forth in
this chapter, any person with disabilities 1 , with a valid Illinois driver's
license issued in his or her name by the secretary of state of the state of
Illinois may request the village board to operate a neighborhood electric
vehicle on any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the village where
the posted speed limit is thirty five (35) miles per hour or less. An
authorized neighborhood electric vehicle is not prohibited from crossing a road
or street at an intersection where the road or street has a posted speed limit
of thirty five (35) miles per hour or more, unless such crossing is prohibited
in this chapter or in any resolution or permit issued under this chapter.
   B.   Review Of Request; Decision: Any permit request will be reviewed by the
village board, and based upon the volume, speed and character of the traffic on
the roadway, the village board will decide whether a neighborhood electric
vehicle can operate safely on the roadway and that the public safety will not
be jeopardized.
   C.   Contents Of Permit: Any permit granted by the village board to operate
a neighborhood electric vehicle on roadways of the village will specifically
designate the portions of the roadways where the neighborhood electric vehicle
may be operated.
   D.   Restrictions On Permit: This section shall not be construed as
permitting or granting any person operating a neighborhood electric vehicle to
drive upon any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the city of Peoria,
the county of Peoria, the Peoria park district or any other municipality or to
drive upon or cross any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the
Illinois department of transportation.
   E.   Physician's Statement Required: Prior to being granted any permit to
operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on any street or roadway under the
jurisdiction of the village, the person requesting a permit to operate a
neighborhood electric vehicle shall provide the village board with a signed,
written statement from a physician, licensed to practice medicine in the state
of Illinois, to the effect that the operator is able to safely operate the
neighborhood electric vehicle upon the roadways of the village in a fashion
that would not be inimical to the public safety or the safety of the operator
or his/her passengers.
   F.   Term Of Permit; Renewal: A permit issued pursuant to this section shall
be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. A permit may be
reissued upon the reapplication and compliance with the provisions of this
chapter by the applicant and after review by the village board.
   G.   Permit Fee: A permit fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid
to the village clerk before any permit is issued. (Ord. 2005-1245, 8-16-2005)
 
Notes
1 1. As defined in 625 ILCS 5/1-159.1.
7-4-4: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
The neighborhood electric vehicle, driver and passengers shall be covered with
either automobile insurance to the extent required by state law or by
comprehensive general liability insurance with a combined single limit of two
hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00). Written proof of the insurance
coverage must be filed with the village administrator prior to permission being
granted to operate a neighborhood electric vehicle in the village. (Ord. 2005-
1245, 8-16-2005)
7-4-5: OPERATION REGULATIONS:
When on a street or highway under the jurisdiction of the village, a
neighborhood electric vehicle shall be operated in accordance with the
following regulations:
   A.   The neighborhood electric vehicle shall have its headlights and
taillamps lighted at all times.
   B.   Any person operating a neighborhood electric vehicle, as authorized in
this chapter, shall travel on the street or highway in the same direction as
traffic and as near the right side of the roadway as possible.
   C.   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any person operating a
neighborhood electric vehicle, pursuant to a permit, on streets or roadways
under the jurisdiction of the village shall obey any and all traffic
regulations set forth in either any ordinance of the village or in the Illinois
vehicle code. (Ord. 2005-1245, 8-16-2005)
7-4-6: REQUIRED EQUIPMENT:
No neighborhood electric vehicle may be operated on a street or highway under
the jurisdiction of the village unless, at a minimum, the vehicle conforms to
the federal regulations under 49 CFR part 571.500, and it has the following
additional safety equipment:
   A.   Brakes.
   B.   Steering apparatus.
   C.   Tires.
   D.   Rearview mirror.
   E.   Red reflectorized warning devices on the front and rear.
   F.   A slow moving emblem, as required of other vehicles by 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/12-709, on the rear of the neighborhood electric vehicle.
   G.   A headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of at
least five hundred feet (500') to the front.
   H.   A taillamp that emits a red light visible from a distance of at least
one hundred feet (100') from the rear.
   I.   Brake lights.
   J.   Turn signals.
   K.   Seat belts for driver and all passengers. (Ord. 2005-1242, 7-5-2005)
7-4-7: SIGNS POSTED:
After the village board determines that a neighborhood electric vehicle may
safely operate on a roadway in the village and adopts a resolution authorizing
the operation on the village streets, appropriate signs shall be posted. (Ord.
2005-1245, 8-16-2005)
CHAPTER 5
IMPOUNDMENT AND TOWING OF VEHICLES
SECTION:
7-5-1: Immediate Seizure And Impoundment Of Vehicles Used In Commission Of
Offenses
7-5-1-1: Offenses Leading To Vehicle Seizure And Impoundment
7-5-1-2: Authority Of Officers To Impound
7-5-1-3: Notice Of Impoundment
7-5-1-4: Administrative Fee; Release And Disposition Of Vehicle
7-5-1-5: Preliminary Hearing
7-5-1-6: Final Hearing
7-5-2: Towing Of Vehicles As Requested Or Ordered By Village
7-5-2-1: Authorized Towing Companies
7-5-2-2: Insurance Requirements
7-5-2-3: Duties And Requirements Of Towing Companies
7-5-2-4: Removal From Towing List
7-5-2-5: Solicitation Of Business By Towing Companies Prohibited
7-5-2-6: Towing And Storage Fees
7-5-1: IMMEDIATE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES USED IN COMMISSION OF
OFFENSES:
7-5-1-1: OFFENSES LEADING TO VEHICLE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:

be subject to seizure and impoundment under this section
