(Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-1-2: AUTHORITY OF OFFICERS TO IMPOUND:
When an officer has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject
to seizure and impound as listed in section
7-5-1-1 of this chapter, the officer shall:
   A.   Notify the on duty supervisor, or if no supervisor is on duty, notify
the next supervisor that is on duty of the seizure and impoundment and the
nature of the offense.
   B.   Inventory and provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility
listed on the towing list as provided in section
7-5-2 of this chapter. If the vehicle is towed to a location not on the village
towing list, the officer shall notify the person taking possession of the
vehicle that it is to be held until the village police department authorizes
its release.
   C.   When practical, the officer shall allow the removal of personal
property from the vehicle prior to towing if the property is not needed for
evidence, subject to forfeiture or otherwise needed to be maintained by the
police. Officers generally will not wait at the scene of any seizure to allow
the removal of personal property or the summoning of persons to remove
property. Persons under arrest will generally not be allowed to remove property
prior to their release.
   D.   Prepare a written police report, notice of seizure (when immediately
deliverable) and tow report, when practical, prior to ending his or her shift.
The preparation of the police report allows for the conduct of a preliminary
hearing, supervisory review and review by the evidence custodian for possible
release of personal property. The report shall state whether the vehicle or
property contained therein is subject to forfeiture or is to be held for any
other reason. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-1-3: NOTICE OF IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Immediately upon seizure of the vehicle pursuant to this section
7-5-1, the officer shall notify the person who is found to be in control of the
vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a person, of the
fact of the vehicle's seizure and of the vehicle owner's right to request a
preliminary hearing as provided in this section
7-5-1. When no person is present to receive said notification, officers shall
make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner of record.
   B.   Within ten (10) days after a vehicle is seized and impounded pursuant
to this section
7-5-1, the village shall notify, by certified mail, return receipt requested,
the owner of record at his or her last known address, as indicated by the
vehicle's registration, of his or her right to request a final hearing before
the hearing officer that will be conducted to determine whether the subject
vehicle is eligible for impoundment pursuant to this section
7-5-1. However, no such notice need be sent to the owner of record if the owner
is personally served with the notice within ten (10) days after the vehicle is
impounded and the owner acknowledges receipt of the notice in writing.
The written notice as required in this subsection B shall state the penalties
that may be imposed if no hearing is requested, including that a vehicle not
released by payment of the penalty, fees and remaining towing/storage fees may
be sold or disposed of by the village in accordance with applicable law. (Ord.
2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-1-4: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE; RELEASE AND DISPOSITION OF VEHICLE:
   A.   A vehicle impounded under this section
7-5-1 shall be released prior to hearing to a person entitled to lawful
possession of said vehicle upon payment to the police agency of a fee of five
hundred dollars ($500.00), plus any and all towing and storage charges. The fee
set forth in this subsection will be refunded by the village in the event that,
upon final hearing as provided in section
7-5-1-6 of this chapter, the hearing officer determines that the vehicle was
not used in the commission of a violation as set forth in section
7-5-1-1 of this chapter. Under such circumstance, the vehicle shall be released
from impoundment to its owner. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this section
7-5-1, whenever a person, corporation, or business entity with a valid lien or
valid security interest against a vehicle impounded under this section
7-5-1 has commenced foreclosure proceedings, possession of the vehicle shall be
given to the person or agent for said entity with a valid lien, to refund to
the village the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale, less any amounts
necessary to pay all lienholders of record, up to the total amount of penalties
and fees imposed under this chapter.
   C.   If a person entitled to lawful possession does not redeem the impounded
vehicle within thirty (30) days after the vehicle is impounded or after the
hearing officer's written determination, whichever is later, then such vehicle
shall be disposed of in accordance with the procedure set forth for disposal of
unclaimed or abandoned vehicles as provided by law. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-1-5: PRELIMINARY HEARING:
   A.   Whenever the owner of a vehicle seized pursuant to this section
7-5-1 requests in writing, within twelve (12) hours after the seizure, and hand
delivered to the Peoria Heights police department, 4901 N. Prospect Road,
Peoria Heights, Illinois, a preliminary hearing on probable cause, a hearing
officer appointed by the village shall conduct at the village hall such
preliminary hearing within seventy two (72) hours of the seizure, excluding
Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.
   B.   All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the preliminary hearing. The formal rules of evidence will not apply
at the hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible.
   C.   If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines that there is
probable cause to believe that the vehicle was used in the commission of any
crime or violation described in section
7-5-1-1 of this chapter, the hearing officer shall order the continued
impoundment of the vehicle as provided in this section
7-5-1 unless the owner of the vehicle posts with the village a cash bond of
five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus fees for towing and storing of the vehicle
as provided in subsection
7-5-1-4A of this chapter. If the hearing officer determines that there is no
such probable cause, the vehicle will be returned without penalty or other
fees.
   D.   For purposes of this section, the hearing officer shall be a licensed
attorney who is not an employee of the village. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-1-6: FINAL HEARING:
   A.   The owner of record seeking a hearing must file a written request for a
hearing with the village chief of police at the Peoria Heights village hall,
4901 N. Prospect Road, Peoria Heights, Illinois, no later than fifteen (15)
days after the notice was mailed or otherwise given under section
7-5-1-3 of this chapter.
   B.   The hearing shall be scheduled and held, unless continued for good
cause by order of the hearing officer, no later than forty five (45) days after
the request for a hearing has been filed.
   C.   All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the
hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible.
   D.   If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a
preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used in the commission of
any of the violations described in section
7-5-1-1 of this chapter, the hearing officer shall enter an order requiring the
vehicle to continue to be impounded until the owner pays a penalty of five
hundred dollars ($500.00), plus fees for towing and storage of the vehicle as
provided in subsection
 7-5-1-4A of this chapter. The penalty and fees shall be a debt due and owing
the village. However, if a cash bond has been posted, the bond shall be applied
to the penalty. If the hearing officer determines that the vehicle was not used
in commission of such a violation, he or she shall order the return of the
vehicle or the fee as provided in subsection
7-5-1-4A of this chapter.
   E.   For purposes of this section, the hearing officer shall be a licensed
attorney who is not an employee of the village. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-2: TOWING OF VEHICLES AS REQUESTED OR ORDERED BY VILLAGE:
7-5-2-1: AUTHORIZED TOWING COMPANIES:
   A.   Towing List: The chief of police shall maintain a "towing list"
containing the names of four (4) qualified towing companies as determined by
the chief of police to respond to requests for the towing of vehicles made by
the village police department.
   B.   Application For Placement On Towing List: Those towing companies
wishing to be considered for placement on the towing list shall submit an
application to the village police department within thirty (30) days of the
effective date hereof. Those towing companies who previously submitted an
application pursuant to ordinance 2005-1251 shall be considered for placement
on the towing list without the refiling of an application.
   C.   Four Companies Chosen; Remainder On File: The chief of police shall
consider the applications of all towing companies submitted and shall select
the four (4) towing companies which, in his judgment, are most qualified for
inclusion on the towing list. The applications of those towing companies not
placed on the towing list shall be placed on file and held by the village
police department. The decision of the chief of police regarding selections for
the towing list shall be final.
   D.   Required Information On Towing List: The name and phone number of each
of the four (4) selected towing companies shall be placed on the towing list,
which shall be utilized in all cases in which a vehicle is to be towed from a
public way or public property or from any private property at the request or
direction of the village police department. Towing companies not on the towing
list shall not be used unless all companies on the towing list are unavailable.
   E.   Selection Of Towing Company To Call: The names on the towing list shall
be selected on a rotating basis; that is, the name shall be selected which next
succeeds the last towing company called for towing services. However, the chief
of police is authorized to use towing companies out of sequence where proximity
to the vehicle to be removed and estimated response time make it more practical
to do so, or where the size or weight of the vehicle to be removed requires the
use of specialized equipment, or when circumstances, in the judgment of the
chief of police, make such action practical. In the event that a car owner
requests that a particular towing company be used, that company may be used,
and such use shall not affect the towing company's place in the rotation of use
under this section
7-5-2.
   F.   Selection Of New Company: Whenever a towing company is removed from the
towing list, the chief of police shall select from the applications on file,
the towing company which, in his judgment, is most qualified to be added to the
towing list. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-2-2: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Each listed towing company shall maintain the following insurance
policies:
      1.   Garage Keeper's Policy: A garage keeper's legal liability policy
covering fire, theft, windstorm, vandalism and explosion in the amount of fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00), and providing that each vehicle suffering damage
being deemed a separate claim.
      2.   Garage Liability Policy: A garage liability policy covering the
operation of the owner's business, equipment or other vehicles for any bodily
injury or property damage. This policy shall be in the minimum amount of two
hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for any one person injured or
killed and a minimum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for more
than one person killed or injured in any accident, as well as an additional
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage.
   B.   Each policy required under this section must contain an endorsement by
the carrier providing ninety (90) days' notice to both the village and the
insured in the event of any change in coverage under the policy. (Ord. 2008-
1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-2-3: DUTIES AND REQUIREMENTS OF TOWING COMPANIES:
   A.   All tow trucks shall be equipped with warning lights and other
equipment required under state law and have working two-way communications
radio equipment on the same frequency as a base station located at the point
where calls are received.
   B.   The towing company shall provide continuous twenty four (24) hour per
day service each day of the year, and there shall be an attendant available at
all times for the purpose of receiving calls and receiving and releasing stored
vehicles.
   C.   The towing company shall assume all liability and shall indemnify and
hold harmless the village from any such liability for damages sustained by
vehicles while being towed or stored and for all personal injuries occurring to
any of the towing company's employees or other persons and shall maintain the
required insurance policies.
   D.   The village shall assume no responsibility or liability for any vehicle
removed from any place without the authority of the chief of police.
   E.   The towing company shall not release any vehicle directly impounded by
the village without authorization by the chief of police.
   F.   The towing company shall maintain records and a claim check system to
assure release of vehicles to the rightful owners or authorized persons. Such
records shall be open to the village police department for investigation of
specific complaints and for compiling surveys under this chapter.
   G.   The towing company shall permit any person appointed by the chief of
police to inspect its wreckers, vault, security room or storage area at such
times as the chief of police shall deem appropriate. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-
2008)
7-5-2-4: REMOVAL FROM TOWING LIST:
The chief of police may remove or suspend any towing company from the towing
list in the event of any of the following:
   A.   The towing company violates or fails to comply with any of the
provisions of this chapter or any other local, state or federal law or
regulation.
   B.   The towing company is no longer actively engaged in the towing
business.
   C.   The chief of police is not satisfied with the services rendered by the
towing company to the village. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-2-5: SOLICITATION OF BUSINESS BY TOWING COMPANIES PROHIBITED:
No towing company may respond to the scene of an accident or emergency for the
purpose of towing vehicles unless specifically called there by the police
department or a person involved in the accident or emergency. This section is
intended to prohibit towing companies from soliciting business at accident or
emergency scenes and shall not be construed to prohibit any towing company from
contracting with any person, firm or corporation; provided, that the towing
company does not solicit towing contracts at the scene of any accident or
emergency. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008)
7-5-2-6: TOWING AND STORAGE FEES:
   A.   Fees Established:
      1.   The following schedule of maximum fees shall be in effect for all
tow calls received off the rotation tow list and shall be prominently displayed
at every office or storage facility:
Standard towing fee (i.e., use of flatbed truck, clean up, dollies, $150.00
etc.)
Exception location fee (winching)                                   40.00
Lot storage fee (per day)                                           35.00
Inside storage fee (per day)                                        40.00
Interrupted towing fee                                              30.00
Service fee (i.e., jump start, tire change, fuel, etc.)             40.00
Snow emergency tow                                                  50.00
Emergency openings after closing/special trips                      50.00
 
      2.   Where special or unusual circumstances require an exceptional amount
of extra work or equipment, a higher fee may be charged; provided, that the
owner or operator of the vehicle to be serviced is informed of the additional
fee in advance, if such person is available to be notified.
   B.   Payment Of Fees:
      1.   The owner or person in possession of any towed and stored vehicle
shall pay all costs incidental to towing and storage to the towing company. A
receipt for payment shall be issued to said person.
      2.   In the event that a vehicle is towed at the request of the village
police department pursuant to section
7-5-1-1 of this chapter, said vehicle shall be held until the required fees
have been paid pursuant to section
7-5-1-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2008-1303, 10-7-2008; amd. Ord. 2022-1672, 4-5-
2022)
CHAPTER 6
LOW-SPEED GAS-POWERED BICYCLES
SECTION:
7-6-1: Definition
7-6-2: Registration; Fees
7-6-3: Application Of Traffic Laws
7-6-4: Excessive Noise Prohibited
7-6-5: Penalty; Impoundment
7-6-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this Chapter, "LOW-SPEED GAS BICYCLE" shall mean: A two (2) or three
(3)-wheeled device with fully operable pedals and a gasoline motor of less than
one horsepower, whose maximum speed on a paved level surface, when powered
solely by such a motor while ridden by an operator who weighs one hundred and
seventy (170) pounds, is less than twenty (20) miles per hour. (Ord. 2021-1661,
7-20-2021)
7-6-2: REGISTRATION; FEES:
   A.   Any resident within the Village owning and operating a low-speed gas
bicycle within the Village shall register the same with the Police Department.
The owner shall furnish the Police Department with his or her name and address,
the make and serial number of the low-speed gas bicycle, and any other
information as the Police Department may require.
   B.   Upon registration of a low-speed gas bicycle and payment of the
registration fee provided for herein, the Police Department shall issue to the
owner a registration sticker to be firmly attached to the bicycle in such a
manner as the Chief of Police shall prescribe.
   C.   At the time of initial registration, a registration fee of five hundred
dollars ($500) shall be made. Subsequent annual registration fees in the amount
of five hundred dollars ($500) shall be due prior to the expiration of the
prior registration. (Ord. 2021-1661, 7-20-2021)
7-6-3: APPLICATION OF TRAFFIC LAWS:
Every person riding a low-speed gas bicycle upon a roadway within the village
shall be subject to all of the provisions of this title, as well as the laws of
this state applicable to low-speed gas bicycles.
   A.   A person may operate a low-speed gas bicycle only if the person is at
least sixteen (16) years of age.
   B.   A person may not operate a low-speed gas bicycle at a speed greater
than twenty (20) miles per hour upon any highway, street, or roadway.
   C.   A person may not operate a low-speed gas bicycle on a sidewalk. (Ord.
2021-1661, 7-20-2021)
7-6-4: EXCESSIVE NOISE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause noise levels from the operation of
a low-speed gas bicycle in excess of eighty (80) dBA in any area within the
corporate limits of the Village. (Ord. 2021-1661, 7-20-2021)
7-6-5: PENALTY; IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Penalty. Any person found to be in violation of any of the provisions
of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of no less than seventy-five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such
violation. Every day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.
   B.   Impoundment. In addition to fines as set forth in subsection A., any
person who has been issued a citation for the same offense under this Article
and found guilty or pled guilty to such citation within the previous twelve
months shall, at the time of issuance of the second such citation for the same
offense, be required to surrender the low-speed gas bicycle to the police
officer or other authorized officer of the village who issues the citation. The
surrendered low-speed gas bicycle shall be impounded and held by the police
department and shall be returned to the owner only after one of the following
conditions is met:
      1.   The person to whom the citation was issued has paid all outstanding
fines or registration fees related to the citation as well as fees and costs to
the village for impoundment in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      2.   In the event that the person to whom the citation was issued
requests, in writing and within forty-eight (48) hours of the seizure, a
hearing before a village hearing officer, and following such hearing, the
person to whom the citation was issued has presented to the Police Department
proof that a determination of not guilty was entered by the Village Hearing
Officer for the cited offense.
   C.   Failure to Retrieve Impounded Bicycle.
      1.   If a low-speed gas bicycle impounded pursuant to this Chapter is not
retrieved from the Police Department within thirty-five (35) days after the
entry of a determination of liability or non-liability by the administrative
hearing officer with regard to the citation resulting in impoundment of the
low-speed gas bicycle, the Chief of Police shall send written notice to the
owner thereof that the low-speed gas bicycle will be deemed abandoned and
disposed of by the Police Department if it is not retrieved by the owner within
thirty (30) days of the date of said notice.
      2.   If the low-speed gas bicycle remains unclaimed thirty (30) days
after the provision of a notice as described in subsection C.1. above, the
Police Department may dispose of said low-speed gas bicycle as it sees fit.
      3.   Any payment received by the Police Department in exchange for the
low-speed gas bicycle will be applied to any fines and fees owed by the owner
from whom it was impounded. (Ord. 2021-1661, 7-20-2021)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Streets, Sidewalks And Public Ways   1
Filling, Grading And Excavation   1A

CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Sidewalk Standards
8-1-2: Damage To Curbs And Gutters Prohibited
8-1-3: Obstructing, Damaging Public Ways
8-1-4: Safety Devices Required
8-1-5: Fires Prohibited On Paved Roadways
8-1-6: Relocation Or Remediation Of Utility Facilities; Aesthetic Requirements
8-1-1: SIDEWALK STANDARDS:
   A.   Thickness: All sidewalks shall be a minimum of six inches (6") thick.
Sidewalks at driveway locations shall be thickened to match the thickness of
the driveway pavement.
   B.   Width: Sidewalks shall not be less than four feet (4') in width.
   C.   Subgrade: Sidewalk subgrade material shall be free of debris, organic
material, plastic clays, and other material prone to freeze-thaw damage.
Subgrade material shall be compacted per IDOT standards to prevent settling
under the traffic of building materials delivery vehicles.
   D.   Location:
      1.   Sidewalks shall be located on both sides of the street within the
right-of-way. (2016 Code)
      2.   Upon a petition signed by the property owners of at least seventy
five percent (75%) of the property frontage in feet of a side of a block in the
Village, the Village President and Board of Trustees may grant the property
owners in the block the right, permission and authority by resolution to
construct a new sidewalk in a location other than as herein provided. (Ord.
204, 9-16-1940)
   E.   ADA: All sidewalks shall conform to all current Americans With
Disabilities Act (ADA) standards.
   F.   Minimum Geometry Requirements: Sidewalk geometry shall comply with this
subsection, State of Illinois requirements, and ADA requirements. Minimum
geometry requirements shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
      1.   Grade (longitudinal slope) shall not exceed eight percent (8%) (1
inch per 1 foot). Landings shall be provided at regular intervals as per the
current ADA guidelines.
      2.   Cross slope (transverse slope) standard shall be two percent (2%)
(1/4 inch per foot) downward in the direction of the back of the curb.
      3.   ADA ramps shall be provided at all necessary locations per IDOT and
ADA requirements. Minimum face to face of the curb width on sidewalk ramps
shall be four feet (4').
   G.   Material Requirements: Sidewalks shall be constructed of portland
cement concrete (PCC) from an IDOT approved plant using IDOT approved mix
design and material.
   H.   Construction Requirements: Sidewalks shall be constructed per the
following standards:
      1.   Forms: Steel forms shall be used. Lumber forms may be used when
constructing sidewalk ramps, curved pavement, or small projects. However, in no
case shall the sidewalk be less than six inches (6") thick.
      2.   Expansion Joints: Expansion joints, three-fourths inch (3/4")
thickness, should be placed only at the junctions of the pavement and sidewalk
and at the intersection of sidewalks.
      3.   Ramp Impressions: Only transverse grooving is allowed on sidewalk
ramps.
      4.   Constructed Width: When constructing sidewalk ramps, the minimum
sidewalk is four feet (4'). Sidewalk ramp curbs shall be installed such that
the four foot (4') width minimum is not compromised, i.e., the four foot (4')
width shall be maintained throughout, face to face of the sidewalk curbs.
      5.   Timing: Sidewalks should be constructed prior to the occupancy of
buildings/subdivision. Forms shall be stripped in accordance with the IDOT
standard specification, and the sidewalk shall be backfilled immediately after
the forms are stripped.
      6.   Inspection And Testing: All inspecting and testing procedures shall
be followed as stated in the Illinois department of transportation construction
manual. (2016 Code)
   I.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation who shall authorize, contract
for or construct any sidewalk on any public street so that the same shall not
conform to this section shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and said sidewalk may be torn out and
removed by the village through its authorized employees and agents. (Ord. 204,
9-16-1940; amd. 2016 Code)
8-1-2: DAMAGE TO CURBS AND GUTTERS PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to ride, drive or lead
any animal or animals, either attached to or detached from any vehicle of any
kind, upon, over or across any curbing or any substitute therefor in the
village after the same has been set for use as such along or upon any street or
alley in the village.
   B.   It shall also be unlawful for any person to throw any material of any
kind upon or against either side of any curbing after the same has been set in
the village to be used as a bridge or means of getting to or from any property,
or in any manner obstruct any gutter or waterway in the village of which any
curbing forms a part. (1914 Code § 22-1)
   C.   Any person, either directly or indirectly, violating any of the
provisions of this section shall, for each offense, be fined as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (1914 Code § 22-2; amd. 2016 Code)
8-1-3: OBSTRUCTING, DAMAGING PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Prohibited Generally: Any person who shall dig in, build upon or in any
manner obstruct or injure any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks, or other
public property within the village, except by authority of the village board,
shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for every such offense. (1914 Code § 10-13; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Obstructing Vision At Intersections: It shall be unlawful for the
owner, lessee or person in possession, charge or control of any premises to
permit any tree or shrub to grow or other obstruction to be erected or
maintained in such a manner as to unreasonably obstruct the line of sight of
traffic or traffic lights at intersections within the village. Any person, firm
or corporation violating any of the provisions of this subsection, or any rule
or regulation made in compliance herewith, shall, upon conviction thereof, be
punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 266A, 1-7-1946; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Buildings, Fences And Hedges:
      1.   No person shall erect or place any fence or building, wholly or in
part, upon any street, alley, sidewalk, park, or other public ground. Any
building, fence or other obstruction upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or
public ground in the village shall be deemed a nuisance, and it shall be lawful
for any member of the board of trustees or the chief of police to cause the
same to be removed or taken down in such a manner as shall be deemed best; and
every person who shall oppose or resist the execution of the orders of said
member of the board or of the chief of police in the premises shall forfeit and
pay a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1914 Code § 18-8; amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   No porch, gallery, stoop, steps, cellar door, stair, rail, or
platform erected, or to be erected, within the village shall be allowed to
extend upon or into any sidewalk; and no bow window shall extend into or over
any sidewalk more than two feet (2') nor less than eight feet (8') above the
grade line, nor shall any cellar door, at its outer edge, rise or project above
the surface of the sidewalk. (1914 Code § 18-13)
      3.   No hedge fence shall be permitted to extend over or into any part of
any public highway in the village. It is hereby made the duty of the owner,
occupant, or agent of any premises upon which there is a hedge fence in
violation of the provisions of this subsection, to remove that part of said
fence extending over or into the highway as aforesaid within ten (10) days
after written notice to do so is served upon him by the chief of police. If any
owner, occupant, or agent shall fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of
this subsection, he shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. If service of said notice cannot be made
upon the owner, occupant, or agent of said premises, or if there is not
compliance with said notice within ten (10) days after the service thereof,
that part of the fence which is in violation shall be removed under the
direction of the Chief of Police, and the expense of removal shall be recovered
by the Village from the owner of said premises in any court of competent
jurisdiction. (1914 Code § 18-14; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Permit To Obstruct:
      1.   Whoever shall, within the limits of the Village, do any act in any
way interfering with the use by the public of any street, alley or public
grounds in the Village without first obtaining permission therefor from the
Village Board shall be deemed guilty of an offense. This subsection is intended
to and does apply as well to those persons and corporations who have
heretofore, by negotiation, secured privileges in the Village, as to every
other person. And any person, persons or corporations by themselves, servants
or agents violating any of the provisions of this subsection, shall be fined as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1914 Code § 10-22; amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   a. Any person, company or corporation who shall encumber or
obstruct, or cause to be encumbered or obstructed, any street, alley, or other
public place in the Village by placing therein or thereon any building
materials, or any article or thing whatsoever, without having first obtained
written permission from the Village President or the Director of Public Works,
shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense.
         b.   The party obtaining such permission shall first give bond in such
penal sum as the Village President or the Director of Public Works may direct,
conditioned that he shall comply with all the conditions mentioned in said
permit, and shall cease to encumber or obstruct said street, alley or other
public place, after the expiration of the time mentioned in said permit, and
shall thereupon, without cost to the Village, restore said street to as good
condition in all respects as before his use, occupation, encumbrance or
obstruction thereof, and shall remove all material and debris from the space so
occupied, and shall indemnify and save harmless the Village and its officers
against and from all costs, judgments and decrees which may be recovered
against the Village, or any of its officers, in any proceeding arising from or
growing out of the use or obstruction of said street as aforesaid, or by reason
of any excavation, opening or obstruction, or other impediment left in said
street, or by reason of any accident or casualty occurring before the
completion of said work in consequence of said obstruction or impediment. (1914
Code § 18-4; amd. 2016 Code)
   E.   Removal Of Obstructions: Any member of the Village Board, the Village
President, or Chief of Police is hereby authorized to order any article or
thing whatsoever which may encumber or obstruct any highway, street or alley
within the Village to be removed. Any such encumbrance or obstruction remaining
more than six (6) hours in any highway, street or alley as aforesaid shall be
deemed a nuisance, and it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to abate the
same forthwith. (1914 Code § 18-5)
8-1-4: SAFETY DEVICES REQUIRED:
Whenever any person shall do any work which shall require the digging up, use
or occupancy of any street, alley, highway or public ground, such person shall,
during the nighttime, put up and maintain such barriers and lights as will
effectually prevent accidents in consequence of such digging up, use or
occupancy of said street, alley, highway or public ground. (1914 Code § 18-12)
8-1-5: FIRES PROHIBITED ON PAVED ROADWAYS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to start, ignite or maintain a fire within
the roadway boundaries of any public street or highway within the Village which
has been improved with a bituminous surface. A violation of this section shall
be considered a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 215, 11-3-1941; amd. 2016 Code)
8-1-6: RELOCATION OR REMEDIATION OF UTILITY FACILITIES; AESTHETIC REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Findings: The findings set by the Board of Trustees are incorporated
herein by reference.
   B.   Definitions:
   PUBLIC WORKS PROJECT: A construction project of the Village for the benefit
or use of its citizens.
   UTILITY COMPANY: Any entity that owns, controls, operates or manages any
utility facilities in the Village. This includes, without limitation, providers
of electricity, water, and gas, and waste disposal, telecommunications and
cable services.
   UTILITY FACILITIES: Any infrastructure utilized for the purpose of providing
to the public heat, cold, power, electricity, water, light, oil or gas, or
waste disposal, telecommunications or cable services including, without
limitation, transmission and distribution pipes, mains, lines, poles, conduits,
wires, cables, fixtures, and other necessary equipment.
   VILLAGE PROPERTY: Property owned by the Village and/or property over which
the Village has dominion and control.
   C.   Relocation Or Remediation May Be Required:
      1.   Upon a finding by the Village that any utility company's utility
facilities located on Village property: a) constitute a threat to, or
impairment of, the health, safety or welfare of the Village citizens; and/or b)
will impede the completion of a public works project undertaken for the health,
safety or welfare of the Village citizens, the Village may require the utility
company, at the utility company's sole expense, to relocate or otherwise
remediate its utility facilities as approved by the Village.
      2.   The Village shall provide due notice to the utility company of its
finding and provide the utility company with a schedule of the time frame
within which the utility company must relocate or otherwise remediate its
utility facilities in coordination with the Village.
      3.   In the event that the utility company cannot complete the relocation
or remediation within the time frame mandated by the schedule, the utility
company shall continue to work diligently to complete the relocation or
remediation and shall immediately provide the Village with the time frame
within which the utility company will complete the relocation or remediation,
with said time frame not exceeding thirty (30) days beyond the schedule
provided by the Village, unless otherwise agreed to by the Village.
   D.   Aesthetic Requirements: All new and relocated utility facilities
located on Village property shall comply with the following requirements:
      1.   All structures associated with any utility facilities, including any
wireless facility (as defined in section
9-5A-2 of this Code), shall, to the extent possible, use materials, colors,
textures, screening, and landscaping that will blend them into the natural
setting and surrounding buildings and improvements.
      2.   All electrical and mechanical equipment, including any wireless
facility (as defined in section
9-5A-2 of this Code), must be of neutral color that is identical to, or closely
compatible with, the color of the supporting structure or utility pole so as to
make the equipment as visually unobtrusive as possible.
   E.   Penalties: The Village may impose a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code per offense as a penalty for each violation of this section.
Each day that a violation continues constitutes a separate offense. The Village
may also obtain an injunction or other appropriate legal or equitable relief to
prevent or remedy any violation hereof. (Ord. 2018-1566, 7-17-2018)
ARTICLE A. FILLING, GRADING AND EXCAVATION
SECTION:
8-1A-1: Definitions
8-1A-2: Permit Required
8-1A-3: Application For Permit; Issuance
8-1A-4: Permit And Inspection Fee
8-1A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings
provided in this section:
   EXCAVATION: Shall include removal, stripping or disturbance of soil, earth,
sand, rock, gravel or other similar substance from the ground.
   FILLING: Shall include the placing of any soil, earth, sand, rock, gravel or
other substance on the ground.
   GRADING: Shall include any operation involving excavation and/or filling.
   GROUND: Shall include, but shall not be limited to, land above and below and
the 100-year flood line of the Illinois River and the banks and beds of any
river. (Ord. 992, 4-17-1984)
8-1A-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No excavation, grading or filling shall be commenced in the village unless a
permit is first obtained as hereinafter provided or unless excepted in this
section or this article:
   A.   Building Permit: Under the provisions of a duly issued building permit.
(Ord. 992, 4-17-1984)
   B.   Excavation For Streets And Repairs: Necessary grading, removal or
excavation of topsoil, or other materials shall be permitted within the limits
of the right of way of any existing street, or for the purpose of constructing
streets and other related improvements within the area of new subdivisions when
made in accordance with subdivision plans approved by the planning commission
and zoning board of appeals, which subdivision plans shall establish the
elevations and grades of said streets and/or the location of said improvements
and for which a street opening permit or a sewer connection permit has been
issued. (Ord. 992, 4-17-1984; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Other Construction Work: Construction work relating to drains,
utilities, or sanitary sewerage systems for which a street opening and/or other
necessary permits have been issued by the village board. (Ord. 992, 4-17-1984)
8-1A-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; ISSUANCE:
   A.   Application for an excavation permit shall be made by the property
owner or his authorized agent, and shall be made to the building inspector as
enforcement officer, on forms provided thereby. An application in duplicate
shall be accompanied by a detailed statement of the proposed work and the
purpose thereof and why the excavation, grading and/or filling is clearly
incidental to the improvement of the property, and written copies, if required,
of the permits granted by the Peoria pleasure and park district.
   B.   Subsequent to the permit application having been filed, with the
accompanying fee, a permit, if all the requirements of this article have been
met, shall be issued as herein authorized. (Ord. 992, 4-17-1984)
8-1A-4: PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEE:
A fee to cover the cost of the permit and inspections shall be charged as
determined by the village board and shall be set out on a schedule of
excavation fees to be filed with the village clerk. (Ord. 992, 4-17-1984)
ARTICLE B. STOP SIGN CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS
SECTION:
8-1B-1: Definitions
8-1B-2: Prohibition
8-1B-3: Eligibility
8-1B-4: Board Of Trustees To Issue Permits
8-1B-5: Limited Number Of Permits
8-1B-6: Application
8-1B-7: Required Conditions Of Permit
8-1B-8: Violations
8-1B-9: Penalties
8-1B-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, when used in this article, shall have the following
meanings:
   CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: Any group, organization, fund, community chest,
fraternity, or other entity which has obtained an exemption from taxation
pursuant to the provisions of title 26 United States Code section 501(c) or
(d), also known as the internal revenue code.
   DONATION: Cash or anything of value given with charitable or benevolent
intention and without any expectation of receiving something in return.
   SOLICITOR: Anyone who solicits donations at the corner of Prospect Road and
Seiberling Avenue within the village of Peoria Heights.
   STOP SIGN FUNDRAISER: Any event where automobiles are hailed, flagged, or
otherwise approached when stopped and funds are requested or solicited from the
occupants of the vehicle or anything of value is exchanged with the occupant of
a vehicle. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
8-1B-2: PROHIBITION:
No one shall engage in solicitation of donations from automobiles within the
streets of the village or any other stop sign fundraising activities except as
permitted by this article or at any other location than the stop signs at the
corner of Prospect Road and Seiberling Avenue. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
8-1B-3: ELIGIBILITY:
Only charitable organizations based in the village are eligible to obtain a
permit to hold a stop sign fundraiser. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
8-1B-4: BOARD OF TRUSTEES TO ISSUE PERMITS:
The board of trustees shall take applications and issue permits for stop sign
fundraisers in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. 2019-1614,
12-17-2019)
8-1B-5: LIMITED NUMBER OF PERMITS:
No more than four (4) total stop sign charitable solicitation permits shall be
issued in any calendar year. Stop sign charitable solicitation permits shall be
issued only to charitable organizations that are affiliated with the village or
that have offices located in the village. Permits shall be issued in order of
receipt of application and approval by the board of trustees. Applications
received in excess of the four (4) annual permits will be automatically denied
and referred to reapply in the subsequent calendar year. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-
17-2019)
8-1B-6: APPLICATION:
Applications for permission to conduct a stop sign fundraiser must be submitted
in full on village approved forms to the village administrator.
   A.   The application shall contain, in addition to other items required by
the board of trustees, the following information:
      1.   Name, address, and telephone number of the person making the
application and organizing the event.
      2.   Name, address, and telephone number of the headquarters of the
charitable organization.
      3.   The authorized and responsible head of the charitable organization.
      4.   Activities to be conducted at the fundraiser.
      5.   Proposed time and duration of the fundraiser.
      6.   Names of all solicitors who will be in the public right-of-way
during the stop sign fundraiser.
      7.   Individual signed waivers of liability from each participating
solicitor in accordance with section
8-1B-7D  of this code.
      8.   Two (2) executed stop sign fundraiser indemnification agreements
signed by an authorized representative of the charitable organization in
accordance with section
8-1B-7E  of this code.
      9.   Proof of recognition by the United States Internal Revenue Service
of the charitable organization’s not-for-profit status as a 501(c) or 501(d)
charitable organization in the form of a determination letter issued by the
Internal Revenue Service.
   B.   Upon favorable action by the board of trustees, and the filing of all
required documents, the board of trustees shall issue a stop sign charitable
solicitation permit for the stop sign fundraiser.
   C.   If the board of trustees denies an application for a permit, it shall
notify the applicant of its decision and the grounds therefor by certified
mail, return receipt requested. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
8-1B-7: REQUIRED CONDITIONS OF PERMIT:
The charitable organization agrees to abide by all required conditions of the
stop sign charitable solicitation permit as listed below.
   A.   Reflective vests and other protective devices are required to be used
by solicitors for safety purposes. The board of trustees requires the use of
cones or barricades, and such devices shall be utilized in accordance with the
instructions of the superintendent of public works or his or her designee.
   B.   In no event shall the board of trustees grant permission to conduct a
stop sign fundraiser before 8:00 a.m. or after 5:00 p.m.
   C.   The board of trustees has the right to choose the weekend said stop
sign fundraiser will occur.
   D.   Each participating solicitor shall execute a release of liability
waiver as prepared by the village and approved by the charitable organization,
or their designated representative, prior to participation in a stop sign
fundraiser event.
   E.   Each charitable organization must provide two (2) original copies of
the stop sign fundraiser indemnification agreement to the village for approval
by the board of trustees as part of the application for a stop sign charitable
solicitation permit.
   F.   A copy of the stop sign charitable solicitation permit as issued by the
board of trustees for the stop sign fundraiser must be kept at the location of
the fundraiser and must be shown to any member of the public or any officer,
employee, or representative of the village upon demand.
   G.   Solicitors shall not verbally or physically induce contributions by
intimidation, coercion, obstruction, or duress. Nor shall solicitors treat the
public in a rude, insolent, or discourteous manner.
   H.   Solicitors shall not obstruct traffic flow or endanger the public in
any fashion. At no time will signs, barricades, solicitors, or other objects
obstruct the view or impede the use of the street, sidewalk, or intersection.
   I.   Charitable organizations must display a sign or signs of at least one
and a half (1.5) square feet in area which identifies the organization and
cause for the fundraiser during the event. Said sign(s) shall be placed so that
they are visible to vehicles traveling in each direction before they reach the
intersection. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
8-1B-8: VIOLATIONS:
It is a violation of this article to fail to comply with any provision hereof,
any condition imposed on the permit, or for any individual to engage in stop
sign fundraising within the village without the permission of the village board
of trustees. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
8-1B-9: PENALTIES:
For purposes of this section, each day upon which unlawful solicitation occurs
shall constitute a separate offense. Any or all of the following penalties may
be imposed for violation of this article:
   A.   A fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation.
   B.   Any permit issued to a charitable organization shall be subject to
revocation in the event of violations of any provision of this article.
      1.   If the board of trustees has reason to believe that a permit holder
has violated any of the provisions of this article, the board shall immediately
suspend the license and give the permit holder written notice in person or by
certified mail, return receipt requested.
      2.   The notice must contain a statement by the board of trustees of the
facts which have resulted in the suspension of the stop sign charitable
solicitation permit.
   C.   If a permit issued to a charitable organization is revoked pursuant to
subsection B of this section, the charitable organization, its direct
affiliates, and participating solicitors shall be disqualified from
consideration for further permits for a period of not less than two (2) years
from the date of revocation. (Ord. 2019-1614, 12-17-2019)
CHAPTER 2
WATER USE AND SERVICE
ARTICLE A. WATER SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-2A-1: Use Of Village System Required
8-2A-2: Authority To Turn On Water; Responsibility For Service
8-2A-3: Application For Service; Deposit Required
8-2A-4: Compliance With Village Plumbing Requirements; Exceptions
8-2A-5: Water Taps
8-2A-6: Service Devices
8-2A-7: Water Meters
8-2A-8: Excavations For Installation
8-2A-9: Responsibility For Repairs
8-2A-10: Rates And Charges
8-2A-11: Delinquent Bills
8-2A-12: Restricted And Prohibited Acts
8-2A-13: Users Outside Corporate Limits
8-2A-14: Penalty
8-2A-1: USE OF VILLAGE SYSTEM REQUIRED:
After the effective date of ordinance 805, passed October 17, 1972, all persons
owning, occupying or using premises in the village limits shall secure their
water from the village water supply at such time as water mains are convenient
to make connection to the premises. In the event any owner or owners fail to
comply with the provisions of this section, notice shall be served upon said
owner or owners. Legal proceedings shall be instituted to enforce compliance.
Such notice shall be served by certified mail to owner or owners of said
premises. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-2: AUTHORITY TO TURN ON WATER; RESPONSIBILITY FOR SERVICE:
Water from the village shall be turned on for service to any premises only by
the director of public works or his authorized agent. The owner of real
property shall be responsible for water service to all properties - rental and
owner occupied. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-3: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE; DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
   A.   Application For Service: Application to have water service shall be
made in writing by the homeowner or authorized agent at the water department
office during normal working hours. The application shall be an agreement made
by the water department and the homeowner to abide by and to accept all
provisions of this article and any other applicable ordinances governing the
use of the village water supply. Documentation showing proof of ownership is
requested at the time of application.
   B.   Deposit Required: A deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be made
with each application; the sum to be retained by the village to ensure payment
of such due amounts when service is permanently discontinued. This deposit,
less any owed still due to the village, shall be refunded without interest.
(Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013; amd. Ord. 2023-1720, 12-19-2023)
8-2A-4: COMPLIANCE WITH VILLAGE PLUMBING REQUIREMENTS; EXCEPTIONS:
No water service to any premises shall commence unless the plumbing complies
with village ordinances; provided, temporary service for construction work may
be allowed by the director of public works or authorized agent. (Ord. 2013-
1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-5: WATER TAPS:
   A.   Permit Required; Fee: Taps to the water main shall not be less than
three-fourths inch (3/4"), and shall be made by a licensed bonded plumber, and
shall not be made without making application for permit from the director of
public works or authorized agent at the water department office. The fee for
any water main taps shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-
7-2013; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Responsibility For Costs: All expense of connection work, tap or new
service will be to the applicant.
   C.   Specifications: Services will be no less than three-fourths inch (3/4")
copper or plastic, with service meaning from the main to premises. In addition,
all plastic lines shall include a tracer wire.
   D.   Inspections: The director of public works or authorized agent will
inspect all connections and new services. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-6: SERVICE DEVICES:
   A.   All services shall consist of the following:
      1.   Full circle stainless steel tap clamp.
      2.   Corporation stop.
      3.   Copper or plastic pipe with tracer wire.
      4.   Curb stop.
      5.   Stop box.
   B.   Curb stops will be located anywhere from the curb line to the sidewalk,
unless not applicable. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-7: WATER METERS:
   A.   Metered Water And Remote Reading Device Required: All premises will be
metered before habitation. Meters will be supplied, maintained and serviced
when needed by the village. Said meters will meet the requirements of the
village water department. All premises will have a remote meter reading device
needed to facilitate the village touch read system.
   B.   Reading Meters: The director of public works shall cause all services
to be read as follows:
      1.   Residential, quarterly.
      2.   Commercial, monthly.
   C.   Estimate Of Rates: At any time a meter cannot be read for any reason,
the water office will estimate an average rate of consumption and will then
notify owners of premises by written notice to make repairs of the metering
device. If owners do not comply, termination of service will be used to make
necessary repairs to metering devices.
   D.   Testing Meters: Any water service consumer may submit a written request
for testing of their metering device. Any such testing shall be at the
consumer’s expense and performed by a third-party at their then current rates.
If the test shows said water meter is not within three percent (3%) accurate,
it shall be repaired or replaced and the testing fee will be refunded.
   E.   Prohibited Acts:
      1.   If any user causes or permits the breakage of seals on a water meter
on his premises or the removal thereof, he shall be in violation of this
article.
      2.   No water meter may be removed without notification by the user to
the village.
      3.   Upon determination of guilt showing a violation of this subsection
E, the user shall be fined, upon conviction, an amount equal to twice the
amount of his water charges for the previous year, or the charges made at his
premises, but not to exceed the maximum set out in section
1-4-1 of this code.
(Ord. 896, 9-6-1977; amd. Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013; 2016 Code; Ord. 2023-1720,
12-19-2023)
8-2A-8: EXCAVATIONS FOR INSTALLATION:
Excavations for installing services or repairs to same shall be under
compliance of this article and other village ordinances relating to street
openings and also state and federal environmental protection agency (EPA)
guidelines. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-9: RESPONSIBILITY FOR REPAIRS:
All repairs made from the curb box to the premises, including the premises,
will be done at the owner's expense by a licensed bonded plumber. The village
shall be responsible for repairs of all services from the main to the curb box,
including curb stop, water meter and remote reader. The village reserves the
right to make repairs by work force or by a licensed bonded plumber in the case
of an emergency at the owner's expense. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013)
8-2A-10: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   User Rates:
      1.   Rates Established: The rates to be charged to users of water
supplied by the municipal water plant of the village shall be as follows:
A five percent (5%) increase for:
   Per Thousand Minimum Charge

      2.   Summary Of Minimum Charges: Beginning May 1, 2025, through November
30, 2025, the availability charge for all existing residential water service
connections, whether they are active or inactive, will be billed at a minimum
charge of eighty-eight dollars and twenty-two cents ($88.22). The Country Club
and Businesses, whether they are active or inactive accounts, will be billed a
minimum charge of thirty-nine dollars and twenty-seven cents ($39.27).
Beginning on December 1, 2025, the availability charge for all existing
residential water service connections, whether they are active or inactive,
will be billed at a minimum charge of ninety-two dollars and sixty-three cents
($92.63), and the Country Club and Businesses, whether they are active or
inactive accounts, will be billed a minimum charge of forty-one dollars and
twenty-three cents ($41.23).
      3.   Effective Date Of Rates: All water rates as herein stated shall
become effective and in all respects shown to commence with the December 1,
2023, billing cycle.
   B.   Monthly Infrastructure Fee:
      1.   In addition to the user charges based on the water rates in
subsection A of this section, each metered user of the water system shall pay a
monthly infrastructure fee of five dollars ($5.00), billed on the same schedule
as the billing for user charges. All revenue generated by the infrastructure
fee imposed by this subsection B shall be deposited in the waterworks fund
maintained by the village.
      2.   The monthly infrastructure fee established by this subsection B
shall become effective beginning with the month of May 2014, but shall be
billed to users only with quarterly statements for water service submitted to
users on or after August 1, 2014.
   C.   Insufficient Funds Fee: The water department shall charge a twenty five
dollar ($25.00) fee on all insufficient funds checks (NSF). If check and fee
are not paid within two (2) working days after notification, either by door tag
or phone, water service will be terminated until any and all payments and fees
are paid.
   D.   Billing: All fees provided for under this Chapter are the
responsibility of the owner of the real property receiving the water service.
Statements reflecting all fees owed shall be billed to said property owner at
their tax mailing address; provided however, that property owners may elect to
only receive fee statements via email. Property owners electing to receive fee
statements via email are responsible for maintaining the email address(es)
associated with their account and updating the Village water department with
any change in mailing address. (Ord. 2006-1269, 9-19-2006; amd. Ord. 2011-1353,
11-15-2011; Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013; Ord. 2014-1407, 5-20-2014; 2016 Code;
Ord. 2016-1492, 12-6-2016; Ord. 2019-1613, 11-19-2019; Ord. 2023-1715, 11-21-
2023; Ord. 2023-1720, 12-19-2023; Ord. 2025-1759, 4-1-2025)
8-2A-11: DELINQUENT BILLS:
   A.   Termination Of Service; Payment Required For Reinstatement: Water
service may be terminated for any premises which account remains unpaid for a
period of thirty (30) days after the statement is rendered and mailed or
emailed. To restart service, customers will pay the account in full or be
responsible to work out a payment arrangement with the director of public works
or authorized agent during normal business hours.
   B.   Lien Provisions For Severe Delinquencies:
      1.   Payment of any charges, rates and fees required under this article
shall be severely delinquent if left unpaid for a period of sixty (60) days
after the statement has been rendered, which will result in a lien filing on
said premises by the village water department.
      2.   At such time, the water department will notify the owner or owners
of said real estate that a lien on said property will be made as prescribed by
Illinois law. The water office will file with the county recorder a notice of
lien claim, which shall conform to applicable law, and a copy of the notice
will be sent to the owner or owners of the real estate referenced by tax
identification number.
      3.   Any lien claim so filed may be enforced by foreclosure. The village
may also elect to sue the occupant or user of the real estate property in a
civil action to recover money due for any service rendered under this article,
plus attorney fees and court costs.
      4.   Property subject to a lien for unpaid water service charges shall be
sold for nonpayment, and the proceeds shall be applied to pay any and all
charges after deducting costs as in the case of foreclosure of statutory liens.
Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the village. The
village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such
proceedings in the name of the village in any court having jurisdiction over
such proceedings against any property for which a lien was filed.
(Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013; amd. Ord. 2023-1720, 12-19-2023)
8-2A-12: RESTRICTED AND PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Sale, Purchase Of Water:
      1.   No water shall be resold or distributed by the applicant for water
service unless approved by the director of public works. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-
2013)
      2.   a. No public utility engaged in the sale and distribution of water,
other than the village water department, shall sell, furnish and distribute
water to any person, firm or corporation for use and consumption within the
boundaries of the village.
         b.   No person, firm or corporation located or residing within the
boundaries of the village shall purchase water from an outside public utility
engaged in the business of selling and distributing water for use and
consumption within the village boundaries. (Ord. 190, 7-3-1939)
         c.   Any violation of the terms of this subsection A2 shall be a
misdemeanor and each day that such violation exists shall be considered a
separate offense. For each violation of this subsection A2, there shall be
imposed a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 190, 7-3-1939; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Tampering With, Damage To System: It shall be unlawful for any person
to tamper with or alter any part of the village water system unless authorized
by the director of public works or authorized agent. Persons so doing will
incur the cost of any repair needed because of the same. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-
2013)
8-2A-13: USERS OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS:
   A.   Regular Rates Apply:
      1.   From and after September 1, 1934, the rates for water furnished by
the village waterworks to users who reside outside of the corporate limits of
the village shall be the same as those charged water users residing within the
corporate limits of the village.
      2.   Any subsequent changes in rates to water users shall apply equally
to water users residing within and to those residing without the corporate
limits of the village.
   B.   Service And Maintenance By Village:
      1.   Distribution mains for water furnished by the village waterworks
beyond the corporate limits of the village and service mains from such
distribution mains to stop boxes shall be serviced and maintained by the
village waterworks without charge to the water users.
      2.   Water meters on premises of users of water of the village waterworks
beyond the corporate limits of the village shall be serviced and maintained
without cost to such water users. (Ord. 130, 8-20-1934)
8-2A-14: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article, upon written notice to the
owner or owners, subject to water service termination and/or upon conviction,
shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and each day a violation continues to
exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2013-1385, 5-7-2013; amd. 2016
Code)
ARTICLE B. GROUNDWATER; WATER SUPPLY CONTAMINATION
SECTION:
8-2B-1: Setbacks From Public Water Supply
8-2B-2: Use Of Groundwater As Potable Water Prohibited
8-2B-1: SETBACKS FROM PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   Statute Authority; Purpose; Scope: Pursuant to the authority conferred
by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-125-4 and 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/14.2 and 5/14.3 and in the interest of securing the public health, safety and
welfare; to preserve the quality and quantity of groundwater resources in order
to assure a safe and adequate water supply for the present and future
generations; and to preserve groundwater resources currently in use and those
aquifers having a potential use as a public water supply, the provisions of
this section shall apply to all properties located within the minimum setback
zone established under section 14.2 of the environmental protection act 1
("act") and this section, and the maximum setback zone established under
section 14.3 of the act 2  and this section.
   B.   Definitions: Except as stated in this section, and unless a different
meaning of a word or term is clear from the context, the definitions of words
or terms in this section shall be the same as those used in the act and the
Illinois groundwater protection act 3 .
   ACT: The environmental protection act 4 .
   AGENCY: The Illinois environmental protection agency.
   BOARD: The Illinois pollution control board.
   MAXIMUM SETBACK ZONE: The area around a community water supply well
established under section 14.3 of the act and this section, and described in
appendix A attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a part hereof.
   MINIMUM SETBACK ZONE: The area around a community water supply well
established under section 14.2 of the act and this section, and described in
appendix A attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a part hereof.
(Ord. 1067, 6-2-1992; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Prohibitions:
      1.   Except as provided in subsection D or E of this section, no person
shall place a new potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or
new potential route within the minimum setback zone of four hundred feet (400')
of wells 7, 9, and 11, IEPA wells 50194, 50196, and 50198, all shown on exhibit
A attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a part hereof, and located
in the southeast one-quarter of section fifteen T.9N R.8E., Peoria Heights,
Peoria County, Illinois.
      2.   Except as provided in subsection D of this section, no person shall
place a new potential primary source within the maximum setback zone of one
thousand feet (1,000') of wells 7, 9, and 11, IEPA wells 50194, 50196, and
50198, all shown on exhibit A attached to the ordinance codified herein and
made a part hereof, and located in the southeast one-quarter of section fifteen
T.9N R.8E., Peoria Heights, Peoria County, Illinois.
   D.   Waivers, Exceptions And Certifications Of Minimal Hazard:
      1.   If, pursuant to section 14.2(b) of the act, the owner of a new
potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or a new potential
route is granted a waiver by the agency, such owner shall be deemed to have a
waiver to the same extent from subsection C1 of this section.
      2.   If, pursuant to section 14.2(c) of the act, the owner of a new
potential primary source (other than land filling or land treating), new
potential secondary source, or new potential route is granted an exception by
the board, such owner shall be deemed to have an exception to the same extent
from subsection C1 of this section.
      3.   If, pursuant to section 14.2(c) of the act, the owner of a new
potential primary source (other than land filling or land treating) is granted
an exception by the board, such owner shall be deemed to have an exception to
the same extent from subsection C2 of this section.
      4.   If, pursuant to section 14.5 of the act, the owner of a new
potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or new potential
route is issued a certificate of minimal hazard by the agency, such owner shall
not be subject to subsection C1 of this section to the same extent that such
owner is not subject to section 14.2(d) of the act.
   E.   Exclusion: Subsection C1 of this section shall not apply to new common
sources of sanitary pollution as specified pursuant to section 17 of the act
and the regulations adopted thereunder by the agency; however, no such common
sources may be located within the applicable minimum distance from a community
water supply well specified by such regulations. (Ord. 1067, 6-2-1992)

8-2B-2: USE OF GROUNDWATER AS POTABLE WATER PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
   PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
   POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption including,
but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes,
or preparing foods.
   B.   Areas Where Use Prohibited: Except for such uses or methods in
existence before the effective date hereof, the use or attempt to use a potable
water supply groundwater from within the corporate limits of the village, as
described in exhibits A and B attached to the ordinance codified herein by the
installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited.
This prohibition expressly includes the village. (Ord. 2014-1401, 2-18-2014)
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each violation. (Ord. 2014-1401, 2-18-2014; amd. 2016
Code)
ARTICLE C. CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
8-2C-1: Cross Connections Prohibited
8-2C-2: Backflow Prevention Devices
8-2C-3: Investigations And Inspections; Entry Powers
8-2C-4: Disconnection Of Service
8-2C-5: Responsibility For Cleanup Costs
8-2C-1: CROSS CONNECTIONS PROHIBITED:
No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or
maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary
or emergency water supply other than that of the public water supply of the
village may enter the supply or distribution system of said public water supply
system. (Ord. 1062, 12-17-1991)
8-2C-2: BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
All plumbing installed within the village shall be installed in accordance with
the Illinois plumbing code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890. In accordance
with said Illinois plumbing code or in the judgment of the director of public
works, if an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of
the public water supply system, the director of public works shall give notice
to the water customer to install such a device immediately. The water customer
shall, at his or her own expense, install such an approved device at a location
and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code, the Illinois
environmental protection agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall
cause the inspection and testing of said device upon installation and as
required by the Illinois plumbing code, the Illinois environmental protection
agency and all applicable local regulations. (Ord. 1062, 12-17-1991)
8-2C-3: INVESTIGATIONS AND INSPECTIONS; ENTRY POWERS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the director of public works to cause
inspections and/or investigations to be made of any and/or all commercial,
industrial and other properties served by the public water supply system of the
village to determine whether actual or potential hazards to said public water
supply system may exist. Such inspections and/or investigations shall be made a
matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years or
as often as the director of public works shall deem necessary. Records of such
inspections and/or investigations shall be maintained and available for review
for a period of at least five (5) years.
   B.   The director shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any
property served by the village public water system for the purpose of verifying
the presence or absence of cross connections. On demand, the owner, lessees or
occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the director of public
works any information which said director may request regarding the piping
system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal to furnish said
requested information shall be deemed evidence of the presence of improper
connections as provided in this article. (Ord. 1062, 12-17-1991)
8-2C-4: DISCONNECTION OF SERVICE:
The director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue,
after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any
property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this article
is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as may be
deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water
supply. Water service to said property shall not be restored until such
conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions
of this article, and until a reconnection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) is paid
to the village. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected if
the director of public works determines that an imminent danger of harmful
contamination to the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be
followed by written notification of the cause for disconnection. Immediate
disconnection without notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or
anticipated contamination or pollution of the public water supply; provided,
that in the reasonable opinion of the director of public works or the Illinois
environmental protection agency, such action is required to prevent actual or
anticipated contamination or pollution of the public water supply system.
Neither the village, its agents or assigns shall be liable to any customer for
any injury, damages, or lost revenue which may result from termination of said
customer's water supply in accordance with the terms and provisions of this
article, whether or not said termination was with or without notice. (Ord.
1062, 12-17-1991)
8-2C-5: RESPONSIBILITY FOR CLEANUP COSTS:
The customer responsible for back siphoned or back pressured material or
contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply
system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed,
maintained, or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear
the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. (Ord. 1062, 12-17-1991)
