CHAPTER 12
SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS
SECTION:
10-12-1: Purpose
10-12-2: Definitions
10-12-3: Roof Mount SESs
10-12-4: Ground Mount SESs
10-12-5: Requirements For All SESs
10-12-6: Building Integrated Systems
10-12-7: Special Use Requirements
10-12-8: Administration
10-12-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to facilitate the construction, installation,
and operation of Solar Energy Systems ("SES") in the Village of Peoria Heights
in a manner that promotes economic development and ensures the protection of
health, safety, and welfare while also avoiding adverse impacts. It is the
intent of this chapter to encourage the development of SESs that reduce
reliance on foreign and out-of-state energy resources, and bolster local
economic development and job creation. This chapter is not intended to abridge
safety, health or environmental requirements contained in other applicable
codes, standards, or ordinances. The provisions of this chapter shall not be
deemed to nullify any provisions of local, State or Federal law. (Ord. 2019-
1585, 3-19-2019)
10-12-2: DEFINITIONS:
   ACCESSORY: As applied to a building, structure, or use, one which is on the
same lot with, incidental to and subordinate to the main or principal structure
or use and which is used for purposes customarily incidental to the main or
principal structure, or the main or principal use.
   BUILDING INTEGRATED SYSTEMS: A solar energy system that consists of
integrating photovoltaic modules into the building structure as the roof or
facade and which does not alter the relief of the roof.
   GROUND MOUNT SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEM: A solar energy system that is directly
installed into the ground and is not attached or affixed to an existing
structure.
   PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM: A solar energy system that produces electricity by the
use of semiconductor devices called photovoltaic cells that generate
electricity whenever light strikes them.
   QUALIFIED SOLAR INSTALLER: A trained and qualified electrical professional
who has the skills and knowledge related to the construction and operation of
solar electrical equipment and installations and has received safety training
on the hazards involved.
   ROOF MOUNT: A solar energy system in which solar panels are mounted on top
of a building roof as either a flush mounted system or as modules fixed to
frames which can be tilted toward the south at an optical angle.
   SOLAR ENERGY: Radiant energy received from the sun that can be collected in
the form of heat or light by a solar collector.
   SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEM (SES): The components and subsystems required to convert
solar energy into electric or thermal energy suitable for use. The area of the
system includes all the land inside the perimeter of the system, which extends
to any fencing. The term applies, but is not limited to, solar photovoltaic
systems, solar thermal systems and solar hot water systems. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-
19-2019)
10-12-3: ROOF MOUNT SESs:
Roof mount SESs shall be permitted with a building permit in all zoning
districts where there is a principal structure. The building permit application
shall be submitted and shall demonstrate compliance with all applicable zoning
requirements. Building or roof mount SESs shall not exceed the maximum allowed
height for principal structures in any zoning district, and the collector
surface and mounting devices shall not extend beyond the exterior perimeter of
the building on which the system is mounted or built. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-19-
2019)
10-12-4: GROUND MOUNT SESs:
Ground mount solar energy systems shall be permitted in all zoning districts
only with a special use permit, subject to the following conditions:
   A.   Height: Ground mount SESs shall not exceed eight feet (8') in height
when oriented at maximum tilt.
   B.   Residential Zoning Districts:   SESs shall not be allowed as the
primary use or the principal structure in any Residential Zoning District.
Ground mount SESs shall not be allowed in a front yard of any Residential
Zoning District.
   C.   Setbacks:
      1.   Ground mount SESs shall meet the accessory structure setbacks for
the zoning district in which the unit is located, but in no event shall the
setback be less than five feet (5').
      2.   Ground mount SESs shall not extend beyond the side yard or rear yard
setback when oriented at minimum design tilt.
      3.   Ground mount SES installations shall not be located within fifty
feet (50') of any principal structure that is used for residential purposes
unless the owner of the property with the residential structure joins in the
application for special use for the ground mount SES.
   D.   Screening: All ground mount SES installations shall be appropriately
screened as reasonably determined during the special use permit process set
forth in section
10-12-7 of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-19-2019)
10-12-5: REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL SESs:
   A.   Reflection Angles: Reflection angles for solar collectors shall be
oriented such that they do not project glare onto adjacent properties.
   B.   Visibility: Solar energy systems shall be located in a manner to
reasonably minimize view blockage for surrounding properties and shading of
property to the north while still providing adequate solar access for
collectors.
   C.   Safety: Roof mount SESs, excluding building integrated systems, shall
allow for adequate roof access for firefighting purposes to the south facing or
flat roof upon which the panels are mounted.
   D.   Building Code: All SESs shall meet the requirements of the applicable
Village Building and Property Maintenance Codes.
   E.   Installation: All SES installations shall be performed by a qualified
solar installer.
   F.   Connection Inspection: Any connection of an SES to the public utility
grid shall be inspected by the appropriate public utility.
   G.   Approved Solar Components: Electric SES system components shall have a
UL listing or approved equivalent.
   H.   Appearance: Brand labels that are visible from the lot boundary of the
subject property shall be removed. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-19-2019)
10-12-6: BUILDING INTEGRATED SYSTEMS:
Building Integrated Systems shall be permitted in all zoning districts but
shall meet the requirements of the applicable Village Building and Property
Maintenance Codes. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-19-2019)
10-12-7: SPECIAL USE REQUIREMENTS:
All ground mount solar energy systems, including those that are the primary use
of the lot or are designed for providing energy to off-site uses or export to
the wholesale market, require a special use permit. The special use permit
application shall include, in addition to all information generally required
for special use applications, all of the following:
   A.   Property Lines: Existing property lines.
   B.   Buildings And Surfaces: Existing buildings and impervious surfaces.
   C.   Site Plan: A site plan of proposed conditions showing the following:
      1.   Location and spacing of the solar panels.
      2.   New electrical equipment other than at the existing building or
substation that is to be the connection point for the SES.
      3.   Perimeter fencing having a maximum height of eight feet (8') shall
be installed around the boundary of the SES. The fence shall contain
appropriate warning signage that is posted such that it is clearly visible on
the site.
   D.   Manufacturer Specifications: The manufacturer's specifications and
recommended installation methods for all major equipment, including solar
panels, mounting systems and foundations for poles and racks.
   E.   Connection And Interconnection: A description of the method of
connecting the solar array to a building or substation, and utility
interconnection details with a copy of written notification to the utility
company requesting the proposed interconnection.
   F.   Setbacks: Information establishing that the SES is located a minimum of
fifty feet (50') from any principal residential dwelling that is not part the
special use permit. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-19-2019)
10-12-8: ADMINISTRATION:
Any person or business entity who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, refuses
to comply with, or resists enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter
shall face fines of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2019-1585, 3-19-2019)
CHAPTER 13
RECREATIONAL ADULT-USE CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
10-13-1: Purpose
10-13-2: Conditional Use Permits
10-13-3: Adult-Use Cannabis Craft Grower
10-13-4: Adult-Use Cannabis Cultivation Center
10-13-5: Adult-Use Cannabis Dispensing Organization
10-13-6: Adult-Use Cannabis Infuser Organization
10-13-7: Adult-Use Cannabis Processing Organization
10-13-8: Adult-Use Cannabis Transporting Organization
10-13-9: Co-Location
10-13-10: On-Site Use Or Consumption
10-13-11: Security And Other Improvements
10-13-12: Application Procedure
10-13-1: PURPOSE:
It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to provide regulations regarding
the cultivation, processing, transporting, and dispensing of adult-use cannabis
occurring within the corporate limits of the village. Such facilities shall
comply with all regulations provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act,
(410 ILCS 705/1-1 et seq.), as it may be amended from time-to-time, and
regulations promulgated thereunder, and the regulations provided below. In the
event that the Act is amended, the more restrictive of the state or local
regulations shall apply. (Ord. 2019-1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-2: CONDITIONAL USE PERMITS:
   A.   Standards: An adult-use cannabis business establishment shall require
approval as a conditional use in the respective zoning use district in which
such organization is to be located. In determining compliance with this chapter
and eligibility as a conditional use, the following standards shall be
evaluated for the proposed adult-use cannabis business establishment based on
the entirety of the circumstances affecting the particular property for which
the conditional use is sought in the context of the existing and intended
future use of the adjacent and nearby properties:
      1.   Impact of the proposed facility on existing or planned uses located
within the vicinity of the subject property.
      2.   Proposed structure in which the facility will be located, including
co-tenancy (if in a multi-tenant building), total square footage, security
installations/security plan and building code compliance.
      3.   Hours of operation, and anticipated number of customers and
employees.
      4.   Anticipated parking demand and available private parking supply.
      5.   Anticipated traffic generation in the context of adjacent roadway
capacity and access to such roadways.
      6.   Site design, including access points and internal site circulation.
      7.   The adequacy of security measures.
      8.   Proposed signage plan.
      9.   Compliance with all requirements provided in this chapter as
applicable.
      10.   Other criteria determined to be necessary to assess compliance with
this chapter.
   B.   Conditions: Upon application to and approval by the board of trustees
an adult-use cannabis business establishment may be allowed by a conditional
use permit, but only under the following conditions:
      1.   No adult-use cannabis business establishment shall conduct any sale
or distribution of cannabis other than as authorized by applicable state and
local laws and regulations, including the CRTA and the provisions of this
chapter.
      2.   All adult-use cannabis business establishments shall operate the
establishment in compliance with all applicable state and local laws and
regulations, including the CRTA and the provisions of this chapter.
      3.   No adult-use cannabis business establishment nor any other person or
entity shall engage in advertising that contains any statement or illustration
that:
         a.   Is false or misleading;
         b.   Promotes overconsumption of cannabis or cannabis products;
         c.   Depicts a person under twenty- one (21) years of age consuming
cannabis;
         d.   Makes any health, medicinal or therapeutic claims about cannabis
or cannabis-infused products;
         e.   Includes the image of a cannabis leaf or bud; or
         f.   Includes any image designed or likely to appeal to minors,
including cartoons, toys, animals, or children, or any other likeness to
images, characters, or phrases that is designed in any manner to be appealing
to or encourage consumption of persons under twenty-one (21) years of age.
      4.   No adult-use cannabis business establishment nor any other person or
entity shall place or maintain, or cause to be placed or maintained, an
advertisement of cannabis or cannabis-infused product in any form or through
any medium, including any sign under Title 9, Chapter 4:
         a.   In violation of the village sign code under Title 9, Chapter 4;
         b.   Within one thousand (1,000) feet of the perimeter of school
grounds, a playground, a recreation center or facility, a child care center, a
public park or public library, or a game arcade to which admission is not
restricted to persons twenty-one (21) years of age or older;
         c.   On or in a public transit vehicle or public transit shelter;
         d.   On or in publicly owned or publicly operated property; or
         e.   That contains information that:
         i.   Is false or misleading;
         ii.   Promotes excessive consumption;
         iii.   Depicts a person under twenty-one (21) years of age consuming
cannabis;
         iv.   Includes the image of a cannabis leaf; or
         v.   Includes any image designed or likely appeal to minors, including
cartoons, toys, animals, or children, or any other likeness to images,
characters, or phrases that are popularly used to advertise to children, or any
imitation of candy packaging or labeling, or that promotes consumption of
cannabis. (Ord. 2019-1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-3: ADULT-USE CANNABIS CRAFT GROWER:
In those zoning use districts in which an adult-use cannabis craft grower may
be located, the proposed facility must comply with the following:
   A.   No more than one (1) adult-use cannabis craft grower shall be granted a
conditional use under this chapter or otherwise permitted in the village.
   B.   Facility shall not be located within one thousand five hundred (1,500)
feet of another adult-use cannabis craft grower or adult-use cannabis
cultivation center; or
   C.   Facility shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of the
property line of a preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school or daycare center, daycare home, group daycare home, part day
childcare facility, public park, public library, residential substance abuse
treatment facility, or place of worship located within the village. (Ord. 2019-
1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-4: ADULT-USE CANNABIS CULTIVATION CENTER:
In those zoning use districts in which an adult-use cannabis cultivation center
may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the following:
   A.   No more than one (1) adult-use cannabis cultivation center shall be
granted a conditional use under this chapter or otherwise permitted to operate
in the village.
   B.   Facility shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of the
property line of a preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school or daycare center, daycare home, group daycare home, part day
childcare facility, public park, public library, residential substance abuse
treatment facility, or place of worship located within the village. (Ord. 2019-
1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-5: ADULT-USE CANNABIS DISPENSING ORGANIZATION:
In those zoning use districts in which an adult-use cannabis dispensing
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   A.   No more than one (1) adult-use cannabis dispensing organization shall
be granted a conditional use under this chapter or otherwise permitted to
operate in the village.
   B.   Facility shall not be located within one thousand five hundred (1,500)
feet of the property line of a pre-existing adult-use cannabis dispensing
organization.
   C.   Facility shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of the
property line of a preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school or daycare center, daycare home, group daycare home, part day
childcare facility, public park, public library, residential substance abuse
treatment facility, or place of worship located within the village.
   D.   No person shall reside in or permit a person to reside in the facility.
   E.   Facility shall not permit any person under the age of twenty-one (21)
to enter a dispensing organization; provided, however, that if the facility is
also licensed as a medical cannabis dispensing organization, persons under the
age of twenty-one (21) may be permitted to enter only if accompanied by a
parent or guardian.
   F.   No drive-through services or sales shall be permitted.
   G.   No outdoor seating shall be permitted.
   H.   Hours of operation shall not be earlier than eight o’clock (8:00) A.M.
and not later than nine o’clock (9:00) P.M.
   I.   Facility shall not operate if its video surveillance equipment is
inoperative.
   J.   Facility shall not have fewer than two (2) people working at the
facility at any time while the facility is open to the public.
   K.   Consumption of adult-use cannabis on the premises, including the
parking area, shall be prohibited except as authorized by majority vote of the
village board of trustees in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 2019-1608, 12-
17-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-1684, 9-6-2022)
10-13-6: ADULT-USE CANNABIS INFUSER ORGANIZATION:
In those zoning use districts in which an adult-use cannabis infuser
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   A.   No more than one (1) adult-use cannabis infuser organization shall be
granted a conditional use under this chapter or otherwise permitted to operate
in the village.
   B.   Facility shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of the
property line of a preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school or daycare center, daycare home, group daycare home, part day
childcare facility, public park, public library, residential substance abuse
treatment facility, or place of worship located within the village. (Ord. 2019-
1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-7: ADULT-USE CANNABIS PROCESSING ORGANIZATION:
In those zoning use districts in which an adult-use cannabis processing
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   A.   No more than one (1) adult-use cannabis processing organization shall
be granted a conditional use under this chapter or otherwise permitted in the
village.
   B.   Facility shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of the
property line of a preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school or daycare center, daycare home, group daycare home, part day
childcare facility, public park, public library, residential substance abuse
treatment facility, or place of worship located within the village. (Ord. 2019-
1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-8: ADULT-USE CANNABIS TRANSPORTING ORGANIZATION:
In those zoning use districts in which an adult-use cannabis transporting
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   A.   No more than one (1) adult-use cannabis transporting organization shall
be granted a conditional use under this chapter or otherwise permitted in the
village.
   B.   Facility shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of the
property line of a preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school or daycare center, daycare home, group daycare home, part day
childcare facility, public park, public library, residential substance abuse
treatment facility, or place of worship located within the village. (Ord. 2019-
1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-9: CO-LOCATION:
If an adult-use cannabis dispensing organization seeks to co-locate with an
adult-use cannabis craft grower, an adult-use infuser organization, or both,
such establishment must include such a statement and plan for its impact and
operation in its application for conditional use. The zoning board of appeals
shall consider the application and may take appropriate action to impose
additional conditions as necessary and make recommendations to the village
board of trustees. Upon recommendation by the zoning board of appeals, the
village board of trustees may deny or authorize the co-location of such
establishments by final approval by a majority vote of the village board of
trustees. (Ord. 2019-1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-10: ON-SITE USE OR CONSUMPTION:
If an adult-use cannabis business establishment seeks to allow on-premises
consumption of adult-use cannabis, such establishment must include such a
statement and plan for its impact and operation in its application for
conditional use. The zoning board of appeals shall consider the application and
may take appropriate action to impose additional conditions as necessary and
make recommendations to the village board of trustees. Upon recommendation by
the zoning board of appeals, the village board of trustees may deny or
authorize the on-premises consumption by final approval by a majority vote of
the village board of trustees. (Ord. 2019-1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-11: SECURITY AND OTHER IMPROVEMENTS:
Upon approval of a conditional use, the owner or operator of the adult-use
cannabis business establishment shall install building enhancements, such as
security cameras, lighting or other improvements, as set forth in the
conditional use permit, to ensure the safety of employees and customers of the
adult-use cannabis business establishment, as well as surrounding property
owners. Said improvements shall be determined based on the specific
characteristics of the floor plan for an adult-use cannabis business
establishment and the site on which it is located, consistent with the
requirements of the CRTA. (Ord. 2019-1608, 12-17-2019)
10-13-12: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
An adult-use cannabis business establishment shall require approval as a
conditional use in the respective zoning district in which such establishment
is sought to be located. An application for a conditional use permit under this
section shall be processed in the same manner and with the same review and
approval process as required for a special use permit under section
10-3-4 , except the standards set forth in section
10-13-2 (A) shall apply in lieu of the special use standards set forth in
section
10-3-4 (E). Further, the other provisions of section
10-3-4  shall apply to a conditional use granted under this chapter except as
otherwise provided herein. The application for a conditional use permit shall
include an affidavit of the applicant affirming compliance with the applicable
section of this section, all requirements of the CRTA, and any restrictions,
stipulations or conditions imposed during the review and approval process.
(Ord. 2019-1608, 12-17-2019)
TITLE 11
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
Village Regulations   1
County Subdivision Code   2
CHAPTER 1
VILLAGE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
11-1-1: Approval And Certification Required
11-1-2: Subdivision Plats
11-1-3: Water System
11-1-4: Record Of Subdivisions
11-1-5: Penalty
11-1-6: Exceptions To Standards Within Overlay Zoning District
11-1-1: APPROVAL AND CERTIFICATION REQUIRED:
   A.   No map or plat of a subdivision of lands situated in the Village, or of
any addition thereto, shall have any force, validity or effect, or be recorded
by the Recorder of Peoria County, until the same shall have been approved by
the Village Board of Trustees and so certified by the Village Clerk. (1914 Code
§ 12-1)
   B.   No such map, plat or subdivision shall be approved until the same shall
be certified by a competent surveyor and acknowledged by the owner, as provided
by the general laws of this State, and said owner or owners shall make oath
that they believe that they are the owners in fee of the property described in
said plat, and shall furnish the certificate of a reputable attorney that he
has examined the title to said property and has found the fee thereof to be in
the person making such plat, and that such property is free from incumbrance,
or if there is any incumbrance on said property, the persons holding such
incumbrance shall join in said plat and consent thereto in writing, such
consent being written upon said plat and properly acknowledged. (1914 Code §
12-3)
   C.   The Village Board of Trustees shall require a duplicate copy of such
map, plat or subdivision, if approved thereby, to be filed in the Office of the
Village Clerk. (1914 Code § 12-4)
11-1-2: SUBDIVISION PLATS:
   A.   Preliminary Plat: Any owner or owners of a tract of land in the Village
desiring to develop a subdivision shall submit to the President and Board of
Trustees two (2) copies of a plat for the use and development of the proposed
subdivision in tentative form. Said plat shall hereinafter be designated as a
"preliminary plat" and shall conform to the following requirements:
      1.   Every lot shall have an area of not less than six thousand (6,000)
square feet. Every lot shall have a minimum width of sixty feet (60') and a
depth of not less than one hundred feet (100').
      2.   Said plat shall be drawn to a scale of not smaller than one hundred
feet to the inch (1" = 100').
      3.   All section lines, adjacent subdivision lines, street and alley
lines, watercourses and existing features pertinent to a proper subdivision
shall be shown.
      4.   The name of the proposed subdivision and name of owner, or trustee
as owner, are to be shown.
      5.   The width of all proposed streets and roads with their proposed
names, alleys, lots, easements and building lines on property proposed to be
subdivided and the full width of streets bounding the proposed street names
shall conform to existing streets, if possible and logical, and shall not
conflict with other names in the territory. The minimum width of streets and
roads shall be fifty feet (50') with the placement of the curb lines to provide
a minimum width of traveled way of thirty feet (30').
      6.   All lot lines shall be shown and the lots properly numbered or
lettered. Building lines and easements shall be shown and determined by
measurements.
      7.   No lot or combination of lots shall be resubdivided for building
purposes not producing at least six thousand (6,000) square feet.
      8.   The subdivider shall provide all curbs, gutters, and a road of seven
inches (7") of compacted gravel.
      9.   The subdivider shall stipulate that he will grade, drain and surface
all streets shown on plat and maintain them in good repair for one year
thereafter, at which time, the Village shall assume the maintenance thereof.
      10.   When laying utilities, the subdivider shall provide a stub for
future openings for each lot. (Ord. 405, 8-15-1955)
      11.   Where the subdivider contemplates a change in classification of the
subdivision, as to zoning, the owner shall present a request for such change
indicating the areas desired and present the required change to the Zoning
Board of Appeals. (Ord. 405, 8-15-1955; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Final Plat: Within ninety (90) days after approval of the preliminary
plat, the original tracing of the final plat made in accordance with the
preliminary plat, together with a print thereof, shall be submitted to the
Village President and Board of Trustees. Such final plat shall bear a
certificate of approval by the Village President and Board of Trustees. (Ord.
405, 8-15-1955)
11-1-3: WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   Any person who develops a subdivision shall be responsible for the
installation of all necessary water mains. Unless the developer, owner or
contractor agrees so to do, no permit shall issue for the development of said
subdivision. (Ord. 896, 9-6-1977; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   All water mains hereafter constructed in any subdivision or addition to
the Village, whether platted or unplatted, or whether said plat has or has not
been accepted by the Village President and Board of Trustees, shall be of such
size and materials as shall be first approved in writing by the Village
President and Board of Trustees, and no such water mains shall be constructed
without written application for a permit to construct the same having first
been made to the Village President and Board of Trustees and permission in
writing granted by the Village President and Board of Trustees for the
construction of the same. (Ord. 392, 3-7-1955)
11-1-4: RECORD OF SUBDIVISIONS:
The Village Clerk shall keep a record of all such maps and plats showing the
property subdivided, the date of said approval, and the date of recording.
(1914 Code § 12-6; amd. 2016 Code)
11-1-5: PENALTY:
Any owner of land in the Village, or any addition thereto, who shall violate
the provisions of this chapter by making any plat or selling or offering to
sell any lot according to any plat in which there is not compliance with this
chapter shall forfeit a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense. (1914 Code § 12-5; amd. 2016 Code)
11-1-6: EXCEPTIONS TO STANDARDS WITHIN OVERLAY ZONING DISTRICT:
Where the Village Board has designated an overlay zoning district in accordance
with the provisions of title 10 of this Code and the plan approved for that
overlay district contains standards for the subdivision of land or the
construction of improvements related to the subdivision of land which are
inconsistent with the standards established in this chapter, then the standards
established in the plan for the overlay district shall prevail over the
standards established in this chapter. Except where specifically superseded or
modified in the overlay district plan approved upon the designation of an
overlay district, all regulations pertaining to the subdivision of land as set
forth in this title shall continue to apply within the overlay district as if
the overlay district did not exist. (Ord. 2018-1570, 10-16-2018)
CHAPTER 2
COUNTY SUBDIVISION CODE
SECTION:
11-2-1: Adopted
11-2-2: Administration
11-2-3: Additional Guidelines
11-2-1: ADOPTED:
   A.   The village of Peoria Heights hereby adopts by reference the county
subdivision code as it now exists or may from time to time hereafter be
amended.
   B.   For purposes of this chapter, the "county subdivision code" consists of
the following sections of the code of Peoria County:
      1.   Chapter 20, article 3, section 3.14 - subdivision.
      2.   Chapter 20, article 3, section 3.15 - subdivision waivers and
appeals.
      3.   Chapter 20, article 3, section 3.16 - plat approval.
      4.   Chapter 20, article 8 - subdivisions. (Ord. 2016-1464, 3-15-2016)
11-2-2: ADMINISTRATION:
For purposes of administering the county subdivision code within the village of
Peoria Heights, the following substitutions and/or references shall apply:
   A.   Any reference in the county subdivision code to the Peoria County board
shall be deemed to be a reference to the village board of the village of Peoria
Heights.
   B.   Any reference in the county subdivision code to the Peoria County
zoning board of appeals shall be deemed to be a reference to the zoning board
of appeals of the village of Peoria Heights.
   C.   Any reference in the county subdivision code to "department", "plat
officer" or any officer or administrative body not otherwise described above
shall be deemed to be a reference to the village administrator of the village
of Peoria Heights.
   D.   Any reference in the county subdivision code to the county engineer
shall be deemed to be a reference to a consulting engineer retained by the
village if deemed necessary by the village administrator. (Ord. 2016-1464, 3-
15-2016)
11-2-3: ADDITIONAL GUIDELINES:
   A.   References within the county subdivision code to the Peoria County
comprehensive land use plan and the future land use form map of Peoria County
shall not apply with respect to application of the county subdivision code
within the village of Peoria Heights.
   B.   Any provision of the county subdivision code requiring review or
certification by the Peoria County health department or any township shall not
apply with respect to the application of the county subdivision code within the
village of Peoria Heights.
   C.   Any reference in the county subdivision code to Peoria County zoning
regulations or the application of such regulations shall be deemed to be a
reference to the zoning ordinance of the village of Peoria Heights as from time
to time amended. (Ord. 2016-1464, 3-15-2016)
